content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												This is my first time finishing the game, and I have also played through the first game. Although it kept the same quality of epic storyline, a lot was noticeably different to the first game, is more complicated in a lot of its mechanics and I found the combat more difficult, although I got used to it in the end. I liked the way you had to think about things a lot more, use more strategy in battle, use all the signs, traps and bombs, not just Aard/coup-de-grace everything in sight. The quests are also more complicated, they are no longer WoW-style kill 20 things/collect 20 things quests, they almost all have multiple ways to resolve them and some of the possible ways require you to find out things the game doesn't automatically tell you about. Even shopping is more complicated, there is a crafting system with templates to buy, and money is often scarce. A lot of potions have drawbacks and levelling up involves a more detailed skill tree. I enjoyed the return of the poker dice quest, as well as Geralt's adventures in arm-wrestling and prize-fighting. I would recommend playing it, as it has a good story, good music and satisfying gameplay, the most important things in an RPG for me, I have a few complaints: The game sometimes hangs for no discernable reason (I am using a fairly high-end Windows 8.1 laptop), which the first game also did. The 'mature' aspects of the game are getting more tacky. I quite liked the erotic artwork and occasionally bizarre implied sexual tastes of the first game, but they've been replaced by the same incredibly repetitive cut scene that leaves virtually nothing to the imagination. Even when Geralt meets the succubus, there's nothing particularly remarkable about his amorous adventures. Also, ALL the NPCs make ribald jokes and swear for no particular reason ALL THE WAY THROUGH THE GAME. And, inevitably, there are lesbians for humorous effect. It feels kind of immature, not mature. The level of explicit violence is also getting more needlessly extreme and gratuitous. and the cut scenes in the strange animated style faintly annoy me.The story still feels unresolved, as the problems you solve mostly come back as soon your back is turned, which gets my mood a little low. Geralt doesn't seem to really have much effect on the wider story of the world, he just solves his own personal storyline, mostly getting his memory back. Everyone is still at war, everything is still a damn mess. It's like a tabletop game where the GM won't let you actually change his beloved world. The growing Wild Hunt theme is the most interesting part of the story that seems to actually concern you, and the third Witcher game is called Wild Hunt, so maybe the plot will actually get somewhere next game?

												Right after i finished number 1, i started with the second witcher game. And I can safely say I am pleased with this game. This game has the perefct balance between story, gameplay, and game lenght. There's quite a bit of dialog, but if you dont like it, you can just skip the talking. This is a rpg game for adults. There's politics, ethical problems, and a bunch of hard choises to make. I spent about 35 hours, and I did almost everything the game has to offer. There's an arena mode wich does not have anything to do with the story of the game, where you fight against increasingly hard waves of enemies, wich game me an hour of enjoyment, but you can play it for quite a bit. In summary, this is one of the best games I have played. The story is amazing, and i was caught in the situations of the game at all times. I was suprised when the game was finished, since I didn't feel time flowing. The gameplay is an HUGE upgrade from the last one, and skill is a bigger factor than stats. The lore and immersion is fantastisc, i actually went through all the books i found. It altso looks amazing, still, in 2016. This one is among the best games I have played, and it deserves a 10/10. Now, I'm starting the third, and probably the last game in the series. Va'fail!

content:
Posted: February 22
												What an immersive tale! This game really ticks all the boxes (except for one very minor point) for a great RPG.Since I played this game right after finishing the first Witcher game I need to say how much more fun the game is to play. Even if there's a fair amount of 'backtracking' it never feels like a chore. My main problem with the first game (the fighting mechanics) got a complete overhaul and are now actually one of the game's stronger points.The presentation is great. The graphical style, the oversaturated colours and the effects really add up to an amazing experience even today. The music and sound effects are very atmospheric too. The voice acting is even better than in the first game and that's quite a feat to achieve.One major issue with the game is the length. It's just too short! It's an intense ride and after 30 to 40 hours you just don't feel like letting go. Luckily there's a really good incentive to replay the game right away (which I'll do now).Another minor complain is the save system. You can save manually and can quicksave, but you can't overwrite older manual saves nor quicksaves. That leads to a huge amount of save files if you don't delete them manually... one by one. Really don't know why the game does it this way.The plot and the characters are the main flesh of the game and they are making the whole game the gem that it is. The three chapters are perfectly balanced and not at all streched out this time. I only wish there was a bit more to do besides the main story, but I gladly take the 'no filler' approach if it's this well made.The game is great and even if it's packed with cutscenes, they are all worth it. Just a great RPG that makes me hungry for the third part.

Basic InformationTitle:  The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings Enhanced EditionDeveloper:  CD PROJEKT REDPublisher:  CD PROJEKT REDGenre:  Role Playing GameGeneral ImpressionA sequel that improves in almost every way compared to its predecessor and paved the way for the masterpiece that is The Witcher 3. The trilogy has constantly changed to cater the needs and desires of its fanbase, a thing most evidently found in the streamlining process of The Witcher 2 in regards to the first one in the series. The graphics in Assassins of Kings are gorgeous and demanding even after 5 years since its release. You will need both a decent system and plenty of time to enjoy this game. It's not worth rushing through it or skipping any dialogue. In fact, I highly recommend that you play and finish The Witcher 1 first, so that you may import your very own save file (and game choices) into Witcher 2. This save system and the choices that ultimately matter, make the series as fascinating as Mass Effect or Dragon Age. Only the best crafted RPGs care for player choices throughout several gameplays.Strong Points+ Gorgeous graphics.+ Excellent storyline and setting.+ Steam Trading Cards & Achievements.Weak Points-  A few glitches.Rating 10/10 This review was submitted for Imperial Reviews and Cubbes.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												The 2011 Game of the Year.Let me start off by saying that the first Witcher finally made me start playing RPG's. It's a game that I am still thinking of once in a while even years after I beat it. It's a game, although with limited amount of NPC (even the enhanced version) and some minor issues, that will stand the test of time. It's a game, whose soundtrack I am still listening to. It's a game whose folklore still captivates me with its creativity and versatility.The art direction in this game is bound to get some awards at the end of the year. It is perplexing just to look at the distant vistas that are missing from so many games. The first Witcher pulled that off on occasion. Such areas as The Lake provided you with the feeling like you were in a big world even though you were confined to an average-size area. Witcher 2 takes this to another level. Not only do you get to enjoy the distant cascading vistas that are staggered by layers and layers of the nearby and the faraway horizons, you also get to enjoy the near environments teeming with life. Yes, we have seen some impressive NPC behavior in the past but this time, the behavior of some of the NPC is near unpredictable. And don't expect them to stand around this time and have same faces.The game features extremely well written dialogue with plenty of words that I had to look up. The story arches in many different directions depending on your actions or inactions. This is a very very mature game. I was able to import my last saves from the first game - which supposedly influences some of the dialogue between the characters. Some of the events are also going to be influenced, supposedly...The long loading times when you enter a new area or even a small house are gone now. Also, if you walk inside someone's premises, you will be amazed by the attention to detail. They devs haven't missed anything on this one.In general, Witcher 2 instantly sucks you in with its immense ambience. I cannot even begin to describe the feelings I had when I was walking through the forest for the first time. Sometimes I find myself standing still in the forest and attempting to look as far as I can and behind every tree you can see another tree and so on...I have never seen anything like it. I also love the background blur.Do not expect this game to be easy though. It is pretty hard. The combat system takes a while to get used to. You will have to time your attacks with almost near precision. Not only that, you will have to combine your regular attacks with your special attacks to cause the maximum amount of damage. The battle system in the first game was sort of a war of attrition. You would usually be surrounded by enemies and you'd have to quickly switch in between your fighting moves to finish everyone off before you yourself died. It will probably take you a while to be able to come out of the fights near-unscathed. So at first you will most likely die and die and die.The game however, gives you plenty of opportunity to roam around and collect herbs before you get into doing heavy quests. In most RPG's, there is no indication of how hard one or another quest is going to be. But we always assume that we will be able to complete it. This game does not let you do that.And unlike the first game that heavily required the use of potions on the Hardest mode, this game require the use of potions on the Medium mode. This time, you really have to look for those ingredients.The ironic thing is that even if you are able to stuff your pockets with the ingredients, you still only know the very basic alchemy at the beginning of the game. So using the temporary oils that will temporarily enhance your melee attacks is essential.Quests. Ok, do you remember all those silly fetching quests in Dragon Age 2 that take place on the same areas over and over again? Now you can forget about all that. I cannot believe that the writers of these games still haven't run out of original ideas for the secondary quests.I am also happy to see some of the Witcher 1 monsters coming back. Not to mention the fact that they look better and move more realistically.Just like with the first game, there is this dichotomy present within human interactions. On one hand, you are the monster slayer, but you are not necessarily the protector of the people. So do not expect to always find sympathizers and allies within the immediate human communities. The racial tensions are still here too and there's plenty of vulgarity to go around.The soundtrack is perfect. Does anyone remember "Peaceful Moments" from the first game? You'll hear plenty of that here.There are also easter eggs pertaining to Assassin's Creed and to the Lord of the Rings.Anyways, I never gave any game a "10", but this game truly deserves it. I really cannot see much wrong with it and I've been playing it since midnight. One thing that is annoying is the disappearing bodies and the ability to loot people's homes without any repercussion. In addition, you really DO have to think ahead and anticipate the movement of your foes.All in all, I got myself a collector's edition. If anyone can afford to get it, please get it - the devs need our support. I won't hesitate to say that this is the most beautiful game ever created, so far; and so far it is my favorite game of all time, until the Witcher 3, of course...I am also happy to boast that on May 13, 2013 after approximately 170 hours of trying I was able to beat the game on Insane difficulty (as in beating the game with permadeath difficulty).

												In the simplest terms, starting to play Witcher 2 is a lot like taking a vacation to a country where you go only sightseeing: you'll sure see some amazing and cool stuff, but you'll have to suffer a lot of unnecessary punishment, fatigue and stress (I pat myself on the back for this analogy). I mean the difficultly curve, interface and mechanics sadly limit the game's appeal. But maybe it's because the developers intentionally don't want to cater to the mainstream audience. And that's probably the attitude that is needed in order to create one of the few adult video games that confidently stands tall as a good game with it's own heart and identity.

												A great Role Playing Game.What i felt was good:+ The design of the world, it is beautifully handcrafted.+ Rich lore (there were books before there was a game).+ Voice acting is great.+ No pansy censorship.+ You have to actually study/read ingame books to figure out how to battle certain enemies or what piece of puzzle you are missing to finish a quest (one does not simply "find an Endrega Queen in XY coordinate marked on your map"). Of course you can accidentally figure it all out, no triggers. Sometimes I'd wish one could sprint for brief moments. You will find yourself running across big towns a lot, at least they are beautiful.Unsure:~ Getting used to combat mechanics takes a while, but partially it is about knowledge of enemy and how to counter it.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2016
												Firstly, if you seek to play the Witcher 3: Wild Hunt, I recommend getting the Witcher 2 first.I have never bought the first game in the series, with outdated graphics and combat, but I am really glad to have played this.The highlights of the game are quite definitely the graphics and the story. For a 2011 game, the world looks beautiful. Textures can look a bit grainy at times, but they are so colourful and vibrant you'll end up loving them.As for the story, what the Witcher series does best (at least the 2 games I've played), is make you feel like you're the main character, you ARE Geralt, his friends are your friends. This is what makes the franchise special. The plot is about Geralt trying to get his memory back, him getting framed for a crime, and all this is intertwined with a political plot. It might get a tad confusing at times though.The game is a lot about decisions. Remember, a single line of dialogue can change your whole journey.As far as combat goes, it's fun, but I HIGHLY recommend playing on normal or hard, as easy mode makes fighting human enemies a joke. I figured this after having played easy for a while, and I got rekt.Onto the caveats.The ui is a bit hard to understand, and not too user friendly. Alchemy is not too fun, although it might be me hating consumables (which is another reason why I love Wild Hunt!).The world is not exactly open world. The game is divided into three main zones, through which you can progress by doing the main quests. You can freely explore one area, but you can't go back to previous ones. And you really have no reason to explore much other than doing quests or destroy monster nests.The most frustrating part about the game for me are the invisible walls. 98% of the time you can't even fall off a ledge or go in water. The Flotsam Forest is actually a maze, because you can't go through bushes. Still, I did play this game just after playing 2 "wall-less" RPGs, so maybe it's just me.Anyway, definitely recommended, will help to understand the Witcher 3's story (you might wanna look up The Witcher 1's story before playing this, it will help you with your initial interrogation).8/10

number of helpful: 479 of 817 people (59%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
												First of all I’d like to state that although I have clicked the ‘do not recommend’ option, my position toward the game is one of neutrality, neither dismissing it as unplayable nor condoning the exuberant praise that The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings seems to receive. The game has many redeeming features which shall be discussed shortly, however I feel as though there are just as many aspects that make the player underwhelmed with his/her experience. Secondly, I should say that this review builds upon my review of the original Witcher, which I have also reviewed on Steam, so I will be making a few comparative points in light of my disposition toward the first instalment in the series.The Witcher 2 is driven extremely well by an engrossing narrative of political intrigue, racial prejudice and social injustice. Although the hybrid of Medieval and fantasy themes has been done before and is far from original, The Witcher 2 fully embraces the combination and creates a three-dimensional world with rounded and well thought-out characters that have their own individual agendas and follow them accordingly. There are a few plot twists along the way which I, of course, won’t mention, but these keep the narrative feeling fresh and engaging enough to continue playing til the end. I would say that the story, fresh from the pages of the original comics, is the main factor encouraging gamers to try this game.Furthermore, we aren’t babysat. Nothing has been toned or dumbed down, which is preferable as too few games are made in modern times that have been made for an adult audience. We are shoehorned immediately into the action and I think that’s why the game puts many people off in the initial stages, claiming it to be unfriendly to new users to the series. I would argue this is a commendable feature however, as the harsh and merciless world of Geralt is directly reflected in the games content and contextual features. The combat is far more engaging than in the original WItcher, due simply to it being more enjoyable. That being said, it is far from perfect. Battles range from being far too easy to far too hard far too quickly. We can quickly descend into the ‘trial and error’ form of gaming, constantly reloading previous saves in order to trial new ways of beating a difficult enemy. You can also only drink or create potions before a battle, not during it, which is more realistic I accept, but ultimately make many aspects of the combat frustrating. If I realise that a potion improving my vigor regeneration will help me win a battle in its opening stages, why not just let me drink one? The guise of this being ‘unrealistic’ simply makes alchemy and potion consumption frustrating; constantly saving, reloading and drinking potions before a known fight drastically effect the pace of the game and cause a stuttering experience that is cause for concern.Perhaps the most disappointing characteristic of The Witcher 2 though is the world itself. I don’t mean its concept, I mean in its literal physicality. The areas you can explore are minuscule in terms of a 21st century RPG and the areas are quickly covered and recovered time and again. This makes the quests fairly limited, as there is only so much to do in a rather small gaming arena. Quests such as competing at arm wrestling, dice poker and brawling are irrelevant sideshows, yet if you take  these out you are only left with half dozen side quests in Act I and II respectively, and only a couple in the rather brief Act III. The overall longevity of the game is actually rather small, with a completed game taking between 16-30 hours (and that would be being generous). Essentially, there are a fair number of things to do in the world, but there really aren’t that many, certainly not deserving of high merit.Quest exploration (in terms of the map and quest markers) is a rather touchy subject for both fans and haters of the series alike. Fans of this game state that the map and quest hints are intentionally cryptic because the game encourages you to explore yourself, and that we shouldn’t be spoon fed as gamers. Haters of The Witcher 2 point on the map and quest markers are totally useless, broken, and ruin the gaming experience completely. While I totally back the formers idea in theory, in practice the latter is nearer the truth. Quest markers as you approach them do sometimes teleport elsewhere without explanation, whilst the game map has no concept of ‘levels’, meaning that you may arrive at your destination only to discover that its several floors above you, a particular problem in Vergen. If the developers didn’t want to spoon feed the gamer and it was all about exploration and realism, why bother with a quest marker at all? Why, at the beginning of the majority of quests, does it tell us where to go? The quest exploration in the game seems to be a halfway house between attempting to help the gamer and encourage exploration, yet it ends up failing on both counts.A problem with the critiques of the Witcher are of course, the critics themselves. Haters of the series have complained of a lack of fast travel. There is of course, no problem with that whatsoever. The developers have created a game that is very graphically impressive with some engaging characters, all of which they want you to experience. Removing fast travel will enhance the possibility of experiencing these things. Furthermore, the confines of the world itself is rather tiny meaning that fast travel is, for the large part, totally unnecessary anyway, as it does not take particularly long to run from one side of the map to the other. One of my main bones of contention with the previous Witcher instalment was its ‘mature’ content. I stated in my review of that game that having maturity in the game does not make the game mature, and I think that unfortunately still applies to the sequel. I’m not sure if it’s because the translations from Polish to English are not clear enough, but much of the dialogue feels awkward, with characters using expletives, talking of♥♥♥♥♥♥and ‘ploughing’ for the sake of it. I think the developers could have included this content without making it so blasé, and it still seems as though the developers are trying to show off to kids and young teens. Nearly all dialogue refers to some obscenity and it becomes tiresome rather quickly. In fact, many of the characters are unlikeable because of this fact, most noticeably Roache and Ioveth. This does help serve the ‘shades of grey’ approach that the developers are going for, using a ‘lesser of two evils’ mindset, yet it is hard to play out an entire game without at least having a couple of likeable characters that we wish to associate with.  A positive note however, is that the ‘Sex Cards’ from the previous game have been removed, presumably because those who were amused or aroused by such content hit puberty and discovered internet porn.Overall, the experience is okay and the narrative really is interesting. But the content of the game, although acceptable, really is not the experience that many exaggerated reviews on Steam that lavish the praise make out that it is. It has many issues that make it fall down. However, I would say that the commercial success of The Witcher 2 should allow the developers the funds to make The Witcher 3 into something special, reflecting an intriguing and exceptional storyline with equally impressive gaming content (for a change).Please review and comment, any feedback is welcome and thank you for reading.

number of helpful: 28 of 36 people (78%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
  OVERVIEW  The Witcher 2 is a single-player fantasy role-playing game by CD Projekt RED, starring Geralt, the hero from the first game released in 2007. Geralt is a witcher, a ghost-haired mutant that can wield swords and magical powers to dispatch foes. Expect a large cast of characters to interact with, plenty of ways to upgrade and customize Geralt to suit your play style, and at least one boss fight against a giant tentacle beast.From what's been said about the game so far, The Witcher 2 is enormous. The official word is 38 hours long, though it's unclear how much that may vary if you decide to take part in all the side quests and minigames. Like in the first game, your actions while playing affect what happens later. In the sequel, this may mean you'll miss entire towns (as well as the associated storylines and side quests) on your first playthrough. According to the game's official site there'll be four different beginnings and 16 possible endings.  COMBAT SYSTEM  Combat has also received a significant overhaul. Gone is the restrictive timing-based system used in the original, replaced by a more free-form system that should be more familiar to those who play third-person action games. You'll be able to equip lots of different armor pieces this time, as well use weapons, spells and alchemical components to kill your enemies. It's best to use Geralt's steel blade against humanoids and the silver one for monsters. Geralt's active target is painted with an icon, letting you know who you'll strike with an attack.The most important thing to be mindful of in combat is your command wheel, which can be brought up by holding the Ctrl key. Bringing this up slows time and allows you to select one of Geralt's magical signs, as well as switch between combat items. Using the magical signs is a must. Even before they're powered up through leveling, these abilities can set enemies on fire (Igni), stun and root them in place (opportunity to perform finishing kill), knock them down and a temporarily dampen incoming damage (Aard), shield (Quen), trap to immobilize enemies (Yrden) and triggers a hex that causes an enemy to fight alongside with us (Axii).  Axii is my favorite sign while fighting with group opponent. Hexing them to fight along your side will reduce their enforcement pressure towards us when they are tightening their fight.   PERFORMANCE  The Witcher 2 looks great. Only hours in you'll be treated to stunning views of enormous, sweeping vistas from the side of a castle under siege. Nearly every scene is populated with plenty of characters; the animations are more realistic than the first Witcher game during conversations and combat. Contrast lighting and warm color tone really brings up Witcher 2 among the best-looking games in existence - only the facial animation is imperfect. Background music and sound effect suit the atmosphere so much plus good voice acting supports a charismatic script really brings up Witcher 2 as a whole fantastic game.   ACCESSIBILITY  Approaching a sequel to a dense role-playing game can be daunting. If you never played the first, The Witcher 2 stars an established character you may know nothing about and is set in a detailed fictional world you're likely not familiar. Why bother playing if you're not already invested in the story and characters?So far, a number of reasons The Witcher 2 feels like a older style of role-playing epic: a rich, detailed experience packed with curiosities, creative and flexible quest designs, powerful reasons to explore and deep gameplay mechanics. And, as a bonus, it's much prettier than its predecessor.Witcher fans that played all the way through the first game are definitely getting something extra here. For you there's an existing emotional bond with some of the characters. When Triss and Geralt walk across the screen and reference past events and the names of lands and cities, there's an added layer of meaning.If you didn't play The Witcher you'll be missing out on context, but it won't be long until you're caught up in the pressing drama of the sequel. I certainly wouldn't say you should wait to play The Witcher 2 until you've completed the first game. Due to a number of changes, mostly for convenience's sake, The Witcher 2 for now appears to be the better game. There's a definite learning curve when it comes to things like combat, managing the numerous menus and brewing and using potions, but it doesn't take long for it to make sense.  CHOICE AND CONSEQUENCE  Some role-playing games present choice and consequence in very clear terms. Sometimes you're given points for being good and evil. Your overall moral standing is displayed as a giant glowing meter on your character statistics page. All your decisions are distilled into one numerical value. Sometimes your appearance changes and characters react differently to your presence. The aim of all this is the make your decisions feel like they're having an impact in the world, that the virtual people you're helping or terrorizing remember your actions and, as a result, feel a little bit more human.In The Witcher 2, there's no meter for good and evil. Instead, Geralt operates outside the reach of a persistent morality rating. During a quest Geralt can choose to help out or tell people to get lost in blunt, explicit terms. The results aren't as simple as unlocking a few extra dialogue options. Instead, there are significant changes to the direction of the quests.In The Witcher 2, choice is not an illusion. At no point has this been more obvious than how the story develops toward the end of the first Chapter. A decision needs to be made about how to proceed forward, and the impact will radically change how things evolve. It determines the next city you visit, the cast of characters you follow and the quests made available. It changes your entire perspective on the main events of the game.  CRAFTING AND ALCHEMY  Though the core sword-slashing combat of The Witcher 2 might strike you as straightforward – time mouse clicks to string together slices – there are a lot of ways to modify Geralt's effectiveness in battle. One of the best ways to secure upgrades is through crafting. Most of everything that can be used and equipped in The Witcher 2 can be crafted. You can make traps, steel and silver swords, armor and even crafting components. When you have the appropriate Diagram, usually purchased from vendors, you need to go talk to crafter NPCs standing around in town. By interacting with them a crafting menu can be called up that displays all your Diagrams as well as whether or not you have the proper components. If you do, then after a simple button press the item is generated. There's no percentage chance to fail and there's no associated mini-game.The value and function of potions in The Witcher 2 differs from fantasy role-playing game standards. You can't consume health restoration potions mid-battle in this game. Instead, you need to drink them before a fight begins, which gives Geralt temporary boosts to things like damage and health regeneration. It's a great system because it means you can't run into a conflict without thinking. Making potions is similar to crafting gear. Vendors sell Formulas for potions, and by combining the appropriate plants special brews are created. The actual process of creation isn't handled by a vendor, but instead accessible through Geralt's mediation menu. Here you'll find listed all your Formulas for potions, bombs and oils. If the proper ingredients are in your inventory, the product can be outputted with a keystroke. Simple enough.  REPLAYABILITY  Of course, if you have dozens of times. The Witcher 2 has four different beginnings and 16 possible endings. Enjoy !   VERDICT  8.5/10

content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
Story:"The Witcher 2" was inspired by a polish book series  called "Wiedźmin". The game tells the story of Geralt of Rivia, a Witcher who is trying to recover his lost memories. Witchers are basically superhumans who can also cast spells and work as mercenaries, who can work as bodyguards, monster hunters, etc.In the beginning he is blamed for the murder of King Foltest (who he was working for at the moment) and went to jail. While there, he is given a chance prove his innocence and goes after the King Slayer while still trying to get his memories back.It's good story overall. I might not be the best but it's certainly good, especially due to the fact that your choices can completly change the Storyline and it has around 4 major endings.GameplayMany people keep complaining about the battle system, but I actually enjoyed it. However, it takes some time until you get used to it.Geralt has 2 different swords: one is made of steel and the other is made of silver. The steel sword it's used against enemies such humans and elves and the silver one it's used against monsters. He can perform a quick and a heavy attack.Geralt can cast 5 different spells, a.k.a. signs: -Aard: Knocks back the enemies, preventing them from blocking your next attacks. There's also a chance of stunning the enemies, which allows you to kill them with just one hit;Yrden: Creates a trap which stuns the enemies and prevent them from defending themselves;Ignis: Geralt casts a fire ball;Quen: Provides full damage protection for a short period of time against a few hits;Axii: Used to turn an enemy against their allies and to persuade NPCs during some dialoguesHis health regenerates very slowly even when you are not in combat, but he can speed it up through potions. However he only drink potions by meditating (which can't be done in combat) and he can't drink too many because they're also toxic.Visuals and SoundtrackThe game still looks pretty good, especially considering that it was released back in 2011. To make things even better the soundtrack was also very well produced. Combining both elements you can get easily immerse in this fantasy world.ConsNow it's time for the cons:-It's not an easy game, but that's not a problem by itself. The real problem are the difficulty spkies, which can be really frustating and some enemies that might seem cheap;-The lack of a fast travel mechanic or even a vehicle or an animal to walk around the map can be annoying at times. It might feel good to walk around exploring the world, but when you pass multiple times through the same area it can get a bit annoying;-The game doesn't explain certain parts such as mutagens and alchemy.Overall it's really solid title and I recommend it to every RPG fan.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
THE WITCHER 2: ASSASSINS OF KINGS ENHANCED EDITIONREVIEWThe Witcher 2, even before entering the main menu, shows us maybe the best CG intro ever in a video game. After the shocking ending of The Witcher leaving us with a cliffhanger, The Witcher 2 starts shortly after the predecessor. Geralt of Rivia, after saving King Foltest of Temeria, works for him now, as a personal bodyguard. Hunting traitors, Foltest sieges a castle and “invite” Geralt to help his army. Something shocking happens in the action-packed epic prologue, and now Geralt must prove he is saying the truth, and have his vengeance, seeking a mysterious man. The Witcher 2 storyline is more action-packed than the first one. It’s epic, it’s complex and have a lot of politics involved. Also, you have to make dramatic choices, that even before the half of the game, show a totally different perception of the entire story, making it almost two in one. (Beat the game two times for the full experience!) Personally, I prefer the first Witcher story, but the second one is really better in showing it’s themes and involves a lot of more things happening in the world, with decisions that matter even in The Witcher 3, drawing to one possible conclusion, showed in an epic CG. The ending does not disappoint and put another cliffhanger that serve as a promise for the epic The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt, the conclusion of the saga. Character development is very good and you will possible love two characters, Saskia and Ioverth. They’re amazing and shows a good background. But… it’s The Witcher! Everyone have their own personal story and unique quests, everything in the world have something behind it. The game’s campaign is shorter than the first one, because is kind of divided in two, but its more action packed like I also said and includes even more epic Boss Battles, that I bet will surprise you. Besides the campaign being smaller, the game itself is bigger, have more quests, bigger areas to explore and more content! The graphics are impressive, as still of today. The darker style of the game shows beautiful scenarios and regions, and well done animations, a problem from the first game. Alongside the epic soundtrack and sound effects, it all boils down to the amazing fantasy atmosphere the game shows you. The movimentation is more fluid than in the first game and you can even climb some obstacles. Combine this with combat that also shows an amazing innovation. Maybe the worst aspect of the first game, turned in one of the triumphs in The Witcher 2. The combat combines the Signs again, but now it’s not a totally combo-based like the first one and have a lot of movements and sounds like more a hack’n’slash game, with truly epic fight scenes with all kinds of monsters, that are now bigger in number than on the first game. Contracts are back as always and you have to clean monster nests and destroy them. As this is the enhanced edition, it features better graphics, bugs correction, and all of the released DLC, so you may find trolls in the game world with some interesting stories, and there is also the special Arena mode where you fight waves of enemies. Talking about the game itself again, there’s a lot of weapons again, and this time, a lot of armors, something I found lacking in the first. You can breed potions as always that help you in combat and sometimes is even necessary for quests. The world feels alive and you have a lot of romance options, but this time with no romance cards, but explicit scenes, even more than its successor, including specially one with Triss…There is also a crafting system for the armor and weapons which gives you the best ones in the game. Now you can meditate (to pass time and brew potions) anywhere if there’s no enemies, so it’s more practical than the predecessor. Dice poker is present: you can play a game with almost everyone and it's very fun and have quests related. The perk and level up system is cool and works well. The bad aspects for the game includes some bugs, random crashes that make you lose your progress and even lose your save in some cases (do a lot of them) and the lack of “RPG interactions”. The first one had a lot of food, drinks that you could eat and an animation was showed. This one does not feature all of that and no animations are present. Ok, that's a minor thing but...my opinion. Another thing is the game can be too punitive at the beggining, not stimulating someone into proceeding in. After you level up a bit it becomes fun, however. Mini games are present in boss battles. And they are annoying. The inventory menus are kind of chunky for me, also. +High Replayability+Choices and consequences+Epic story with political background+Epic and amazing soundtrack and sound effects+Big Immersion+Customization, lots of weapons, armors and skills+Top quality realtime weather and passage of time +Charismatic characters +Beautiful scenarios with large areas+A lot of sidequests and talk+Cool scenarios+Variety of monsters even a dragon!+Lots of content+Fun combat+Romance scenes+Epic CGI in the start and in the end of the game.+Level up system+Dice poker+Boss battles+Arena mode-Some bugs-Random crashes-Annoying boss battles mini-games-Lack of minor details-Over-punitive beggining-A bit chunky inventory menusVa fail, Gwynbleidd. The Witcher 2 takes everything the first did right. And do it better. To be continued.9,5/10

												Awesome game.   I initally had a hard time getting into it, as I found it was harder than most rpg's that I play ( I'm a big fan of Dark Souls and Demon's Souls, though the Witcher 2 difficulty is different from those kinds of games. )  I also found it akward to play with a keyboard, and once I switched to a controller, my gameplay satisfaction significantly increased.  Once I got through the first chapter, I hit my stride then and figured out how to be a more effective Witcher, and the initial learning curve was overcome.  Gameplay is good, coupled with really good fighting animations, proves for a satisfying experience. Graphics and audio are very well done; the game has a satisfying and fitting soundtrack.  The story is interesting, and I always felt compelled to find out what happens next.  However it does allude to the first game quite a bit, and while it does fill in some details for you, it may be better to play through the first  game, but in my opinion it is not absolutely necessary.  The game also features multiple meaningful choices and there are several endings to obtain, giving alot more playabilty. All in all I would highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												The Witcher 2 as a game is the meaning of the word progress. Everything from the graphics to the systems behind the game are an amazing feat, one you would expect from a big named developer backed up by a huge budget. The looks of the game are not only unparalleled due to its PC only nature, but also because it presents a world that feels hand crafted. The attention to detail borders on the extreme: the clothes, the houses and buildings, the faces of the characters their weapons and in general every corner, nook and cranny of the world has a distinctive touch. The scenery is simply breathtaking, and if you are like me you will want to make a screenshot out of every frame. It also shows that you don't need an overabundance of browns and blood reds in your palette to show a gritty dark fantasy world. This game shows its maturity not through a pretense of adult topics or over the top action animations, but through a careful use of its elements and by showing the player some respect: yes, you are an adult, and you can handle these topics, because indeed the Witcher's is a dark world filled with conspiracies, racism and characters in between every single shade of gray. It is a living, breathing, unforgiving world.The story is as complex as in the first game, filled with twists and choices that may change the fate of many, and forking paths that make a replay of the game not only encouraged, but required in order to see the extent to which they occur and diverge. Normal and hard difficulties are recommended and will test your skills if you don't face every battle with all seriousness, preparing beforehand by brewing and drinking potions and using all of your abilities during the fight, i.e. your swords your magic signs depending on what enemy you face and traps and bombs for your crowd control.The actual combat is in no way dumbed down. It will still punish you if you go unprepared and you can't mash your way out of battles. It is in much better shape than in the first game, and friendly to both the use of a gamepad or mouse and keyboard. The user interface is slick and great looking.The ending of the game comes abruptly, and you might feel that it doesn't solve every issue the game presents (the main storyline issues ARE solved, though). It is no excuse from what many will consider a downbeat ending, but in all honesty it doesn't detract a single beat from what this game does right, which is almost everything else. Even if you don't like the ending you will feel that the journey was worth it.In the end I feel like I'm required to praise this game so high despite its shortcomings not because it is a perfect game, but because it is an honest one. When more and more AAA releases are done with specific quarters or demographics numbers behind, or executives who never play games are calling the shots, The Witcher 2 really feels developed to please it audience, to show them they too are tired of these.There is a certain level of quality you expect from bigger developers which have more of a history and a name, because they deliver experiences that go way beyond what you might get from the indie guys. It is OK, they have the money and the numbers behind. This is a trend that has been changing in the last years and that no longer holds true in most cases though. In this case in particular neither of these apply. In my mind CDProject RED are already the big name, from whom I will expect unrelenting quality. Because after what they achieved they can't be considered the little guy any longer. With the Witcher 2 they delivered a game that is truly above and beyond any RPG from the last years, that feels like a product of love, careful planning and an overall shout to fans and the gaming community that says "we know what you want, and we can deliver. Where others have failed you we will prevail." And God if they don't.A serious contender for the best game of 2011, and frankly there is little in the horizon that looks like it might compete with it. Five years from now when other games made by bigger companies are all forgotten in the $5 bargain bins of the world, many will be reinstalling this game to reminisce and fondly say: "yes, I played a game was this good in 2011, and it was glorious."Congratulations CDProject RED, you just released your first masterpiece.

content:
Posted: January 1
 The story The witcher 2 continues the story from the last games ending, where an assassin attempted to murder the king of Temeria, king Foltest. The assassin was unsuccessful, Geralt murdered the assassin before he could kill Foltest. When Geralt unmasked the assassin he is revealed to be a witcher.There's alot of hatred towards nonhumas in the witcher universe. Many nonhumans flee to the forests to join the Scoia'tael, an army of nonhumans who fight for freedom. In the witcher 2 you will meet a commander of the Scoida'tael, Iorveth. Some time go by. An unkown assassin kills Demavend III, the ruler of Aedrin. Perhaps not the best ruler as he was known for being rather cruel, but also quite intelligent and knowledgeable about the tactics of war. More time go by, Foltest with his army and Geralt at his side, attacks La Valette castle. They are successful in taking over the castle. King Foltest reunites with his two children, Anais and Boussy locked up in a tower, with the help of Geralt. In the tower with Foltest's children is a blind monk. As Anais and Boussy leaves the room, the monk throws off his cape to Murder king Foltest. This time the assassination on Foltest was a success. The assassin is reavealed to be yet another witcher. He flees and jump out of the castle tower. Two soildiers enter the tower only to find Geralt with king Foltest's corpse lying on the ground, Geralt is framed for the murder of the king of Temeria. He is taken to the castle dungeons for interrogation, this is how he meets Vernon Roche, a commander of the Blue Stripes, a special force in the Temerian military. He trusts Geralt and thus he decides to help Geralt find the real murderer. Geralt is still trying to recover his memory which he lost in the beginning of the first game.The dialogue system is very good, the voice acting is superb. It doesn't feel like you're talking to a wall anymore. The graphics The graphics have certainly seen a big upgrade from the first witcher game, it actually looks quite amazing for the time it came out. Characters also look much more unique. They have also added more cutscenes and the animations look very good. The UI has also seen a big upgrade, The UI in the first game was a mess but it looks alot better in the witcher 2. Something i miss with the UI from the original witcher game, is the 3D witcher medallion in the corner, it looked very nice. In the second game it's just 2D medallion next to your health. The sound and music The sound quality is much better than it was in the first witcher game, and of course the music is still amazing, the soundtrack has become one of my favorite soundtracks of all time. The soundtrack is epic and it fits the theme of the game. The gameplay Perhaps one of the biggest changes to the witcher 2 is the new action combat system, the group fighting mode is gone now you can use either fast attacks or strong attacks in battle. They have added rolling and blocking to the combat, the combat is much more fast phased. I have to say i really like the new combat system, its not as frustrating as the first games combat. You still have your magical witcher signs, and this time you have every sign unlocked from the start of the game.There is also a brand new alchemy system, now you can only create and drink potions while meditating, and you can only have three potions active at a time. The potions also last very short, in the first game they lasted for several in-game hours, now they only last 10 minutes. A big problem with this is that potions and other buffs last over cutscenes which means that some potions wear off before a fight, and you can't drink a new one since you're in a fight and you can only drink potions while meditating. The character building is not as good in the witcher 2 as it was in the first witcher game in my opinion. You can however get some quite satisfying finishers. The alchemy tree is not very good, and thats due to the bad alchemy system, so if you're planning to play this game i wouldn't recommend to do an alchemy build as it might not work out so well.The game runs pretty good on my computer, but I have heard of people having optimization issues. I have however experienced a couple of hard crashes and freezes, which is pretty annoying if you haven't saved your game in a while, I learnt that the hard way. Cons and pros  Pros:  Great story, perhaps not as good as the first game but still an amazing story Amazing graphics that look ahead of its time Epic soundtrack that really fits the theme of the game Great sound quality, a big upgrade from the first game Great combat system UI looks way better than it did in the first game Fantastic experience Cons:  The game can be a buggy mess sometimes I experienced some hard crashes and freezes which slowed down the story and led to some frustration The combat can still be very frustrating poor alchemy system  The wicther 2 is shorter than the first witcher gameThe game has its flaws but it's still an amazing game. I'll give an 8/10 to the whole game as I didn't really like the alchemy system nor do I think that the story can match up with the witcher 1 story, but the combat is definitely a big upgrade to the games gameplay and a kick in the right directionThe witcher 2 - trailer

												Don't buy Witcher. Buy Witcher 2. Need explanation? Read on.OK, let's make something perfectly clear. I've spent at least 17 hours in Witcher and although I've recommended it in my Steam review, I don't think too fondly of that game. I've never got through it. Although the story is OK (but not great), I consider Witcher to be ''buy it on sale'' title. Game mechanics are so broken I've lost all of my will to play it. I just couldn't stand it.Although a friend of mine (Witcher fanatic and a gaming journalist), a guy that says Skyrim can suck his balls, recommended Witcher 2 to me on more than a few occasions and although he pointed out the game is different than the first one, somehow I've managed not to get it until this last summer sale. And I didn't buy it this summer, either - this friend bought it for me as an act of protest because I've neglected an awesome game.Did I say awesome? Yes, I DID. Witcher 2 is AWESOME. It goes straight into a Chamber of greatness which includes titles such as Doom II, Duke Nukem 3D, Quake II and Morrowind.Witcher 2 brings an awesome and oh-so-needed upgrade to every single system of Witcher universe. The story gets really suspenful and interesting now, so great it leaves the first one in the dust. It makes it funny. Combat? ♥♥♥♥ing finally. No more mini-games click-on-time attacking that made me so nervous. This is a proper sword-wielding and cast-spelling game. Fighting numerous opponents is a joy now. You can dash and stab almost in perfect harmony; fights in Witcher 2 are soul-soothing experiences. Quest finding and resolving is easier and more logical, menus are no longer a cluttered mess, girls are more naked and dwarves curse and drink like late GG Allin.Witcher 2 is a great, great game that shall be rewarded with a CLASSIC title as the time goes bye. Its living and breathing world will suck you in and you will choose a side. And you'll ENJOY IT.Once again, DO NOT SPEND YOUR MONEY AND TIME ON WITCHER. Get Witcher 2 and don't let the first game keep you away from this masterpiece.P.S. Dwarves. I love MOTHER♥♥♥♥ING DWARVES!!!***If you like this review, feel free to join me for some more recommendations at http://steamcommunity.com/groups/libereviews

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												TL;DR version: Despite a rocky start and painful setup (graphics), it won me over within no time. The story is amazing, voice acting is great, maybe not as polished as the Witcher 3, but still great. Playing through this will help understand a lot of things in TW3. Buy it, it's great value for money, especially considering there is a lof of replayability, given the 16 endings based on your choices, and different Acts 2/3.Detailed:Initially almost refunded it. The installation includes a scan for 'optimal' settings, which is completely broken. It was so unoptimised, the motion blur gave me motion sickness... 2-3 hours of my playtime went into that launcher toying with the settings until I got it right. Even though I cover it sufficiently, and should be able to play on max settings, I had to tone down a few things and disable all motion blurs. Boom, now it was playable.The Enhanced edition seems to have the Arena tutorial, which I only used to test my graphics setup to be honest. It's something you may like to skip, pretty awful. I actually used the Prologue as a tutorial, works fine.Combat is a bit clunky, not as polished as in TW3, but after getting used to it...makes sense. The Space key is your friend. The game is not as linear as the first game, but not open world like TW3. You still get plenty of areas to explore and side quests to do. I disliked the carry weight limit, but that can be fixed with mods. Some people dislike the lack of fast travel, I was okay with it. Apart from some mob farming for a certain armor in Act 1 that took forever and Geralt wore the shoes off his feet, there isn't too much tourism.The story is great. Your choices matter, and for some of them there are real repercussions, like SPOILER ALERT the fate of entire kingdoms! Yeah, plural. Intricate story-telling, not too pushy, keeps you interested, although can be confusing at times for people new to the Witcher world. It actually made me buy the books to learn some of the references, so there you go.There are indeed ♥♥♥♥♥houses. I must have paid 2,000+ orens for such services just for the fun of it. Great stuff. There are also other options, ahem, but you'll find that on your own.All in all, it's a great game, if unoptimised for a lot of devices. The story wins you over and it's definitely worth the money. Even better if you buy the game during a sales period, like I did. Will definitely make the TW3 more enjoyable and enhance the experience there. Also ♥♥♥♥♥houses.Buy it.

												Witcher 2 improves over the original in almost every way. The combat is the biggest change it’s much better overall.  Just like the first game the story is one of the best stories I have played in a video game, I feel so involved in everything that is happening. The amount of detail in the lore just makes the whole experience very rich. Amazing writing, character depth and voice acting sell these characters as real people. Every character is fascinating and you want to learn more about them and in doing so you become more connected to them. The way the story changes by the choices you make has never been so expansive as it was in this game. One choice in particular about a third into the game changes the outcome in the story completely and it almost becomes two games in one because the outcome is so different between each other they end up being completely different experiences. The only thing that keeps this game from being a 10 is the linearity, it is a very linear experience overall, there isn’t much free roaming you can do it’s only strict linear paths. This is something I know the witcher 3 addresses which I am looking forward to.9/10 (Amazing)

												I wanted to like this game, It appeared to be right up my alley and It has everything I love in an rpg but I just couldnt get into it. 												Right then... I absolutely adore the first Witcher game. It introduced me to the world, lore and books. I expected more awesomeness from the second entry in series. Well, to be honest with you, i am a bit mixed on it. I love the story, the characters, the voice-acting, world, graphics, every little sound, but i can't say the same about combat system. Yes, i have problem with one of the most important part of videogames. Gameplay itself. I feel like i'm just going around this beatiful world on rails, spamming the "X" button, occasionally mixing it with "A" button to roll away from attacks.I really don't know how to feel about The Witcher 2. I love it, but at the same time, it feels often like a chore to play. Let's just say, don't buy it for gameplay. Buy it for pretty much everything else. If you are a fan of the books or Witcher franchise as a whole... Well, then you have already played this, haven't you... I can't say i don't recommend it, because i love it. But i hate it when it comes to combat. I'm sorry, just buy it for yourself and try it on your own. It's really cheap most of the time.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												*might contain minor spoilers*Almost 5 years after the release, I finally played Witcher 2. You play as an imprisoned witcher, Geralt of Rivia, who is accused of murdering a king. The game begins with compelling flashbacks in which you storm a castle, and it shows how the murder happened. Through the game, you are chasing the real killer as well as try to recover your memories about the Wild Hunt and Yennifer. You meet interesting characters (some from the 1st Witcher game), and in one point have to choose who will you follow. This changes the story quite a bit (mainly different location in chapter 2), so the game can be enjoyed in the 2nd replay. The game has prologue, 3 chapters and an epilogue, with different maps you cannot return to when you finish the chapter. I don't think you must play Witcher 1 to enjoy it (I didn't finish it for instance). Pros and cons:+ The game still looks very pretty.+ Good voice acting and quality mature dialog (even non clickable npcs ramble when you run by).+ Intriguing main story, the world is rich (although you might get lost with all the different names).+ You can 'steal' anything and nobody will attack you.+ You can sleep with a number of women (there's a cut scene with boobies and booties).+ Sweet soundtrack that fits nicely.+ Not black and white: monsters aren't necessarily bad. You also have a choice to kill or spare     some people which effects the political map of the world.+ You can skip dialogue and cut scenes.+ Some of the quests are very interesting...- ...but some are classic monster slaying type. Either eradicate xxx or you fight through monsters to get to the place, find item etc.- Walking back and forth can be a chore sometimes.- You must meditate to drink potions.- If you are trying to collect materials for crafting weapon/armor, the local shop will have good alternative relatively cheap, which makes crafting undervalued.I cannot really comment about fighting difficulty as I played on easy (focused on the story), but for me, the fighting mechanics were better than in Witcher 1.The game has a few puzzles, but I also cannot comment on difficulty as I was mostly too lazy and just googled correct sequences.All in all, it is a great game which can be bought really cheap on sales. If you haven't played Wild Hunt yet, I think these ~40 hours into Witcher world can be well spent before throwing yourself in the latest installment of the Witcher saga.

content:
Posted: April 19
												Rating: 8/10Overview: Third Person RPGThe Good:+ Making difficult choices is at the heart of the Witcher series, early in the game you must make a choice that completely alters the story and quests providing a very good incentive for a replay. These choices are not black and white, good or evil but often fall in the moral grey area forcing you to really think about your actions. Every choice has good and bad points and often carries consequences with it.  + Well written side-quest that offer multiple ways of completing them. Some side quests span the entirety of the game depending on your choices. + The story is very deep and complex and can be overwhelming given the number of people and locations involved. The story deals heavily in politics and power and those that really immerse themselves in the lore will truly appreciated everything the designers and writers have made.  + 3 skill trees; magic, swordsman and alchemy, each one provides a different way of engaging enemies in battle. + Find items, plants allowing you to craft potions and equipment+ Lots of mods The Average:+/- Combat is much improved over the first game but still feels a bit lackluster compared to other games. You must invest in certain skills for combat to become more flexible.  It isn’t until halfway through the game when you have enough experience points for combat to feel a bit more engaging. You can’t move and block at the same time making it almost pointless to block.   The Bad:- The game does not overwrite any saves, doesn’t matter if its an autosave, manual save or quicksave, it makes a new file for each one. After a few hours of playtime you could have a lot of saves that could cause problems. - This game has a nasty cloud save bug where it no longer works properly causing you to lose many hours of game time. Disabling steam cloud doesn’t seem work and the ‘solution’ to fix this doesn’t always work.  Deleting and reinstalling also didn’t work. Conclusion:A brilliant RPG that isn’t afraid to deal with serious, mature subject matter. Your choices carry a lot of weight making the story feel more impactful. A combat system that takes a while to really feel good and a nasty technical bug holds it back.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
												The Witcher 2 has well made story and smooth feel to the combat.-There is a lot of lore etc. behind this game and I do expect the story behind this was good, but I personally never played the first Witcher game, and didn't feel the need to. You decide whenever or not you want to know more about the backstory and such or if you want to just jump straight in.Review:All the rolling, swings and magic usage feel incredibly fitting at almost all times which is very rare in a game with swords as well as magic. Sure the enemy lock on system is bad, but otherwise there is little to no complaints to be made. Just remember that you have all the bottles and magic  for a good reason and you will need to use them a lot.Each enemy has their weakness and the combat is extremely hard. (If you are new to gaming, you might want to play on a lower difficulty setting than normal) I am still amazed by the people who beat this game without grinding for money to get better gear at the insane difficulty, just shows how much skill you can gain at this game as I can barely survive the very first moments at the hardest difficulty setting.The world you explore feels very open even though it is as a matter of fact very linear and restricts you to a few chosen paths. It's very fun to explore the maps for items, which are gained trough killing enemies and completing tasks which people give you.They also have this alchemy system in which you craft these potions which give you buffs to help you find items in the environment as well as to help you effectively deal with your enemies.You also have a vast amount of armor, swords and recipes for potions, which some of appear to be behind the wall of rng. While yes it is quite a shame that some equipment may be inaccessable for you, but on the positive side you do get more things if you happen to feel like playing trough the game again.There are also some moments in which you see nudity at, or some small scenes in which you can optionally have sex with other women, just as a small disclaimer in case you did not know this already.Hmm, so the characters do seem to each have a personality which you can really get attached to and you can as a matter of fact interact with a lot with these people besides the NPC's which some of you can interact a little with. But I personally did not like the talking scenes that much at all. Otherwise this game has been a blast to play.Highly recommend it to every person.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												Much like its predecessor, The Witcher 2's greatest strengths lie in its storytelling. The characters are deep and flawed and you feel for both the heroes and the villains, the dialogue is at times witty, at times profound, and the twisting, turning intrigue of nefarious plotting, civil war, and the corrupting influence of power is always engaging and motivating. On top of that, TW2 is a vast improvement in terms of visuals, and I dare say it remains one of the best looking games ever made.  But again, like TW1, it's flaws lie in the games technical aspects. The combat system is the most frequent target for criticism, and I must admit, when I first played the game before the balancing was patched it was the single most frustrating experience of my life. Perhaps it was the benefit of hindsight that assisted me, but my second playthrough was a breeze by comparison. In saying that, the combat remains difficult to learn and beginners are unfortunately punished for lacking the clairvoyance to know when one must save before a big battle. Generally speaking, the autosave points are placed a little more kindly than in TW1 and restarts will often only send you back to the start of a fight, but when they don't it can be an annoying experience. There's also a single poorly implimented stealth section towards the start, which again tests the commitment of newcomers. But once you understand that you can dodge-roll infinitely and you put a few points into your skills you'll find that, while not the most elegant system, it's far more interactive than that of TW1 and allows the player to become quite powerful when they get the hang of it. Criticism aside though, I'd say that this is a must-play RPG for any fan of the genre. It streamlines a lot (if not all) of the inconvenient gameplay quirks of the first game, and continues to build on Geralt's epic story in a beautiful and detailed world. I played through both games in preparation for TW3 (come on Steam, discount the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥!) and while I felt every one of my 33 hours in TW1, this game never felt like it overstayed its welcome. Ultimately I was sad to see it finish, especially as the last moment of gameplay is a wonderfully powerful emotional climax. I recommend this game at whatever price it's sold for.

INTERESTINGLY-Witcher is about spell casting, dragon slaying, medieval ages.-My love for Witcher starts with (gasp) Witcher 1, and remains LOVE rooted from there, with only a technical appreciation for WITCHER 2, and (wow the graphics) WITCHER 3. The creator of The Witcher is still with us today and though NOT without merit (he has received recognition for promoting Polish culture).GAMEPLAY-The format is much like any Assassin's Creed game, 3rd person and open world. If that's your thing, this is going to be enjoyed by you.-The world is the same as in Witcher 1; the people, the culture, "the orens" :-) -I was SO excited learning of the possibility to transfer saves from game to game in the genre (by the time I learned of this Mass Effect was doing so too, :-) I just loved anything to do with Witcher).CRITICISM -If you think I just won't stop praising this game, apart from an obvious comparison with Lord of the Rings, THIS GAME and all Witcher games CONTAIN GRAPHIC CONTENT, unlike and to the credit of LOTR, I would appreciate if there was a setting in our OPTIONS menu we could input that may limit the level of this CONTENT we are looking at without affecting gameplay, HEY, there are some young children looking at  cartoon images here of WHAT, then there's unbridled SWEARING that they are exposed to??!!. I would agree with stricter measures for censorship of the sale of these games to certain age-groups otherwise.  ; in conclusion,I recommend Witcher 2.GAME ON

content:
Posted: March 5
												The Witcher 2 by CD Projeckt Red review.I will start off by saying that I was late to the Witcher series. (Still haven't played Wild Hunt) With that being said, they are games that should not be overlooked by RPG fans, even though the first 2 are 5+ years old. I played The Witcher about 3 years ago and I wish I would of played it alot closer to my Witcher 2 playthrough because I had forgotten details about some of the previous characters and locations. A quick trip to google cleared up all my confusion and my gameplay experience was great.Story -> 9/10I was fully immersed in the story once I cleared up a few things I had forgotten from the first one. It moves along a steady pace and ramps up to a good finale by Act III. I imported my character from the original which added a few weapons and armour (as far as I could tell) as well as a few references and minor story alterations. There are some very tough decisions to make which can alter the course of the game. The voice acting (English) was a little wooden from some of the characters (Dandelion, Triss and to some extent, Geralt himself) but it didn't diminish my experience any. The dwarves in particuliar were great as they are vulagar as f*** and are always good for a laugh. I am also happy to report not a single character took an arrow to the knee.Sound -> 8/10 [Creative SB X-FI Platinum]The sound effects were very well done, especially in combat. Ambience while walking around really pulls you in. From the idle chatter in towns to the various sounds while out for a stroll in the wild. I found the music score to be great but there was not as many tracks and got a bit repetitive. The music in the taverns is burned into my memory probably forever now.Graphics/Performance -> 9/10 [Asus Maximus VII - 4790K - 16GB 1600MHZ - R9290X Crossfire - Freesync]From a 2011 point of view, the graphics are amazing, from a 2017 point of view.....I still thought the graphics looked great.(Looked better and ran better than Skyrim all modded up) The enviroments were extremely detailed, in particular the forest in Act I. Textures were fairly hi-res and the lighting was very nice. Character models look good and the clothes/armour all looked great. Some minor clipping and characters teleporting around abit but nothing major.From a performance standpoint everything was top notch. The game scaled amazing with multi-gpu, I had no problem maintaining 144 fps. (Dips down to 115-120fps in some places) With that being said I played alot of the game with a single gpu with the framerate locked to 90 fps because my monitor only can run Freesync up to 90hz. If I ran Freesync on with multi-gpu, the framerate would just rocket out of control (sometimes to 200fps) turning my room into a sauna. I ran all settings on max except the Uber setting, which just tanked performance, at 2560x1440 resolution. I experienced about 5 crashes in 45 hours of gameplay which is exponentially lower than the Bethesda games I've played on the same system.Gameplay -> 7/10 [Normal Difficulty]The Good: The overall feel of the game was generally good. I was able to map the keys in a way that I was not fumbling around like some games. The combat was improved from the first one. It feels rewarding as you start to accumulate better talents and equipment. By the end cutting down 6+ enemies at once was easy using a combination of weapons and signs. I didn't use alchemy much as I couldn't be bothered to meditate everytime I wanted to drink a potion. Also it is nice you don't need to be near a fire to meditate anymore.The Bad: The quicktime events are horrible and whoever puts these in the game and continues to use them to this day should be shot. I was kind of let down by some of the mini games, especially the dice, you can't win!!! The economy is sort of crappy. I found a rare elven sword and I went to sell it and I was given enough money to buy 5 apples from another vendor. WTF? If you are a completionist and need every book and every crafting diagram (which I will do on another playthrough) you better enjoy killing harpies for hours on end. Money is scarce. I believe there is a mod for it which I may use on my second playthrough.Conclusion -> 8.5/10I would recommend this game to anyone that even had their eye on it in the slightest. You can always pick it up for cheap. Halfway through the first act I realized I should had the difficulty alot higher since normal was a leisurely stroll. I put 45 hours in one playthrough and like I said I never went through it with a fine toothed comb. I see myself putting one maybe two more playthroughs so I could easily have over 100hours in it before I never look at it again. I recommend play the first Witcher prior to playing this one because it sets up the world and events happening. I felt that this game felt smaller in scale compared to the first Witcher. I felt that way about Mass Effect 2 & 3 as well. But still, 45 hours for a game I probably paid 5 bucks for on a Steam sale is great value. Now on to The Wild Hunt!!!

content:
Posted: November 19, 2013
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below) Game Name: The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition Original Release: 2011 Genre Tags: RPG; Mature; Adventure; Fantasy; Choices Matter  My Overall Grade: A+ Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 30-70 hours Multiplayer Aspect: None Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Aesthetes; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseurs REVIEWThe Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition provides a great experience, and tells a captivating tale... although it has a somewhat bland and frustrating combat system.  The game boasts a myriad of mature themes and storylines, and it is very enjoyable for those who appreciate impactful decision-making in their games.  However, the sheer magnitude of the game may cause it to drag a bit for completionists.This game is absolutely beautiful.  The story is deep, rich, complex and mature.  The world feels immersive and lived in.  There are sufficient RPG elements (crafting, items, leveling, spells) to appease any fan. In order to experience everything in the branching storyline, you will need to play through it a few times… or at least play through sections of the game a few times to see the results of different decisions.  The combat is probably the weak point of the game, as it is pretty bland and on higher difficulties can be frustrating.  You may want to consider playing on a low difficulty to just enjoy the story and avoid frustration.  If you can afford both the time and the money, I suggest you play the first one through at least once before playing this.  Or at the very least read a synopsis of the plot of the first game.There are dozens of aspects I could go into detail describing when it comes to The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition, but it doesn’t seem necessary.  If you are a fan of epic RPGs with dark, immersive stories and captivating atmospheres then you will most likely enjoy this.  If you are someone who has trouble getting invested in story-driven, slow-paced experiences, then you may want to look elsewhere for your next game.Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!
