content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
												The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings is a decision-driven fantasy RPG released by CD Projekt RED in 2011.  Like all The Witcher games, The Witcher 2 is based on The Witcher series of novels by Andrzej Sapkowski.Story (mild spoilers):The Witcher 2 (W2) takes places in a fantasy world heavy inspired by Slavic mythology and Polish history.  The universe of The Witcher games is steeped in political intrigue and features strange monsters and magical forces that influence people's lives for the better or worse.  In this world, a sect of mutant warriors called "witchers" (or hexers) serve as itinerant monster slayers for hire.  One of these witchers is the famed Geralt of Rivia, also known as the White Wolf.The game picks up shortly after the ending of The Witcher (W1), which showed Geralt of Rivia defending King Foltest of Temeria from a mysterious assassin.  In the aftermath, King Foltest "orders" Geralt of Rivia to serve as a glorified bodyguard.  However, a sinister plot by a mysterious faction compels Geralt to search for answers, reacquainting him with certain figures from his past.  Still suffering from amnesia prior to the events of W1, Geralt must regain his memories and find out who is killing the Northern Kingdoms' monarchs.W2 feels fairly shorter in story length than W1.  Nonetheless, the decision-driven storytelling of W2 remains strong, and I found the supporting cast highly memorable.  The game presents almost entirely different story paths which start near the end of Chapter 1 and dramatically change your character's quests and location for the majority of Chapter 2.  The grey morality surrounding monster slaying, philosophical issues, and political matters remains a key aspect of the decision-driven narrative.  The game ends on a bit of a cliffhanger and some plot lines seem unresolved...at least until The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt.  Nonetheless, the narrative remains fairly compelling.Finally, the import system is not as comprehensive as in games like Mass Effect 1-3, but some decisions (e.g. decisions on Princess Adda, Siegfried [Order] or Yaevinn [Scoi'atel], and a couple other characters) add/change dialogue options and alter certain NPC interactions.Rating: goodGameplay:The timed attack clicks of W1 have been replaced with a more "Dark Souls"-esque combat gameplay style (if you want to use that analogy).  Geralt has a basic skill tree alongside three other skill trees for alchemy, swordsmanship, and magic.  I favored a build centered around swordsmanship with some perks in magic, but found most of the alchemy tree useless for this build.  Like in the first game, your character uses two swords: steel for humans, silver for monsters.Enemies can feel RELENTLESS early on.  You may find yourself underleveled at first, but can become a powerhouse of destruction near the end.  This unbalanced difficulty, however, may deter many players.The alchemy system of W2 does away with alcohol bases for potions in W1.  Instead, you simply combine ingredients and voila: a masterpiece.  You must have the necessary ingredients and recipes beforehand from looting and finding merchants.  Meditation is now required to consume potions, but is offset by being able to meditate almost anywhere outside of combat.  In addition, you can utilize bombs, specific sword oils, throwing knives, and traps against your aggressors.As this is a decision-driven story game, dialogue remains key to discovering info and shaping the outcome of the narrative.  You can utilize persuasion/intimidate/axii abilities to steer a conversation to your benefit provided you have the required level for each.  Be mindful that your decisions can have drastic story consequences.  This game does not hold your hand.  You are free to choose the path you believe is right.The game offers several side quests, from contracts to arm wrestling, brawling, and dice poker.  There is no fast travel, so you'll be backtracking a lot to complete these.Rating: goodAudio:I played the game in English since that's my primary language.  W2's voiceacting has certainly improved since the last game and features quality vocal talent for many NPCs.The music is AMAZING.  It is highly atmospheric and more than captures the mood and identity of each area you're in.  Some of the combat music may really get your blood flowing during fights.Rating: excellentGraphics:The game looks gorgeous, especially if you have the hardware to enjoy the lighting FX.  On high graphics settings, the environments and character models are bristling with detail.Rating: excellentOverall: I loved this game, and it certainly improves over some of The Witcher's shortcomings.  My biggest concern was the story, which felt like it was on a slightly smaller scale that that of The Witcher to me.  The cliffhanger ending is an obvious setup for The Witcher 3, but I still felt right at home playing this game.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
Review - The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition"A marvelous adventure RPG that makes you really think of what decision you should make."The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition is an Adventure/Action RPG that welcomes the player once again to the world of the witcher, Geralt of Rivia. The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition starts off with Geralt being detained in dungeon as he was accused for murder of the Temerian King Foltest. He is then interrogated by Vernon Roche, the leader of the Blue Stripes, to tell his part of the story. After persuading Roche, your adventure then begins.The game has very much improved in terms of graphics and gameplay. The game's environment and atmospehere is so detailed and very engrossing that just removing the minimap can really get you lost (well, unless you have memorized the area). The soundtracks and voice actings are great. Even if you're just performing sidequests, you'll actually feel that those tasks really matter as if it's as important as the main plot of the game.One thing that sets The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings apart from other RPG games is its combat system. Geralt's swordplay is very different and unique. There will be times that hack n' slashing enemies head on could lead to your own demise.As you explore the game's world, you'll eventually come into crossroads of decisions and this is The Witcher series strong-point. Just like in the first game, your decisions really matter and affects the flow of the story, the actual ending of the quest and it even affects how the NPCs react to you. Siding with the humans can lead to elf merchants ignoring you and not giving you the service they provide. The decisions you take can either lead to death, a scar on a relationship, a new item, a battle or even a romance scene with one of the girls, etc. The player's decisions shape what kind of personality you want Geralt to portray whether you want him to be a merciful hero, a seeker of justice or just a plain old witcher doing his job.The game is quite short with having only 3 chapters (4 in all if you include the prologue) but its immense design on each quest makes the game very long. After your first playthrough, it'll make you want to start all over again as you'll wonder what would have happened if I made this decision instead of the other.The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition is a totally great game that once you finish it, you'll end up looking for more of it. I highly recommend this game to big fans of the Witcher series and to those who really love Action/Adventure RPG games with great story content.Personal Rating:Story/Plot: 9/10Gameplay: 8/10Music: 9/10Grapchics: 8/10Overall: 8.5/10

												The Witcher series is an odd one for me. I enjoy the atmosphere, the art, the story telling, the boobs, but I outright hate the combat.  I've tried several times to sit down and go through this game but the clunky combat keeps me from really diving into it. Not this time, though, NOT THIS TIME. I've put my big boy pants on and I'm finally ready to enjoy this Action RPG masterpiece of Gaming known as The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings. WIth my hatred for the combat I still have to give this game a two big thumbs up. I see it's often on sale for next to nothing. Go for it. Also, easily still one of the best looking games out there. There seems to be a fair amount of mods for it as well. I came across one that addresses the combat with numerous fixes. So pull your pants down, mod it up and enjoy yourself with some epic Fantasy.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												The Witcher 2 is a game with memorable characters, beautiful towns and landscapes, and a story filled with political intrigue. It's rare to come across a game with choices which feel impactful while avoiding typical 'black and white' or 'good and evil' situations. What lacks in gameplay is made up through the narrative.The gameplay is sub-par. Geralt of Rivia is equipped with two swords: one for human-slaying and one for monster-slaying. With magic-like abilities called signs to go along with his swordplay, Geralt is a force to be reckoned with. Dodging and parrying are two important aspects of the combat system. Geralt can die in a moment's notice if the player isn't careful, so it's vital to know when to be aggressive or defensive. However, The combat feels sluggish. The tab-targeting feels unresponsive at times, dodging does not always go the way the players want it to, and contact with enemy units does not feel responsive. A huge plus though is the way a player has to prepare for each encounter. Geralt cannot use potions during combat, only when he is meditating, which a player can do at anytime outside of combat. Potions range from boosting his recovery rates to increasing his attributes and resistances. It's a fairly comprehensive system and adds a layer often missing from other games.To level up, the player is given a 'skill tree' to add attribute points to four different categories, each composing of their own active and passive skills: Training, Alchemy, Signs, and Swordsmanship. The leveling up system is not complicated, but the choices you make are important. Geralt can level up to 35, which for example can fill up  the Training Tree and one other. So the player is given the choice of specializing in a certain tree, or become a jack-of-all-trades, balancing their skills points across all areas. It's a simple system which relies on player choice as a main driving force.The story is interesting enough to continue unraveling its many mysteries. Geralt meets friends, foes, and backstabbers along the way. What's great is that each character has a sensible motive to their actions. Voice-acting is great and the writing is well-done. The cutscenes do not offer much in terms of action, but the dialogue options and the strive to know more about the characters is enough to justify the more static encounters. Visually the game is absolutely beautiful. The lighting was and still is the best in the gaming industry. It benefits to take a second and marvel at the scenery surrounding Geralt. The forest around Flotsam, the first town Geralt encounters, is stunning. It helps make the world come alive, and like Mass Effect, creates a very convincing world, as if there's a lot more going on than what Geralt sees in his eyes. The character models, although great, could use some variety. It was common to come across the same character models across various parts of the game.If you are a fan of mature-themed RPG adventure, this game ranks among the best of them. It comes highly recommended.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												The Witcher 2 improves upon the first game in terms of combat, graphics and scale, however the game world is more linear in design and the story is debatably not as compelling as the Witcher 1. The choice and consequence system is brought to a new level here, with one decision changing half of the game entirely. The game has a somewhat darker atmosphere than the first and the soundtrack isn't as memorable. The combat is greatly improved with more options and tactics thanks to the extensive skill tree. Overall, this is a great game and a worthy successor to the first.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2016
												A good game, but not a perfect game. The atmosphere, the graphics, the idea behind the game are wonderful.  As are many of the characters, even the character you play is quite amazing himself. It's an immerssive game that captures the player and throws lots of enemies at you and lots of very neat little details. This game, based on the books definately does feel like an RPG. The gameplay is relatively satisfying, with visuals probably outdoing the gameplay itself but they create a very uniqe atmosphere which I prefer to other RPGs.In this game the choices actually do matter, there's quite a few and it's not just black or white (morally speaking). What is also unbelivably suprising about TW2 is that, despite the game coming out in 2011. This game on Ultra looks still up to date as ever, it looks astonishing truely.While this game succeeds in delivering a good RPG experience, there are some issues which don't make it a 10.. - The saving game system is far from perfect, not allowing you to save over games or choose the name of your saves instead every time you save it creates a new save. Doing this can make a huge cluster of saves which freeze your game every time you click load. So you must periodically clean old saves.- 3 big skill trees to pick from but very few skill points make it quite difficult to build the ultimate Witcher. - The game is actually quite short, especially if you don't do the side quests. Of course, after this there is the Witcher 3 which only continues the best kind of fun. The amount of hours I have are not correct, as I tried to play this game before but never completed it so it's more hours than needs be. - The facial animations are subpar, not really great at showing off emotions of the characters.- The combat is unforgiving at the begining, defiantely needs getting used to and remember Space is your friend.

												First off, I'd just like to say that I have never played the first game, and I have never read the books that create the basis for this game. If you are looking into buying this game, go onto t"The Witcher" youtube channel and watch the small little overview they offer about the first game. Onto the actual review, this is easily one of the best RPGs out there on the market at this time. The graphics are absolutely stunning and run quite smoothly, the artwork and textures are brilliant and vibrant, yet bleak enough to preserve the game's "feel". Speaking of feel, this game has a dark, mature attitude full of corruption and disgust. The moral choices in the game require Geralt to make morally ambigious decisions. There are no rights or wrongs, only decisions based on the scenarios. Combat can be best described as playing Dark Souls with a character who doesn't weigh 450 pounds, fun, but challenging as well. The plot has enough turns to keep things flowing, but it's not ridiculous. Plenty of sexual encounters. To conclude, I rate the game as a strong 9/10, and highly recommend it to anyone who is looking for a good game. I got 60 hours out of it and bought it for 2.50.

												The Witcher 2: Assassin's of Kings is not only one of the finest RPGs but also one of the best games ever made. It boasts an insanely amazing intellectual mature non-linear driven story made by your own choices, and it lives up to it's word. Very well written, memorable characters, some dam amazing dialogue and very well structured. One has to play this at least twice to realize/understand the entire game as every playthrough will have something different to offer. number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												I really enjoy games that walk me through an interesting story and dump me in a fully fledged world. The story has heritage in Polish culture and is based on The Witcher books by Andrzej Sapkowski. Fantasy worlds are fascinating but are sometimes difficult to be drawn in to. With the Witcher I did not find that to be the case.The gameplay is quite linear in some senses where there are three main chapters plus a prologue and epilogue which significantly move on the story and change the environment. However, when playing within a chapter you are given time to explore the beautiful environment and complete the quests around you. It is not necessary to play the first witcher before playing this but inevitable there are quotes which relate directly to the first game.The combat swordplay feels a little clunky and some small amount of time should be spent on the wiki to understand signs and so on (Aard is your friend). All in all, before this gets too long - definitely worth a pick up.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Drawing from it's rich source material the Witcher 2, continues the tale of Geralt of Rivia as he seeks to uncover the truth behind a mysterious group of assassins who are after royal blood. Building on the amazing story which started with the first Witcher game, considered a classic by many, Witcher 2 also improves the experience of being a professional monster-slayer. The combat is challenging and realistic ( no chugging fifty potions in the middle of a fight :P ) and the visuals and voice acting are excellent, and the story as aforementioned is gripping filled with impactful choices, characters that you will grow to love and others whom you'll want to introduce to a witcher's blade.  For those who have played the Witcher 3 Wild Hunt and want to immerse yourself more in the witcher world but find the first witcher to have not aged particularly well Witcher 2 Assassins of KIngs is an excellent game detailing Geralt's adventures leading upto the events of Wild Hunt. Overall an amazing RPG and good entry point for those who have never played a Witcher game as well as returning monster-slayers.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												The Witcher 2 EE is like your neighborhood cougar. A fine woman who's grown wise through her experiences. Seductive in her gaze, can treat you to a good time then read you a bedtime story. (Compares a computer game to an attractive woman.... descending ever deeper and deeper, are we?)Right, Right...... The Witcher 2.An essential chapter in The Witcher video game trilogy. Unlike the original game from 2007, The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings is an absolute must for those interested in playing it's sequel, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt. The state of the Northern Realms in the third game is a direct outcome of major events that transpired over the course of Assassins of Kings. The Witcher 2 continues the tale of an amnesia-struck Geralt of Rivia. After foiling an assassination attempt on King Foltest's life, the legendary monster slayer turned royal bodyguard must accompany Temeria's king into battle against traitors of the realm. As stated, a player need not play the original for an enjoyable experience, but for those who prefer complete participation, emotional investment, and absolute understanding of its references and characters, it is advised. Positives:  - Stellar choice-driven narrative. - Immersive gameplay mechanics. - Soundtrack is brilliantly enveloped around a player's every action; electrifying during combat yet sentimental when required. - Believable fictional world brimming with interesting interactable characters. - Stunning visuals. (Dem textures doe!!!!) - Punishing difficulty that forces players to use all the tools at their disposal. - Pixilated tittays! ...in your face literally a few minutes after you start the game.Negatives (More like knit-picks):  - Conversation persists even when paused by the player. - Geralt's Grayish silver hair rather than the lore-appropriate milky white. (Easily corrected with a mod) - Glitch where unlooted items from fallen enemies disappear after reloading a save.  - Geralt's movement constantly interrupted by invisible surfaces belonging to furniture and vegetation. So F*ckn good, y'all don't even know.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2015
												I bought this game years ago... when I played it the first time I didn't like it tried another five times still no dice. Now I'm here don't know what changed maybe I just didn't understand it but I'm glad I gave it a shot, better later than never right?So let's get all the good stuff out of the way first, the biggest and greatest change has to be the combat it's fast paced full of action and well it just feels great. The game looks good and has aged well, has a tonne of options to mess with too always a plus. The keyboard and mouse work great but default key binds feel odd and a controller works perfectly. The audio is amazing from the voice acting to the sound effects all the way up to the soundtrack. I would say the game length is good took me roughly about 30-35 hours to complete, there's also a tonne of side quests to do and of course heaps of main quests. The user interface is great with a mouse and keyboard but a bit weird with a controller still works fine though. There's some great game changing choices to be made and that's to be expected from a heavily story driven game. It also comes with a arena mode it's as fun as you'd expect from a survival based mode but it's still a great pass time.Now the bad... first thing I want to get of my chest is the navigation I don't think I have ever played a game with such a detailed but useless map and mini map, I found myself getting lost often because of it. There is no sprinting and at first it's fine but later you'll find yourself pulling out a sword just to dodge everywhere. A downside to the new combat is once you corner a single enemy excluding main bosses they get stuck and can't fight back, small gripe which made it feel cheap. The games pacing feels off most of the time, sometimes it's quick sometimes it's slow other times it's super quick etc it never seemed subtle. There doesn't seem to be enough different armor and weapons to go collect and spend time on, which is fine I suppose but I excepted more. A minor bug I found on dual screens was an invisible second mouse pointer would appear on the second screen hovering over things, not a big deal but annoying.I honestly think the game is great if you are craving a story driven game, it might not appeal to some but it's definitely up there with the Mass Effect series.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21
												Although 'The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings' happens to be my least favourite game in the trilogy, I still found it very enjoyable. It begins with a very exciting introduction, and the new combat system is well-explained in the opening quests. Also rather early in the game we meet the antagonist of 'Assassins of Kings'.My favourite of all the 'Witcher' villains is from this second instalment: Letho of Gulet. Letho is a man of colossal proportions, and matches his incredible power with a sharp, cunning mind. Some of the other characters introduced in this game are also rather memorable, but none so much as Letho. The perfectly written villain is just one element of a very good story.These days, we're all familiar with RPGs offering players a choice. We were also very familiar with this feature five years ago when this game released. Still, none of the games I've played have offered a choice quite as significant as one of the ones presented in this game, in which your selection will change at least 6-8 hours of gameplay.I wish this game had been as open to explore as the other 'Witcher' games, and I think more investment in side quests could have been made. Still, play 'Assassins of Kings' and you'll be signing up for a first-rate fantasy adventure, full of highly entertaining battles and well-written, well-acted characters.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												It's a great game.  As in Witcher 1, your choices matter.  When it was released the graphics were next-gen, but it was nearly unplayable on my system due to bugs.  Here we are years later with the Enhanced edition for which I am playing it through a second time, and there are still bugs.  Nothing game breaking, but highly annoying nonetheless.It's still a great RPG with an intriguing story, though I am betting you'd appreciate it more by reading the books, which I have not read.  Gameplay wise, it can sometimes be a little hack and slashy, but on the higher difficulties you're forced to use a bit of strategy; it differs a good bit from Witcher 1 and takes a little getting used to.  If you're an RPG fan it's not one to miss, but you really should play the games in order to know what's going on (I actually like the 1st more than the 2nd in a few ways).

												Truth be told, I am very new to this type of game. Especially the RPG element as I spent most of my time playing FPS. So one day, i saw that The Witcher 2 had a discount. So i thought, why not try an RPG game? Besides, the reviews are good.I bought it, downloaded it and got ready to jump in. I thought the game was nice and all, till I tested its combat. I can't recall how many times have i died, trying to get the ballista in the Prologue. But i eventually passed through it. After 15 hours of gameplay, i realised that my items were still on the low level side; so long story short...i restarted the whole game and spent hours grinding and searching for the good items in the game. And it was very worth it.Each quest reveals the story and lore of The Witcher universe, which I daresay, is very wide and large. I enjoyed the story telling and presentation by the Developers, though sometimes I find the voice acting a bit..off. - Story 9/10Combat was very new to me too as I've never played any games similiar to the Witcher series. It might be a bit hard for new players like me to get it at first, but soon you'll find it natural just like breathing. Combat 8/10The Witcher 2 has an abundant of interesting characters to suck the players into its universe. Iorveth would had to be my favourite character :) . Good Job CD PROJEKT RED - 10/10Overall, this game is very well-made and tailored. After I finished this installment, I bought the Witcher 3 without hesitation.I expect my mind to be blown, CD PROJEKT RED :)

content:
Posted: March 4
												The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings followed in the glorious path that was set by the first Witcher game but took even greater turn towards the perfection that was topped by the third title.What the first game lacked, it was greatly improved in the Witcher 2, be it the wonderful graphics (which were pretty incredible for 6 years old game!), top notch storytelling and the much criticized combat mechanics.I write this review after my second playthrough before embarking on a journey of the Witcher 3 and I can tell you, I had a blast even after playing this game twice!I loved every little side quest, I loved reading the journal entries which were fun and entertaining (I really recommend to read them!) and I thoroughly enjoyed all the dialogs and plot twists and turns.The gameplay was fun and challenging and the combat issues I had in first game were no longer a bother.This game has also one of the best romance scenes in the gaming history (yes, I mean the one with the Triss Merigold :-)) ) and the choices you make throughout your adventure makes you feel like they really have impact on the story (which they really do!).If you played Witcher 3 but haven't tried previous two titles, I highly recommend you to go for it - you will have ton of fun! And if you haven't play Witcher 3 yet and you are thinking if you should start with the previous games first - hell yes! It feels great to go through the lore from the very beggining, absorb the story, the characters and all the things that will come back at every corner in the Witcher 3.Eternal glory to CD Projekt Red for their incredible work!15/10!

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
Time of completion: ~21 hours (68 days total)Date of writing the review: 22.February.2015Difficulty I played at: Easy (with a little twist, read below for more info)My rating: 7.5/10=====================================My review will be separated into different parts covering the many different aspects of the game. First let me give you my overall opinion and if you want you can read about every small detail about it.This game is great, I loved it. Unfortunately it suffers from many design flaws, which really make your experience frustrating at times. It seems that the developers didn't learn their lesson too well from the previous game's problems. I had to stop playing for about a month because of how the missions were layed out and the unclear mission markers.I played it on EASY difficulty, but only used the armor I imported from my "The Witcher 1" save and that armor sucks. I did not use trophies or good trousers or gauntlets. This really gave me a challenge and made the game a lot more enjoyable. Graphics and performance  I played it on a PC with an i7 4770, GTX 770 and 8GB ram on MAX settings. The performance was perfect. Stable 60 fps in every part of the game. It only dipped to 40-45 fps while exiting out of a cutscene, but it wasn't for more than 3 seconds anyway.The loading times are way too long though. The one that really stands out is when you die. After dying it takes a huuuge amout of time for the "reload" text to appear, staying in a black screen for more that 10 seconds. That forced me to constantly quick save so I don't die and have to wait for the black screen to disappear, I reloaded the save before the final blow.The graphics at first felt very weird to me. The whole prologue has this yellow overlay and makes the scenery look cartoony and fake. After the prologue is over the graphics look just right. Lots of greenery, beautiful scenery and an amazing view. Story:   I had no trouble understanding the story of "The Witcher 1", but this one was too much for me. I found it very difficult to follow. I often asked myself: Why does this guy do this ? Why is this here ? Why can't I just do this instead of this and all our troubles will be gone? The multiple choices were great though because I didn't like certain characters in the game and I wanted to see them suffer. Choosing to kill someone instead of saving them gave me the feel that I am in control of Gerald's life and I am not just there for the ride. This opens up the option to replay the game and have a different experience. I will definitely replay the game again in the future. Combat system A HUGE improvement over the combat system in The Witcher 1 in my opinion. There is just so much more to do than just mashing the left mouse button. You can dodge, parry, set traps, use mutagens to increase your abilities, meditate to drink potions and more. Unfortunately some of these options are completely unnecessary. I never once used a trap and never threw a dagger at someone's face.The meditation system is terribly implemented. In order to drink a potion (something which will decide the outcome of the battle) you have to meditate. You can only meditate before a battle and not during it. Then how the hell am I supposed to know when exactly a battle is gonna start ? How can I know when to prepare ? I know it looks more realistic this way, but in my opinion the game suffers because of it. This forced me to constantly quicksave after moving 20 meters because I didn't know when a battle wound start. Controls: The controls are not bad, what annoys me is that one key is used for so many actions. For instance the left mouse button is used to: attack, put out fires, jump down, climb up, talk, open doors and pick up items. I play on a PC, I should have the option to choose, not to have everything on the same key. I often picked up items I didn't want instead of opening a door, or climbed down a ledge instead of picking up an item. This adds to the frustration I mentioned earlier. Freedom: ... or the lack there of. There is not much freedom in movement. The Witcher 1 suffered from this too. The world is big, but it doesn't feel big at all. There is a pre-determined path you have to walk on. What if I want to go behind this house, or go and see this bush up close ? I can't. The world is very limited in terms of where you can go. Another thing is the ledges. I can't jump down from a half a meter tall ledge without clicking the left mouse button and waiting for Gerald to align himself to the exact spot where he can jump down and wait for an animation. I cannot just jump down from anywhere, no, I have to find the ledge where it says: jump down and then click on it. both TW1 and TW2 suffer from this and really slow down the game play a lot. Speaking of that... Gameplay: This is a story-driven game and unfortunately the gameplay will be constantly interrupted by a cutscene. I swear the cutscenes are so abundant that you can't walk 50 meters before being interrupted by a villager or a dwarf wanting to arm wrestle me. Not much gameplay to be had here. Fortunately the battles and especially the boss battles are very well made and some take a long time to complete without an interruption. Length: I was really surprised by how short the game felt. That must be because about 40% of the game is cutscenes or dialogue. If felt really short. Even after replaying the first 2 hours, starting from scratch, completing the game, spending an hour or 2 on arena mode, the game still felt very short for some reason. I mean it's 2 times shorter than The Witcher 1 and that game did not have so many cutscenes. ( 39 hours in TW1, 21 hours in TW2). Side missions: While the first game had very lengthy side mission, which made sence and gave you great benefits after completing them, this one  has none of that. Most (maybe 80%) of the side missions consist of: kill X number of enemies in this area and bring me proof, or win X number of arm wrestling contests, or win X number of dice poker games. Speaking of which, dice poker was my favorite distraction in TW1, in this one the dice are way too dark and hard to see, the symbols on them are almost identical, so I avoided playing it, that's unfortunate because I really loved that mini-game in TW1. Other small nit-picky things, which didn't fit anywhere else: + Boobs: You will see boobs, lots and lots of boobs. You will see and touch at least 5 pairs of boobs, if you search for them, you might get to see even 10 pairs.- Mission markers: Very difficult to determine where exactly they are. Often you will be standing on one, only to figure out that it is several floors below you. Now you have to find another way to get to it. Even games from 2002 had mission markers that indicated if the objective is above of below you and actually made sense (GTA Vice City)- Vergen: There is this city in Chapter 2 that has the worst layout ever. I am willing to bet that about an hour and a half of my playtime was spent trying to figure out how to get to a lower lever or find where exactly the mission marker is located. This chapter made me stop playing for about a month because of how annoying the layout of the city was.=================================================There is more to talk about, but I will leave it here because I ran out of characters. If you have questions then ask away, I will answer everybody. That's it for the review, I recommend the game, I paid 4 euro for it on the summer sale, but would not buy it for full price. The game definitely does not deserve the "best RPG ever" award and does not even come close to it. It is highly overrated and does not deserve a score higher than 7.5/10.Please play The Witcher 1 first, it was incredible and this one is a downgrade from the original.

Lots of greenery, beautiful scenery and an amazing view. Story:   I had no trouble understanding the story of "The Witcher 1", but this one was too much for me. I found it very difficult to follow. I often asked myself: Why does this guy do this ? Why is this here ? Why can't I just do this instead of this and all our troubles will be gone? The multiple choices were great though because I didn't like certain characters in the game and I wanted to see them suffer. Choosing to kill someone instead of saving them gave me the feel that I am in control of Gerald's life and I am not just there for the ride. This opens up the option to replay the game and have a different experience. I will definitely replay the game again in the future. Combat system A HUGE improvement over the combat system in The Witcher 1 in my opinion. There is just so much more to do than just mashing the left mouse button. You can dodge, parry, set traps, use mutagens to increase your abilities, meditate to drink potions and more. Unfortunately some of these options are completely unnecessary. I never once used a trap and never threw a dagger at someone's face.The meditation system is terribly implemented. In order to drink a potion (something which will decide the outcome of the battle) you have to meditate. You can only meditate before a battle and not during it. Then how the hell am I supposed to know when exactly a battle is gonna start ? How can I know when to prepare ? I know it looks more realistic this way, but in my opinion the game suffers because of it. This forced me to constantly quicksave after moving 20 meters because I didn't know when a battle wound start. Controls: The controls are not bad, what annoys me is that one key is used for so many actions. For instance the left mouse button is used to: attack, put out fires, jump down, climb up, talk, open doors and pick up items. I play on a PC, I should have the option to choose, not to have everything on the same key. I often picked up items I didn't want instead of opening a door, or climbed down a ledge instead of picking up an item. This adds to the frustration I mentioned earlier. Freedom: ... or the lack there of. There is not much freedom in movement. The Witcher 1 suffered from this too. The world is big, but it doesn't feel big at all. There is a pre-determined path you have to walk on. What if I want to go behind this house, or go and see this bush up close ? I can't. The world is very limited in terms of where you can go. Another thing is the ledges. I can't jump down from a half a meter tall ledge without clicking the left mouse button and waiting for Gerald to align himself to the exact spot where he can jump down and wait for an animation. I cannot just jump down from anywhere, no, I have to find the ledge where it says: jump down and then click on it. both TW1 and TW2 suffer from this and really slow down the game play a lot. Speaking of that... Gameplay: This is a story-driven game and unfortunately the gameplay will be constantly interrupted by a cutscene. I swear the cutscenes are so abundant that you can't walk 50 meters before being interrupted by a villager or a dwarf wanting to arm wrestle me. Not much gameplay to be had here. Fortunately the battles and especially the boss battles are very well made and some take a long time to complete without an interruption. Length: I was really surprised by how short the game felt. That must be because about 40% of the game is cutscenes or dialogue. If felt really short. Even after replaying the first 2 hours, starting from scratch, completing the game, spending an hour or 2 on arena mode, the game still felt very short for some reason. I mean it's 2 times shorter than The Witcher 1 and that game did not have so many cutscenes. ( 39 hours in TW1, 21 hours in TW2). Side missions: While the first game had very lengthy side mission, which made sence and gave you great benefits after completing them, this one  has none of that. Most (maybe 80%) of the side missions consist of: kill X number of enemies in this area and bring me proof, or win X number of arm wrestling contests, or win X number of dice poker games. Speaking of which, dice poker was my favorite distraction in TW1, in this one the dice are way too dark and hard to see, the symbols on them are almost identical, so I avoided playing it, that's unfortunate because I really loved that mini-game in TW1. Other small nit-picky things, which didn't fit anywhere else: + Boobs: You will see boobs, lots and lots of boobs. You will see and touch at least 5 pairs of boobs, if you search for them, you might get to see even 10 pairs.- Mission markers: Very difficult to determine where exactly they are. Often you will be standing on one, only to figure out that it is several floors below you. Now you have to find another way to get to it. Even games from 2002 had mission markers that indicated if the objective is above of below you and actually made sense (GTA Vice City)- Vergen: There is this city in Chapter 2 that has the worst layout ever. I am willing to bet that about an hour and a half of my playtime was spent trying to figure out how to get to a lower lever or find where exactly the mission marker is located. This chapter made me stop playing for about a month because of how annoying the layout of the city was.=================================================There is more to talk about, but I will leave it here because I ran out of characters. If you have questions then ask away, I will answer everybody. That's it for the review, I recommend the game, I paid 4 euro for it on the summer sale, but would not buy it for full price. The game definitely does not deserve the "best RPG ever" award and does not even come close to it. It is highly overrated and does not deserve a score higher than 7.5/10.Please play The Witcher 1 first, it was incredible and this one is a downgrade from the original.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												An excellent rpg with great soundtrack and dark humour where your choices does make a difference. The game has pretty interesting lore. I suggest you play the first game or read the books to have a better understanding of the story. The graphics were pretty good for an 2012 game. I find that their dialogues can be quite humourous at times. Be warned however, as this game's combat system punishes those who rush into the fight without preparation. Use everything in your arsenal including potions, spells, equipments and buffs to fight your enemies. The only problem with this game is that it always crashes when you have a lot of saves. All in all, I'd give it a solid 9/10.Glad I spent money on such a dedicated team. Look up CD PROJEKT ;)

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 13, 2016
												After finishing the Witcher 3, I decided to replay the Wicher 1 and eventually Witcher 2 I never fully played back in the day, to complete the story and this experience. I can never tell which part has my favorite storyline, they are all so well written and interwoven so each one is marvellous and feels like a brilliant piece of a larger set. The gameplay itself playing this part in 2016 does feel a bit clumsy since this isn't the Witcher 3's open world free movement and you end up feeling like going through a labyrinth half of the time. However the graphics still look amazing, the story is even more amazing, there are choices, there is politics, there is action, drama, love-making, a little bit of everything. It's a build-up to the Witcher 3 and I have seen many people say you don't need to have played 2 in order to pick up 3, but I definately wish I had played this one first, so i wold recommend doing that. It's brillaint, well-worth it and gives you the background for the next installment. I really hope they make another witcher game. 9.9/10 for me.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												I don't do reviews often (that's my friend HOTSHOT's job and specialty, hehe) but this game really deserves one from me.Simply one of the best RPGs I have ever played in my entire life. Amazing story (follow-up to The Witcher 1 in some ways but with a few new twists in the plot), awesome gameplay and really memorable characters. Keep in mind that the game has a bit of a "steep" learning curve when it comes to the combat mechanics. You really need to kind of "study" and pay attention to your enemies' moves/patterns (sort of like Dark Souls but not near as difficult) because you die pretty quickly, even on Normal difficulty.You need to get this game, even if you don't like RPGs, just the story itself is so compelling that you will have the desire to finish the game just to see how it unfolds. Buy it. Buy it. Buy it.

												This game is about our beloved witcher, Geralt of Rivia. Join him on an epic journey to clean his name and help the kingdom from falling apart. This is a game where your choices will have some affect on the later parts of the game. The games about The Witcher are very story-driven, so I would recommend you to read or play through the first "The Witcher". The combat is fun, and not only Hack and Slash, so it is challenging, and after some fights you will need to combine attacks with potions, poisons and Signs, magic spells Witchers use. The story is great, and after a while you will find out that Geralt is a character with great depth and a incredible backstory. If you want a monsterslaying game, a game with good story and atmosphere or just a game with good combat, this game is for you.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												Witcher 2's great in all fronts, graphics, gameplay, story, lore, charecters and so on. The action-RPG's a unique one, having been developed by CDProjekt Red, a Polish dev company bringing us a real prideful offering as to how a western action-RPG presents itself on the global stage. Unique in what regards?Positive:W2 has plenty of choices in the story arc, even outside the main forks in the road such as Roche's path, or Iorveth's path, there's certianly multiple ways to handel meeting up with bosses, and other key plot points. There's ways to close/not initiate certian mission b/c of xyz, so I sugest watching the "Changing Locations" vid from the devs on the multiple stories. W2 is indeed practically 1.5 games in 1.  The dialogue trees fill a convergence in the emersiveness and gets away with some pecilular takes on the cast's rogueish attitudes, Geralt picking up on chicks, the dice minigame, midevil slang, such as bugger, wh0r3son, ba$tard, all terms you don't really hear in the modern Americas, but used in Scottland, the UK, and such, however b/c this is a myere'd and dark time, synergysticaly it all plays to the story. Negative:The combat can be handled via simple mash to progress, however if you get into the rolling and dodgeing, you can fine tune your fighting tactics. Geralt's the archetypical battlemage w/ rather straightforward skilltrees for wizardry, and alchemy, however his swordplay and dodgeing whilst in combat are his coup de' grass. The skilltree progressions are linear, un-complicated, and arguabley a bit of a toss. Wizardy allows you to throw spells at a one shot per meter rate in battle, giving enemies status effects such as catching fire, while the alchemy tree has you crafting interesting potions that, unfortunately, can only be used just before the battle commences. The weapon/armor progression system's unique in an unfavorable way in regards to the story's tendancy to branch meaning you can miss a NPC needed that would have given you quests, or items, or even find yourself in custody, or in a dundgeon, and if you didn't explore it just right, you will lose your confiscated gear.W2's submenu's and UI are still difficult to nagivage, and aren't user friendly, however they're mods to it.Witcher 2 has a modding community as well, w/ game dev's even adding to the combat w/ advances from Witcher 3. Witcher 2 Multiple Paths Trailer: "Changing Locations"http://www.gametrailers.com/videos/1utzna/the-witcher-2--assassins-of-kings-enhanced-edition-exclusive-changing-locations-trailerWitcher 2 Offical Dev's "Unofficial Combat Mod" w/ aspects in combat from the upcoming Witcher 3http://redkit.cdprojektred.com/index.php?c=mod&m=show&p=77

content:
Posted: November 20, 2016
												I understand why people love this game—I get it, it has fantastic graphics, a great story, wonderful music and characters—so much to love. But what in the liviing hell is up with the terrible menus and AWFUL controls?! "Oh, I see I'm surrounded, better roll around and make sure to attack in the direction I'm facing"*Geralt attacks blindly in opposite direction while getting hacked in the backWhy can I not look at the key bindings in-game?Why can I not adjust the graphic settings in-game?Why does Geralt REFUSE to attack the guy with the shield who is on his &$#*ing KNEES?! He's right there, Geralt, it doesn't take a #$*ing witcher to NOT swing your bloody sword over his head, or for some unknown ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ reason turn your back to him while attacking in the general direction of the camera.I want to love this game. I love everything else about it. But without something resembling competent gameplay, a game is NOTHING to me. If the gameplay and UI were any clunkier, it would a box of rocks (that you pick up with the same button as attack, because yes, the gameplay here makes THAT little sense).This game isn't hard (I think I'm one of the few people who thought Dark Souls 2 was too easy), but I feel like I'm being punished by simply playing the game.What a massive dissapointment.**I am still going to try to get into this game (again), and if my opinion changes I'll update, but this is now my third time, and I still hate the combat in this game.

												Easily the best RPG I have played in years.A rich and vivid world that is home to a story that defies typical fantasy cliches. Sale discounts leave the game at around 4€ which might be worth the gamble.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												Like a little action in your RPG? I know I for one have been disappointed with many offerings in the ARPG genre, but The Witcher series has done alot to win my interest back to a once shining section of the video game world. There is a lot too this game, while I feel its not for me to break down all the flaws and finesse's of the sequel to The Witcher, I will point out that you will be hard pressed to find another game anything like it in its lore. In fact, everything in The Witcher is different from the normal; from a very interesting system progression system to the combat mechinics (which come with a fairly steep curve for those who havent the patience to learn the practice it takes to time blows and parries). There is alot to like about this game. I've come only to write this "Review" to tell you that if you havent tried this series out dont worry, The Witcher 2 story brings new players in nicely without making it feel patched into the story. Other than that, this is a AAA rpg that has added the action combat element near flawlessly. Its got its kinks and there are some questionable interface choices but really Im nit picking because there isnt a whole lot to complain about. Just buy the game. Its worth your dollars if your a fan of fantasy rpg with action combat. The difference here is the difficulty isnt insulting and the depth is rewarding. Get the damn game, okay?

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
												One of the greatest RPGs ever made. The biggest positive of this game is it's non linearity- there are many difficult choices that we will have to make. Second chapter of the game looks completly different depending on our previous decisions. The story is pretty decent, just a bit "too political" in my opinion, but all those movie-like cutscenes are downright gorgeous. It just makes it really easy to feel involed in what's going on. Combat is ok, sort of a tactical hack & slash. It's up to us whether we'll help ourselves with magical signs, traps, potions or with little of everything. The only two flaws that I can think of is difficulty arch (game is hard at the beggining and gets quite easy later), and the fact that it could really be longer. Takes 20+ hours to finish the main story, and 30+ hours to finish it with all the side quests. But still I think it's a great game and I'd recommend it to anyone who likes action RPGs.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												A good successor to the first game. That said, It did have problems.  The gameplay, more specifically the combat, in my opinion didn't get better, in fact it just turned more frustrating.For starters, the targetting system is an utter failure.  Now you say, "Can you elaborate?".  My response to that is not really, so if you are expecting Batman Arkham Asylum smoothness in regards to targetting, prepare to be disappointed.  Second, the practicality of Geralt's sword combat.  When in comparison to the first game it had three fighting stances:  The strong stance, reserved for heavy/bulky enemies; the fast stance, for the quick and agile enemies; and the group stance, for those times when you were outnumbered and surrounded.  In the Witcher 2, those stances were thrown away and combat became streamlined by replacing it with light attacks by clicking the left mouse and heavy attacks by pressing the right mouse.  That doesn't sound bad, right?  In some cases, yes, it worked out fine.  But there were some instances where this new combat mechanic just sucked completely.The big problem is that the new mechanic didn't leave it as straightforward as the first game.  Geralt in this game does his super stylish spins in the worst of occasions.  Where in the Witcher 1, he did his spin attacks more in his group stance to keep from being overwhelmed, and in this game he does his spins for the sake of spinning, whether you are surrounded or not.  Sometimes when you want him to do a wide slash spin when surrounded, he doesn't, or when you want to do powerful but quick attacks on one or 2 opponents, he does his spins and all that time he used up spinning he gets hit like the idiot he was.  TL;DR  You have less control of the swordplay in the Witcher 2 in comparison to the Witcher 1.Next up is the potions/enhancements.  Oh god...  This was probably the most frustrating bit.  In the Witcher 1, you could go into your inventory and drink a potion.  Before or during combat, and the effects lasted much longer.  Simple as that.In the Witcher 2, you have to predict when combat will show up, sit down, drink, have him♥♥♥♥♥♥around for another 10 seconds, stand up, then you are good to go.  And no, you can't drink potions during combat.  So, if you show up at a boss fight with no potions in your system, you are screwed.  You either have to go back a save or two, drink the potions on the prior knowledge of meeting the boss/hard part and beat it/them, or you have to bite the bullet and beat it/them without potions.  Hilariously enough, you can enhance your armor and weapons during combat.  Why not stay consistant?  I don't know.  Even worse, the potion effects only last 10 minutes (a tiny bit more if you have devote your levels to the alchemy skills).  TL;DR  Your potion usage is restricted (in comparison to the prequel again).What else...  The game is shorter in content overall and in my opinion feels just a little bit more linear and less open.Oh, and the game's soundtrack doesn't feel as memorable as the first.So far, everything from the above is dedicated to those who played the first game.  If you haven't, then it won't really change anything.OTHER THAN THAT....The graphics are glorious.  The textures are really top notch.The story is well thought out.  If you don't know much of the lore you might be a bit confused time to time.Oh, and no naked chick cards.  This time we get a couple of sex scenes.  Woohoo.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2016
												TLDR:-This game is phenominal, buy it.Long Version:My first experience with The Witcher was the third game. I decided to play through the first two for background then the third one again. I expected the first two games to be a drag, especially after being spoiled by the graphics and gameplay of The Witcher 3. I was pleasantly surpised, to the point that I decided to restart the first game after skipping most of the side quests in the first two chapters. I also decided to read the novels and short stories to gain a greater understanding of the characters and story in the games. I am extremely glad I did. Not only do they obviously give you a much greater understanding of the aforementioned elements, but they are also phenomenal stories by themselves. This game has stood the test of time surprisingly well, and is definitely worth your money, even at full price, though, if you are willing to wait, you could get it much cheaper on sale, as I did.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												This sequel really lives up to the name. The battling system, character development and abilities have been completely changed. I am playing it on a very high difficulty level as that is the only way for unique items to be available in the game, so I'm not sure if the battling is challenging on the lower settings. My experience so far has been a difficult one so far :)The graphics engine is absolutely amazing and if you have a beast of a machine you will fully enjoy the beauty of this game. I sometimes just stand around and admire the landscape. As with the first Witcher there are some of mini-games for you to spend some time on.Whether you are a Witcher fan or not.. this is an exceptional RPG!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												This game is superb in almost every aspect. It has a very well connected story with mature content and its "replayability" is  enough to spend more than 40-50 hours playing it. The game is closer to a linear than a non-linear game, but in a certain way that's what makes the story special, because you can realize how the decisions you make change the story/world through each chapter (still, the player has a wide freedom in each chapter, excluding the prologue/epilogue). The script is written in a way that sometimes decisions are extremely hard to make, something that I liked a lot. Sidequest in this game are well made and worth your time since they are mainly separate stories which will engulf you even more in the game, also, they sometimes have *minor* impact in the main plot.The combat and skill tree is ok, much better than in TW1 IMO, in the end, it depends on your tastes.The graphics are really cool and it has been a game to take as reference to make benchmarks.The soundtrack is awesome and every track fits every part of the game. A must have for RPG lovers. 9/10

content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												The Witcher series turned out to be one of my gaming diamond. It's not about graphics, but strong plot and solid RPG elements will stick with you in every moments of the game. The Witcher 2 still remain its standard of story (some parts are modified from The Witcher novel). You might want to catch up from The Witcher 1 to gain full experience of the story. The highlight is various decisions along three main chapters which point you out and force you to deal with consequence. This give high replayability like The Witcher 1.The combat system is changed from point-and-click (The Witcher 1) to dynamic hit-and dodge (The Witcher 2). For me, the combat is greatly flexible, but less complexity in strategy (The Witcher 1 gives your more different sword styles and Sign charge). The skill system is quite stricted than The Witcher 1 skill pattern). However,  the game provides you a lot of armors and weapons choice (Yeah, you can hit boss with a scoop).QTE is also another factor that's shouldn't be in RPG game, I feel kinda disappointed they put QTE in the end of boss fight and fistfight minigame. Cause the game lacks some challenges.I may complain too much about its problem. However, it's just minor issues and I understand it's hard to keep its previous standard if you attempt to change something. The Witcher 2 still one of my strong RPG game all the time. even it's not deepest, longest, or toughest, but I feels very very enjoyable in every moment of this game and I have high hope for The Witcher 3.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												This is a game for those who appreciate a well-rounded, deep, and engaging RPG. The game's vanilla difficulty curve is strange. It starts out balls hard, then becomes a cake walk towards the end. If this becomes problematic for some, go to   The Witcher 2 Section of Nexus Mods [www.nexusmods.com]  and install the "Witcher 2 Full Combat Rebalance" using Nexus Mod Manager. I recomend using NMM unless you are comfortable with installing mods manually and dealing with the files themselves.Overall I, as a fan of RPGs such as this, would give it a solid 9/10 for:(Good)+Great graphics/animation+Interesting art+Good story/writing+SO MUCH CHOICE+Combat mechanics(Bad)-Gameplay style uncomfortable for newcomers-Throws player to the wolves in the beginning, recommend playing tutorial

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												CD Projekt weaves an impressive, mature & complex storyline that evolves based on your decisions.  I'm really in awe seeing how my choices made a deep impact.  In one playthrough, Geralt aided the murder of a king.  (He deserved it!)  In another, Geralt was a liberator.  The third time, our "hero" was in it for himself reigning death & having mobs have their way.Other games are just too linear by following a single path to a given destination.  The Witcher 2 destroys the mold by varying the direction of the game.  By the 2nd chapter you've chosen a side which massively affects everything:  allies may now be enemies, where you end up is completely different, and those you saved may have dire consequences later on.With multiple endings, I highly recommend this RPG.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												Now I sit here with the Witcher 2 finally finished.I am not a big fan of it's combat but then I am spoiled with the Dark Souls series. The game although bring a lot to the table. Anyone playing Crusader Kings 2 will feel like they are playing a minor hero character in a big world of politics and schemes. It is brutal world, a beautiful, brutal world! The story continues from the first game and puts Geralt in a messy messy time full of troubles. This game was released same year as Dragon Age 2 and Skyrim. It is probably not as big and as long as these two but I think it out perform Dragon Age 2 with flavour and story, I care more for the characters in Witcher 2 than those in Dragon Age 2. In Dragon Age 2 I wanted to kill them. In Skyrim I did not care even that much about NPCs and many places felt very empty. The Witcher is a very gorgeous game. As I said before the combat is not my favourite but I can see if people prefer this over the more unique Witcher 1 combat system. The sound is good and the voice actors are in my opinion very good. The models also come in more flavours this time compared to Witcher 1. It feels a bit shorter than Witcher 1 but comes with a big replayability with the a split in the road. I do hope that all your options, Kill A, Let A go, Save X over Z, Help Nr 1 and fight Nr 2. I hope these options have consquences in Witcher 3. The game is not perfect but to consider what a failure the big guys at Bioware itself released this year and how they continued to release overrated games with plenty of flaws, it is hard then to judge this Polish studios struggles. It is a excellent  game in a grim world! Showing the darkness of humanity and the chaos errupting from a dead king. Resembling the chaos in Europe in the middle ages in a bit. It is a grim bloody world, full of prejudice, hate, treachery and  destruction. But also lot of comeraderie, courage and love shown. 9 out of 10. Trigger Warning: It is not a game for you SJW wimps! Go play Dragon Age Inquisition with you.

												Pros :+ Pretty good graphics.Not THAT good,though+ Beautifully written story line+ Tons of things and quests to do+ A lot of items variation available,from potions,weapons,enhancements,etc,so there's a lot of thing to find,craft,or buy so you won't get bored after several hours+ The words you choose to speak will affect the story+ Uncensored nude girls characters sometimes appears along the game story.This game even has some sex scenes in it.I'm not sure to put this in the Pros.But since I'm a guy,so...Cons :- I don't really like the combat system.It's a little bit crude and it's impossible for me to win without getting hit if multiple opponents attack me.- Characters have no expression.It's vital to add facial expression and good voice acting in a story rich game.The voice actor for Geralt (main character,the white haired guy) isn't a really good one for me,and there's no facial expression at all- Crude animations during the 'talking' session where you choose what do you want Geralt to speak- Strange movement animation.The animation when you walk to right/left/back direction is really,really bad.- Controller support is a failure for me.I can't manage my inventory at all using my controller.No,mine is not a third party controller.I don't know the problem is me or the game,though.Overall,the cons are meaningless and it's totally acceptable and it won't ruin your gameplay.Unless you can only play with a controller,of course.I love this game so much for its story line and the ability to control the way Geralt respond to other characters (not for its nude girls and sex scenes).This game is totally worth it an I'm really looking forward to play The Witcher 3 : Wild Hunt.Buy this game if you want to know the whole story.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												CD Projekt weaves an impressive, mature & complex storyline that evolves based on your decisions.  I'm really in awe seeing how my choices made a deep impact.  In one playthrough, Geralt aided the murder of a king.  (He deserved it!)  In another, Geralt was a liberator.  The third time, our "hero" was in it for himself reigning death & having mobs have their way.Other games are just too linear by following a single path to a given destination.  The Witcher 2 destroys the mold by varying the direction of the game.  By the 2nd chapter you've chosen a side which massively affects everything:  allies may now be enemies, where you end up is completely different, and those you saved may have dire consequences later on.With multiple endings, I highly recommend this RPG.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												A lot can be said about this game. It has its great moments, but also some very lame sides. First, the positive things about this game: It is a nicely done rpg with lots of costumization possibilities. You can not travel between cities and have to follow the plot of the game, but once you're in a city, you are free to explore it however you want to. There are lots of side quests and the main plot itself is very interesting. The side quests are also meaningful and mostly fund, not of the "fetch me this flowe" kind. The game is clearly made for adults, since there's a lot of brutality and nudity in it. This is nice to see in an era where almost every game is being made for all audiences. The crafting system is also one of the strong features of Witcher 2. You can craft weapons, armor, potions, traps etc.On the other hand, there are some things which ruin the game. The checkpoint (aka autosave) system is a failure. You watch a cutscene, you listen to a conversation and then get to the fight scene. If you die, you don't get to fight again immediately; no you have to watch the cutscene again (which you can skip btw) and listen to the conversation (which you can click through). It is very annoying to constantly have to click your way to the fight after every death and it only adds to your frustration. There are also instances in the game where you don't control your main character, but you are rather given the control of a character in the story to fight. The game is almost telling you "Hey remember all those skills you gained through collecting experience and all? Yeah, they're gone. Have fun!". This is very very frustrating. In the end, you should make up your mind: can you endure the frustration of this game to enjoy its exciting plot and positive features?tl;dr Witcher 2 is a beautiful game with some very annoying bull**** in it.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												Haunting and atmospheric just like the first in the series, and very fun and challenging to play through. The series seems to be becoming more action/adventure oriented than an RPG meant for purists, but what this game does it does very well. The combat system has become more oriented toward player skill rather than Geralt's attributes, but this turned out to be pretty fun once I got the hang of the controls. Branching storylines encourage replayability, as in the first game. At first I had a problem with the excessive use of bloom and shader effects, though these things are implemented far better and more artistically after the first chapter, so I suggest everyone keep these settings enabled. Overall this is a very well-written and clever game and I would recommend it to fans of the first game or fans of the fantasy fiction genre in general. You won't be disappointed!

content:
Posted: April 6, 2016
The Witcher 2: Assassins of KingsPros:. Well written, easy to follow story. A lot of choices which are divided into 'Major' and 'Minor', the major will affect the story and the minor will usually be something personal to Geralt, such as a choice between Orens (the games currency) or some gear. All of the main characters are fantastic, and even then, the more minor characters will have some short story behind them. Very good graphics which still hold up today. Good combat for the most part, knowledge is key in this game, if go into some fights without correctly preparing with oils and potions et cetera, you're probably going to die very fast. A good 'rewardingly difficult' system similar to Dark Souls (although not as hard) . Fairly good replayabilty. Good game length for the priceCons. Game is pretty unoptimized, I bought this on my old pc, which was bad but still above the recommended requirements and couldn't this game at a stable frame rate at all. Now, however with my 390, the framerate dips from the usual 60 (on ultra) all the way down to 20 in certain situations. The game is quite buggy, such as the game not allowing you to do simple things like climb a rock which can halt your progress into the game. The horrible targeting system the game uses for its combat, you can only target one enemy at once which can screw up entire scenarios as the target is chosen via who is at the centre of the camera, which leads to things like being unable to attack another enemy with easeOverallI give this game a 8.1/10 and heavily recommend it to any Witcher or RPG fan for its great narrative, characters, and gameplay, but be wary of the games bad optimisation and bugs.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												I'm still not sure what to think of this game. Visually it's absolutely beautiful. The story and the lore are great, there's a branching path which makes the game play differently, there's no "right" and "wrong"... But the actual game itself, as a game with its technicalities and mechanics, falls short of my expectations.The user interface is confusing, and not only because there are no tooltips:The only witcher sign whose purpose I could remember was Igni, because it burned things.Inventory management is a mess; they have tried simplifying it compared to the first game, but again, without any tooltips, the only sorting options I figured out were "by newest obtained" and "by most weight". The others... I have no idea what they're about.The character skill tree won't list where mutagen slots are located. I've talked to a couple of people who played the game, and they all mutated their first ability with something stupid. You can't remove the mutagen, so you're stuck with that choice until the end of the game. If you're reading this, don't do it until you're absolutely sure that you chose correctly, because it won't be surprising if you used a lesser mutagen and got a greater mutagen five minutes later.You have to decide early on which path to take: magic, alchemy, swords. Not enough talents to push all three branches.Looting is a problem, as there is no "highlight loot" key, and there are no labels. If a corpse leaves more than 4 things to be looted, you won't see them until you enter the loot window. Positioning the character to loot items and rotating the camera is too hard.The map is confusing, especially if you're outside a city. Sometimes it seems you can go a certain way to get somewhere, but it's blocked by some bushes and you have to go back and find an alternate route. You can't leave markers, nor is everything on the map marked: for example, in Flotsam I found a book merchant in a random house.Buying weapons/armor from merchants doesn't let you compare stats to items you own.You can get good items by crafting diagrams, but you have to find someone to craft; Geralt can't do it. He can just make potions. I actually had to use pen and paper to write down what I want and what I need to craft it.Speaking of potions - you can't drink them during a battle. You have to do it before, but... How are you supposed to know you'll be in battle? Some people like it, some don't, but for most, if they desire challenging combat, it'll be a case of "save often, reload often".Eventually I dropped down to easy difficulty, stopped caring about my inventory, looting, oils, potions, bombs and all of that, and just concentrated on the story and the quests. Before that, I was fighting the game itself, instead of monsters.And the game became fun.If you want a deep story - go for it. If you want perfect and streamlined game mechanics, go for it still, but you might want to do what I did.Recommended anyway. Looking forward to the third game!

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												Some my Pros/ConsPros:+ Mod support+ Ritch storyline+ Nice looking visuals even on low settings+ Perfect soundtracks+ A lot of craftable items+ High quality NPC voice acting+ Fun during monster hunt (preparing traps/poisons/reading up on the creatures etc)Cons:- Unrealistic sword combat. It doesn't feel right. - Unbalanced gameplay mechanics - Oils and potions barely last long enough to be of any use, and forcing you to drink them in meditation mode is tiresome. Also fairly unrealistic and breaks immersion somewhat. Many skills over/underpowered (i.e. dodge-roll, shield sign, alchemy tree etc.)-Clunky UI and menus. Bad sorting options, unintuitive selection design (i.e. hover over recipe with mouse cursor, then press space or enter to complete recipe. but don't click and make sure not to move your mouse away from recipe in list). The map, while looking totally freaking awesome, is almost entirely useless. Many more problems with UI.-Lack of camera controls and options.-Unclear or non-existent tutorials.-Also, doors. OMG DOORS. Another obvious piece of the game programmed with the fortcoming console port in mind.Overall. 6/10.  I can recommend Witcher 2 if you are keen on fantasy setting and magic items crafting...

content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												I highly recommend this game simply for the facts that the Story is great, It's good looking, the fighting mechanism is really good and it contains hard puzzels (you got to read the quests to make progress).  It's not a rush game (where you kill and proceed) in this game you have to dodge, parry and barrel roll and then strike.  The fighting mechanism is more like dodge until you find a great opportunity to strike and prepare before you go into combat (drinking potions, use poison ETC).The cons though would be the "target select mechanism" because when you're fighting a lot of enemys, the character "Geralt" attacks (often) the nearest enemy pointed in the direction you're looking at, and also when you have a companion the enemys rather attack your companion than you (which makes the game a lot easier).8/10 IMO
