												One of the best RPG I have ever played. Great story telling, great character development and character engagement. The battle system is also very well executed and at some points (and at hard difficulty setting) challenging. Side quests are atmospheric and far from feeling grindy. Morale choices are all over the place and those choices matter and they also alter the experience making replayabilty a must rather than a chore . Graphics are stellar and there are also some mods if you are fun of modding . On the minus side there are are some bugs but nothing game breaking. I had a boss fight stuck and the game could nor progress but this wasn’t often and didn’t ruin my enjoyment. All in all a great game that should not be missed from any RPG fun and its on SALE very very often ;)

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2011
												♥♥♥♥ing Brilliant - Is tied in my Top 3 RPG's of all time list.I originally purchased 'The Witcher' after reading positive reviews about a week after launch - With the Death metal band VADER helming the official music video that I checked out on youtube; it was SOLD for me, I purchased it via Direcct2Drive as it was not on the Steam Platform at that time. TW1 on its launch was hailed by critics and myself for having an amazing story - and even more impressive: (Re-Coding the BioWare ?Aurura?) engine used for Neverwinter Nights into a Third Person Action / Tactical combat system; with optional WASD movement.-As soon as The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings popped up on Steam for pre-order I pre-ordered with huge excitement. I checked out the system requirements and I had just ordered my 560 ti SLI's from that era; along with 120hz monitor and Nvidia 3D Vision 1.0 - -Once it came to launch day I was able to play everything on Ultra aside from having Ubersampling on (Now with my 780 ti's in SLI ubersampling is cake; it was also 100% smooth when I had SLI 680's and SLI 780 GTX MSI OC edition) - The Visauls set the bar for the Genre, perhaps "in house" engines in general. The art design was outstanding, dark and gritty edged with realism in every nook and cranny. The lighting/Shadow, weather+day cycles all realistically done in a mind blowing fashion.  "Nvidia 3D Vision Ready" - I popped on the original Nvidia 3D vision 1.0 wireless glasses with the old asus 120Hz monitor I had. This may still be the most brilliant 3D vision title ever released. Geralt's swords literally (unsheath and just stand holding it) would pop out in a way that it seemed the blade was coming a foot+ out of the screen and right into my face; the tip of the blade. - I had an entire play in 3D Vision and it was the most astonishing "3D" experiences of my lifetime in gaming. I've completed the game 5 times, with one being totally 3D Vision, one Playthru when I got my 680's initially, then began a playthrough that I finished when I received my 780s (each series I had dual SLI) - Seeing the transformation of all ultra with Ubersampling enabled from SLI 560ti's to 680's was outstanding and jaw dropping; then not worrying about hitting 70Cish once I git my 780's was even more-so outstanding -laughs- : I was still being held back a bit in overall performance due to my CPU an AMD 8150 that would bottleneck such great CPU's; and using all 4 slots on my MOBO for ram with an AMD CPU is a no-go idea for performance; as I had 16 gigs of G.Skill ripjaws. - despite this I finished that play, and finally decided to play it with a non "Vernon Roche" chapter 2 (yeah I was stubborn, I always intedned on the next play being the completely different chapter 2 but had to keep going with Vernon Roche's ideals as it felt like who I was as a player, and the Geralt I wanted to play as. I upgraded my CPU to an AMD 9370 8 core liquid cooled at 5.0GHz, and grabbed 2x8GB G.Skill Trident X's with very low (fast) timings and higher over-all speed of the ram and saw amazing boosts in all my benchmarks; and Played thru-once more. I began a playthru again; just completing all but one of the interrogation flashbacks with Vernon Roche - When I upgraded my SLI 780's to SLI 780 ti's (Each Nvidia GPUs mentioned have been the MSI Manufactured versions). The 780 Ti being the fastest GPU ever created with 1GHz faster memory speed per card than the prior "OC Gaming Edition" 780's I had, and 800 more Cuda cores amongst other very impressive improvments.- Having a 144hz monitor with Nivida G-Sync Kit attached in and working (the asus 144hz Nvidia 3D Vision 2.0 / Nvidia lightboost 24 inch monitor came G-Sync kit ready 6 months prior to G-Sync being announced; I am glad this was the monitor I purchased back then; I was dissapointed when I read about G-Sync specific monitors then elated when I saw this was the only current monitor that was G-Sync Upgradable.- For the most recent play-through I contacted Nvidia for a G-Sync kit; used a phillips head on the back of the monitor and easily plugged in the chip (has a nice clear and labled spot for it to just plug right in) It's hard to even describe the difference until you actually groove with it and see / play with it yourself! My PC is totally ready for Geralt's Finale in the gaming franchise (I have yet to read the original books that the games are based)With many RPG's coming out for each platform; I had a huge J-RPG crush during the SNES-PSX era; Highlights being FF2 cartridge(FF4)-FF3 Cartridge(FF6) and the reason I purchased a PSX for the timeless Final Fantasy Vii, The dissapointing FF8 comes to mind as I forced myself to play it due to hype and having it pre-ordered the same date the Dreamcast was released on 9-9-99, and then despite having amazing adventures on my PC With Baldurs Gate 1-2, Planescape Torment etc - I gave Final Fantasy IX a chance which blew me away and was able to give Square another chance in my book; for the awful FF8; releasing a rather fantastic and "Interesting FF9" - Still J-RPG's forced linerality which defenders proclaim "It's about the story" (It seems these defenders have never played PLANESCAPE TORMENT or Baldurs Gate 2 The Witcher 1 suffered SOME gameplay and combat elements for an excellent story; Dragon Age Origins and The Witcher 2 had far superior stories than any J-RPG I've played without the lineraty style seen in J-RPG's, but thats a battle between fan's that  will never end as JRPG diehards assume any PC/Western RPG is an Elderscrolls style Open World Title with very poor story (Although Morrowind <3 <3 had a rather excellent story; despite the shallow characters that Bethesda still continues on with) - Perhaps the Witcher 2: Enhanced Edition release on The Xbox 9800 or whatever (Atari Jaguar 720 etc) was an excellent wake up call to many console Atari Joystick gamers; they got to finally experience our 2011 GOTY / RPG of the year; which then was a GOTY candidate and RPG of the year winner again in 2012 due to the Enhanced Edition console release (Confusing indeed.) which brought more revenue and spotlight towards the wonderful minded CDProjektRED; without that occuring and having TW3 be multi-platform (WITH PC as the Ultimate Intended platform still; partnering with Nvidia for hardware owning only options that are mindblowing in the Press Conference highlighting them all by Nvidia <3) - Then perhaps TW3 would not have been on the cover of Game Informer pumping up people who perhaps didn't even notice the 360 version on store shelves as "Skyrzrimz" is all they've ever heard of in the Role-Playing Game Format; or "Falloutz" Not that these titles have anything wrong with them The general public just murders anything excellent with their subpar Console versions while being blown away by the graphics (I saw skyrim on a friends 360 and threw up in my mouth a little)-I was sent a promo copy of the 360 version to review due to CDPR knowing my love for The White Wolf and his awesome adventures, I grabbed a 360 and blasted through the 360 form of the title which seemed to have pushed the console to its limits and then some, arguably the best looking 360 title to date - I was happy gamers who settle with 8 year old hardware could enjoy TW2 on Less than Medium PC settings!-Now with The Wicther 3's release looming; my PC being ready for the game to run smooth on Ultra; I cannot wait to be immersed completely rec. footage via Nvidia Shadowplay & Twitch.TV No Death Ruleset streams; with SLI 780 ti's prepared for all the Nvidia exclusive hardware graphical / immersive implementations that will not be possible with the "Next Gen hardware from 2010" consoles but when I shut up and think about it, Atleast more people are still experiencing TW2 and will experience TW3 (even if it is subpar to the build we'll be pre-ordering here on Steam). Geralt The Riv. Geralt of Rivia, The White Wolf.We have more adventures in store for us.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2014
												The Witcher 2 world is simply wonderful, picturesque, varied and vast, incomparable to any other role-playing game.It isn’t open world game. But don’t worry, you won’t run along the paths on both sides limited by invisible walls. CDPR replaced them seamlessly with natural obstacles like chasms, giant trees or very thick bushes. Locations are very diverse. These are cities, villages, open areas, and covered with dense vegetation and ancient elven forest where tree crowns blurring high in the clouds. All amaze diversity and ingenuity. The new proprietary engine Red Engine perfectly shows a play of lights, creating a magical atmosphere, paradoxically also realistically.Combat plays crucial role in the game at any moment we have the opportunity to duel difficult opponent and even take part in the epic battles. The fighting has changed since the first Witcher. We have stronger and more powerful attacks to choose from, varied by passive and active skills. There are three paths of character development: swordsmanship, alchemy and magic. Generally, fighting system is fun, scenic and rewarding, it requires constant attention and feline reflexes, because sometimes we literally have only split seconds to activate protective emblems or attack an open enemy. Not everyone will like this rule, since some players might get frustrated fighting larger groups or one difficult enemy. Overall, The Witcher 2 Assassins of Kings is a beautiful game with modern graphics and addictive gameplay, with its emphasis on realism, psychologically complex characters, original and surprising missions, elections burdened consequences, rewarding combat, good music, humor, sex and climate. First of all, the climate! All these elements form a coherent whole for making up the unique atmosphere. We have, moreover, to deal with the so-called immersion, true masterpieces in terms of visualization and scenario.

												Really fluid combat system. Beautiful graphics. In-depth gameplay with lots of game mechanics (skills, combat moves, items). Also tons of side-quests for you to do. HOWEVER! number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 7, 2016
												While The Witcher 1 was a big first and successfull attempt to bring the world and feel of adventure of Witcher books to the video games, Witcher 2 wanted to up the quality. Tell an even better story, look better, play better... Which might've worked if not for all the issues this game had during the development, issues that are felt throught the rather messy experience The Witcher 2 is.They did succeed in making it look better, obviously, but the look actually aged a bit worse due to the colour filtering choices and the fact that for all the looks it achieved, the world feels smaller, more cramped, more boring to look at. Not everywhere, of course, act 2 has few locations that look nice and the opening scenes can be impressive, but most of the game just looks like a mess of drab colours.It tells the story in a more interesting way, but the story itself is less interesting. It has more nuances, it has some very exciting global implications on the game world and choices feel more natural, are provided in a more personal way. It does bring even more wit and humour from the books, it evolves the characters. And it is the very best thing about the game. Although, it seems, that in Witcher 3 most of the choices are invalidated by events out of your control anyway. Oh and if you do play for story - just go with Iorveth. While Roche path has some pretty interesting (and also mostly invalidated in TW3) choices, all of Act 2 and most of Act 3 will be extremely boring, as Roche gets the most boring locations, quests and dialogues in his path, seemingly mostly due to the fact that this path was developed last.As for the gameplay... If you play on Normal, it's not bad. If you try the Full Combat Rebalance 2 mod it might make some things more interesting. If you play Dark mode or something like that, then don't try the FCR2 mod... Actually, just don't play Dark mode at all, or any other higher difficulty. Despite some attempts by CDP RED to make gameplay fun, gameplay is mostly pretty frustrating and is either simply not fun, or in some cases maddeningly broken. A lot of ideas, with recipies, crafting and such are just a mess (and Dark mode only "benefits" depend on those). In addition, all those small animation limitations, you encounter everywhere and things like that make The Witcher 2 to be not a particularly fun game to play.But the story can be worth it. And was for me, twice. Just, don't expect to like anything else.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												Played it in late 2015 with Windows 8.1. I did not play Witcher 1 previously.This game has its flaws. It is not perfect. Among the bad things, we have:- Several Crashes. In my 35 gameplay hours, it crashed like 4-6 times. - Awful UX. I didn't like the menus. For instance, when buying a new weapon, you don't have the option to compare the new weapon and your actual weapon. You have to exit vendor's menu, enter your inventory, memorize your weapon, and then enter vendor's menu and compare both weapons. Awful.- The combat is a little rough.Among the good things:+ The story is great. I really liked the story and the plot twists. + Your choices matter.  There are several endings based on your decisions.+ The bosses are incredibly hard yet fun. I cursed at the screen several times, yet I couldn't stop playing.+ Graphics are nice even as today.+ Playing Witcher 1 previously is not a requirement.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												Some my Pros/ConsPros:+ Mod support+ Ritch storyline+ Nice looking visuals even on low settings+ Perfect soundtracks+ A lot of craftable items+ High quality NPC voice acting+ Fun during monster hunt (preparing traps/poisons/reading up on the creatures etc)Cons:- Unrealistic sword combat. It doesn't feel right. - Unbalanced gameplay mechanics - Oils and potions barely last long enough to be of any use, and forcing you to drink them in meditation mode is tiresome. Also fairly unrealistic and breaks immersion somewhat. Many skills over/underpowered (i.e. dodge-roll, shield sign, alchemy tree etc.)-Clunky UI and menus. Bad sorting options, unintuitive selection design (i.e. hover over recipe with mouse cursor, then press space or enter to complete recipe. but don't click and make sure not to move your mouse away from recipe in list). The map, while looking totally freaking awesome, is almost entirely useless. Many more problems with UI.-Lack of camera controls and options.-Unclear or non-existent tutorials.-Also, doors. OMG DOORS. Another obvious piece of the game programmed with the fortcoming console port in mind.Overall. 6/10.  I can recommend Witcher 2 if you are keen on fantasy setting and magic items crafting...

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2011
												♥♥♥♥ing Brilliant - Is tied in my Top 3 RPG's of all time list.I originally purchased 'The Witcher' after reading positive reviews about a week after launch - With the Death metal band VADER helming the official music video that I checked out on youtube; it was SOLD for me, I purchased it via Direcct2Drive as it was not on the Steam Platform at that time. TW1 on its launch was hailed by critics and myself for having an amazing story - and even more impressive: (Re-Coding the BioWare ?Aurura?) engine used for Neverwinter Nights into a Third Person Action / Tactical combat system; with optional WASD movement.-As soon as The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings popped up on Steam for pre-order I pre-ordered with huge excitement. I checked out the system requirements and I had just ordered my 560 ti SLI's from that era; along with 120hz monitor and Nvidia 3D Vision 1.0 - -Once it came to launch day I was able to play everything on Ultra aside from having Ubersampling on (Now with my 780 ti's in SLI ubersampling is cake; it was also 100% smooth when I had SLI 680's and SLI 780 GTX MSI OC edition) - The Visauls set the bar for the Genre, perhaps "in house" engines in general. The art design was outstanding, dark and gritty edged with realism in every nook and cranny. The lighting/Shadow, weather+day cycles all realistically done in a mind blowing fashion.  "Nvidia 3D Vision Ready" - I popped on the original Nvidia 3D vision 1.0 wireless glasses with the old asus 120Hz monitor I had. This may still be the most brilliant 3D vision title ever released. Geralt's swords literally (unsheath and just stand holding it) would pop out in a way that it seemed the blade was coming a foot+ out of the screen and right into my face; the tip of the blade. - I had an entire play in 3D Vision and it was the most astonishing "3D" experiences of my lifetime in gaming. I've completed the game 5 times, with one being totally 3D Vision, one Playthru when I got my 680's initially, then began a playthrough that I finished when I received my 780s (each series I had dual SLI) - Seeing the transformation of all ultra with Ubersampling enabled from SLI 560ti's to 680's was outstanding and jaw dropping; then not worrying about hitting 70Cish once I git my 780's was even more-so outstanding -laughs- : I was still being held back a bit in overall performance due to my CPU an AMD 8150 that would bottleneck such great CPU's; and using all 4 slots on my MOBO for ram with an AMD CPU is a no-go idea for performance; as I had 16 gigs of G.Skill ripjaws. - despite this I finished that play, and finally decided to play it with a non "Vernon Roche" chapter 2 (yeah I was stubborn, I always intedned on the next play being the completely different chapter 2 but had to keep going with Vernon Roche's ideals as it felt like who I was as a player, and the Geralt I wanted to play as. I upgraded my CPU to an AMD 9370 8 core liquid cooled at 5.0GHz, and grabbed 2x8GB G.Skill Trident X's with very low (fast) timings and higher over-all speed of the ram and saw amazing boosts in all my benchmarks; and Played thru-once more. I began a playthru again; just completing all but one of the interrogation flashbacks with Vernon Roche - When I upgraded my SLI 780's to SLI 780 ti's (Each Nvidia GPUs mentioned have been the MSI Manufactured versions). The 780 Ti being the fastest GPU ever created with 1GHz faster memory speed per card than the prior "OC Gaming Edition" 780's I had, and 800 more Cuda cores amongst other very impressive improvments.- Having a 144hz monitor with Nivida G-Sync Kit attached in and working (the asus 144hz Nvidia 3D Vision 2.0 / Nvidia lightboost 24 inch monitor came G-Sync kit ready 6 months prior to G-Sync being announced; I am glad this was the monitor I purchased back then; I was dissapointed when I read about G-Sync specific monitors then elated when I saw this was the only current monitor that was G-Sync Upgradable.- For the most recent play-through I contacted Nvidia for a G-Sync kit; used a phillips head on the back of the monitor and easily plugged in the chip (has a nice clear and labled spot for it to just plug right in) It's hard to even describe the difference until you actually groove with it and see / play with it yourself! My PC is totally ready for Geralt's Finale in the gaming franchise (I have yet to read the original books that the games are based)With many RPG's coming out for each platform; I had a huge J-RPG crush during the SNES-PSX era; Highlights being FF2 cartridge(FF4)-FF3 Cartridge(FF6) and the reason I purchased a PSX for the timeless Final Fantasy Vii, The dissapointing FF8 comes to mind as I forced myself to play it due to hype and having it pre-ordered the same date the Dreamcast was released on 9-9-99, and then despite having amazing adventures on my PC With Baldurs Gate 1-2, Planescape Torment etc - I gave Final Fantasy IX a chance which blew me away and was able to give Square another chance in my book; for the awful FF8; releasing a rather fantastic and "Interesting FF9" - Still J-RPG's forced linerality which defenders proclaim "It's about the story" (It seems these defenders have never played PLANESCAPE TORMENT or Baldurs Gate 2 The Witcher 1 suffered SOME gameplay and combat elements for an excellent story; Dragon Age Origins and The Witcher 2 had far superior stories than any J-RPG I've played without the lineraty style seen in J-RPG's, but thats a battle between fan's that  will never end as JRPG diehards assume any PC/Western RPG is an Elderscrolls style Open World Title with very poor story (Although Morrowind <3 <3 had a rather excellent story; despite the shallow characters that Bethesda still continues on with) - Perhaps the Witcher 2: Enhanced Edition release on The Xbox 9800 or whatever (Atari Jaguar 720 etc) was an excellent wake up call to many console Atari Joystick gamers; they got to finally experience our 2011 GOTY / RPG of the year; which then was a GOTY candidate and RPG of the year winner again in 2012 due to the Enhanced Edition console release (Confusing indeed.) which brought more revenue and spotlight towards the wonderful minded CDProjektRED; without that occuring and having TW3 be multi-platform (WITH PC as the Ultimate Intended platform still; partnering with Nvidia for hardware owning only options that are mindblowing in the Press Conference highlighting them all by Nvidia <3) - Then perhaps TW3 would not have been on the cover of Game Informer pumping up people who perhaps didn't even notice the 360 version on store shelves as "Skyrzrimz" is all they've ever heard of in the Role-Playing Game Format; or "Falloutz" Not that these titles have anything wrong with them The general public just murders anything excellent with their subpar Console versions while being blown away by the graphics (I saw skyrim on a friends 360 and threw up in my mouth a little)-I was sent a promo copy of the 360 version to review due to CDPR knowing my love for The White Wolf and his awesome adventures, I grabbed a 360 and blasted through the 360 form of the title which seemed to have pushed the console to its limits and then some, arguably the best looking 360 title to date - I was happy gamers who settle with 8 year old hardware could enjoy TW2 on Less than Medium PC settings!-Now with The Wicther 3's release looming; my PC being ready for the game to run smooth on Ultra; I cannot wait to be immersed completely rec. footage via Nvidia Shadowplay & Twitch.TV No Death Ruleset streams; with SLI 780 ti's prepared for all the Nvidia exclusive hardware graphical / immersive implementations that will not be possible with the "Next Gen hardware from 2010" consoles but when I shut up and think about it, Atleast more people are still experiencing TW2 and will experience TW3 (even if it is subpar to the build we'll be pre-ordering here on Steam). Geralt The Riv. Geralt of Rivia, The White Wolf.We have more adventures in store for us.

												Rating slayer! 10/10 Pros:-Really well crafted story which has you make choices that have a large effect on the games story- increases immersion and replayability -There are some really good voice acting work in this game -The world has a lot of places to explore and interesting lore-Characters are believable and fun to talk to -The game still looks greatPro/Con (some players will like it and some wont):-Combat is hard and has you thinking a lot about each encounterCons:Can't really think of anyThis is a great RPG and I would recommend this to anyone who is looking for an RPG, great story, and a world to explore. content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												Very in depth, great title, worth replaying 3 times if necessary to conjure up different endings, setting up the Witcher 3. Controls are tight using the 360 gamepad, combat could be described as well timed button mashing, while everything else is very responsive. Having 27 hours for my first playthrough, this was a great purchase during the steam summer sales. Story is well written, with a variety of interesting characters (featuring a badass intro movie) and with the inclusion of choices that changes the outcome of the story dramatically. The Witcher does a good job of explaining what happened prior to the events of the game with the exception of some names and such (being a newb to the series it's hard to keep up with names). And finally, the graphics are soo damn pretty, I spent a great deal of time admiring the art direction and landscapes of the various HUBS and feilds. 11/10 would play again (after I finish the original), done.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												Is the game good? Yes. It's a flawed gem of a game and one that could well have been one of the best RPG's ever made, if it wasn't for one thing: the combat. The combat is either shallow and dreadfully easy on "Easy", or absolutely impossible on "Normal". "Normal" is really hard mode and they need another difficulty in-between.Putting that aside, pretty much everything else in the game is good. Graphically it looks very pretty when maxed out for a game this old. Having never played Witcher 1, I found it's not very beginner friendly with regards to the story - but then I kind of expected that anyway. Nevertheless, if you have not played the previous game, expect to be confused... a lot. When you finally get your head round it you will find it has significant depth and is highly engaging.Your companions all have back stories of their own and they are well fleshed out. Not many games have had me caring for characters I have only spent a minimal amount of time with in game, but this one got me!The RPG elements are solid and allow for quite a bit of customisation. It has an interesting potion mechanic, based on your "toxicity level", so you can't just swig every potion you have before a fight.So, all in all, it's a good game. It could have been brilliant if a few issues were resolved. Regardless of which, it has made me want to get Witcher 3 this February, so consider me hooked!Jimbo Rating: 7/10

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												Hmm, again the Steam recommendation system provokes thought. This isn't a great game, it's a good one. It has numerous flaws. Ridiculous boss fights (thank goodness for easy mode), stupid missions with auto fail conditions (I nearly was reduced to tears by one idiotic sequence where you had to follow someone through a greyscale cave where the mission was restarted if you put one foot wrong), display and path finding glitches, and a bizarre plot that lost me some time ago. But it also has much goodness - smashing combat, once you figure out you have to roll a lot, stunning visuals, a fantastic main character and decent supporting cast, including several strong female characters - don't be deceived by the pandering to teenage boys with the top heavy character models. There is action aplenty and a reasonable amount of exploration to do, however I feel it didn't live up to it's predecessor and it does feel curiously amateurish in places. I really have no idea how this devteam is going to pull off something as ambitious as Witcher 3, but I'll certainly be playing it. Recommended? Yes, but with the caveat that the game is deeply flawed and a definite slog at times.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												Well, I played The Witcher 1 a little bit, a few hours and eventually dropped it not because I didn't like the story because I did but because the combat was really, really boring and well, there was quite a lot of it so it was hard to avoid it, especially in RPG games.Moving on, The Witcher 2 got released, didn't play at launch but a few years later I decided to give it a shot. It is so much better than the first game in my opinion. The story, the gameplay, graphics and most especially, combat, they're all better.Now, the game itself is not THAT huge as you might think it is. At first glance it does seem so but after finishing it you realize it's really not. Nevertheless, that doesn't mean there aren't things to do. There's plenty of side quests, lore to explore, books to read (I think, didn't touch them that much), monsters to slay and yeah, you get a lot of content, especially for the lowered up prices you can find right now.I really recommend this game because CDProjekt really nailed it.Get it m9s ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
												Really, really solid Action-RPG. The story is engrossing, full of well-developed characters and locales. Many choices are made throughout the game, and all of them feel like a moral shade of grey, being much more interesting than the good-or-evil binary in some other games. The game feels like it covers only a small section of a much larger canvas, and it is always obvious that important events are happening around Geralt and company. The world feels alive and lived-in, and there are many small details that draw you in. NPCs gather in town centers and taverns and banter between each other. Some of the dialog ends up repeated if you stick around one area too long, but it is written well and does not become grating. Creature design is good, and some of the larger ones are very intimidating. Monsters in the wild form packs and hunt and attack other monsters (and you).The combat in this game is good, but not great. Most fights can be either rushed down quickly or kited around, getting in a few hits at a time. Strong attacks seem more effective than fast attacks almost all of the time, and I sorely missed the "group" attacks from the first game. The signs are useful to varying degrees. I found myself using Quen, Aard, and Yrden signs fairly often, but Igni and Axii signs were hardly ever used. Preparing for combat by drinking potions and using sword oils is very important, especially for more challenging fights. For some reason, you cannot lock on to bosses, but the camera is still cooperative and not too much of a pain to manage.The inventory system is streamlined from the first game, and is less of a chore to manage.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2013
												The Witcher 2 is indeed a title that needs to be experienced by every single RPG fan out there; however bear in mind that this title does carry a PEGI age restriction of 18, and is not suited for anyone below this age limit. As stated before, this is not just because of the nudity or the graphic violence, but due to the fact that The Witcher 2 has an in-depth storyline that covers a diverse range of political and racial aspects, which allows it to be the spectacular mature title that it is.When it comes to lasting appeal, The Witcher 2 will take between 30 to 40 hours to complete, depending on your skill level and whether you partake in various side-quests. If you have not picked up a copy of the Witcher 2, I can highly recommend it wether on sale or full price, it's worth every penny of your cash.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2016
												I started this game a few days ago and unlike the first witcher game where I could dump hours at a time, this one feels like a chore to play for a number of reasons. 1. Combat.  The combat isn't hard, it's cheesy. It's impossible to lock on to a target, there is no sword stances like the first Witcher and you die extremely quick in any difficulty and there were fights early on where the only option I could find was to exploit the AI programming. There's a fight with 10-15 creatures(you have no aoe and can't agro only one at a time) in act one and if you dive into them they will gather around you and you just die with no ability to escape(Fair enough, realism... BUT the only way I found to do this fight after multiple attempts is fight them one at a time at the limit of their programmed agro range. 2. Map and NPC's. I can't find f*%$ing♥♥♥♥♥♥even when it's marked and NPC's that have valuable items you need to buy for quests are no where to be found. I resorted to googling a lot of quest locations and even then couldn't find a lot of them.  3. Menu. the UI is god awful and is a chore to navigate around. 4. Boss fight. My first bossfight I died a dozen times just trying to figure out what to do and how to execute it, this isn't Dark Souls FFS. Finally when I got through phase 1 (yay) a f%%king rock just drops out of the sky onto my head killing me. I died a handful more times in phase 2 trying to figure out what I was suppose to do, walk up to the boss, instantly die, run around, rocks kill you. 5. Dumb mini games. They are boring, clunky and again feel like a chore to play. The first witcher was more fun throwing dice in.5/10 would not reccomend.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												The Witcher was a fantastic game. For some reason, the devs felt like they had to change the combat system and slow down the pacing of the sequel. I am sure the control changes were to appeal to the console market, and it was a big mistake. It completely ruins the game. Not only the controls overly complex and counterintuitive, but they are made worse by a very steep difficulty curve. This combined with the lack of clarity in the storytelling and what is far and away the worst menu system I have ever seen in a game and you wind up with a disappointing shadow of what could have been. I love the story and really wanted to experience it in its entirety, but could not do so due to the game's awful controls, terrible pacing and confusing menus. Also, as much as I like dialogue heavy games, this one overdoes it. Too much of a good thing. I can't count the number of times I've wished an npc would just shut up already. When you can sit down in a game for an hour or two and accomplish nothing, something is very wrong.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												Really damn good game overall. Good graphics, a great mature story and setting, gameplay is astronomically better than Witcher 1. That being said the combat while a million times better than the game before is still lacking, but its cons are outweighed by the pros of having to use intelligent decision-making to prepare for fights which is something that is completely missing from almost all modern RPG lately.Remember when you had to drink that potion of fire resistance so you could fight that dragon in Skyrim? Or you had to keep a stash of holy water so you could fight vampires? Me neither.In Witcher if you do not prepare to fight monsters like a Witcher you will fail miserably, and rightly so for thats what sets apart Witchers from just really juiced up monster slayers.The game does suffer from trying to be too cinematic, but fortunately this is only for the Prologue. Its recommended that you play Witcher 1 before playing this but you really don't need to as Witcher 1 can be a bit of a chore to play.I would argue that the most important aspect of this game is the mature story, if you are not very into story driven gameplay then I cannot recommend this to you.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2013
												The Witcher 2 is a prime example of how an RPG SHOULD be made.  No morality meters, no light side or dark side, and an extremely non-linear storyline that changes each time you play through the game.  You MUST play this game on DARK difficulty to really get the full experience of the Witcher 2.  Why?  Because if you play on anything below you won't get the full Witcher feel.  I played through the first time on Normal and never used traps, alchemy, or bombs at all.  In Dark difficulty you must use EVERYTHING at your disposal to defeat monsters and your enemies.  Dark is what the game intends you to play at.  You must read up on monsters before you go face them, learn their strengths and weaknesses, and defeat them by the skin of your teeth.  Although not a perfect game the Witcher 2 is a masterfully made game that inspires you to play through it again and again.  If you've ever played an RPG you MUST play the Witcher 2!  It's a thrill ride and extremely immersive.  The Witcher 3 has become my most anticipated game of 2014 thanks to this game and the first.I have to give this game an 8/10.  I would give it a 9.5 but the third Act of the game and the ending I felt were a bit weak.  Regardless this is one of the pen-ultimate RPGs ever constructed in gaming.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												I'm playing the Witcher series backwards - started with 3 and then 2, and currently in the process of playing 1, so I am somewhat spoiled by Witcher 3's incredible gameplay and story and voice acting.The gameplay in 2 is ok, but I didn't like the fact that you needed to take your potions *before* heading in to a fight. Sometimes you don't know you're heading for one, so I missed the opportunity a few times. Compared to 1, the skill tree and meditation practices are much easier, but compared to 3, they're a little complicated. I like the improvements in 3.The storyline was very good, the voice acting was pretty decent - a great improvement over 1, but not quite up to par with 3. Perhaps I shouldn't be comparing, but it's hard not to.Overall I enjoyed this game. It was hard at times, trying to figure out what spells or combat should be used on a boss, but challenging. It was good to get more background to the whole Witcher series story. 7/10

Posted: July 3, 2015
												After messing around with the tutorial and prologue, I never truly gave the Witcher much of a chance. It appeared to have a deep story and well-developed setting, but I didn't particularly enjoy the combat with a keyboard and mouse. Returning with an Xbox 360 controller, I now find the combat thoroughly enjoyable. The controls take some time to learn, but the combat is fair and requires thought (unless playing on easy). I am at the start of Chapter 2 and have officially become hooked on the Witcher universe. This has been one of my most enjoyable playthroughs this years. I greatly look forward to continuing the story in Witcher 3. If you are a fan of fantasy, adventure RPGs and clever dialogue, then I highly recommend the Witcher 2 Enhanced Edition.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2013
												Witcher 2 inspires awe, every game you play after you finish this game is a slight dissapointment. The story in this game has so many different choices and endings it feels like a different game everytime you choose a different path. The graphics are unreal and beat everything realeased, even today, the animations and voice acting is superb and the sounds are so clear and music is amazing and it fits really well into the dark fantasy world. There are some memorable tracks to this game which have made their way into my playlists.The combat style is not different from most rpg's, hack and slash, magic spells (called signs) and potions. Some people say it came out as half baked, but I love it and it really gets you to think about your stategy, especially against large groups of enemies. The constanting rolling around that you ahve to do to avoid enemy attacks is rather tiresome, as blocking is ineffective against many different enemies. The different skill trees are all very well balanced and each skill impacts combat and how you play big time. The drawback with the alchemy system is that potions can only be consumed outside of combat, so constantly saving before entering a new room is advisable, so it is possible to reload without worrying if you have lost a large portionof time spent doing quests. The main protagonist, Geralt of Rivia is a badass monster slayer who you just love form first sight (much like his hot girlfriend Triss!!). And the most hyped up and important part of the game, the story is written and directed like a AAA movie title, only ten times better! Going through the prologue is like watching Game of Thrones, it is awesome.This game also utilises Witcher 1 saves so all the different choices and descisions you made in that, impact your Witcher 2 game! The story's allusions to the whole witcher univerrse allow you to roleplay the witcher effectively, but the main plot pulls Geralt out of his main profession, he turns away from his witchering throughout much of the main plot, with only a few quests showing off his full monster hunting aspect. This game is magnificent, it is a visual feast and contains a plot which constantly twists and turns and gets you to think long and hard about decisions you make over your favourite characters.Overall - 99/100 Must play!

content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												By far one of the best games I've played. It has it's problems, but they don't take away from the game enough to ruin the experience in any meaningful manner. It has a slight old school feel to it as well, which I liked very much. Feels good to die over and over and over again in a game like this for a change as well :) You get to solve how to beat the game, learn it, and then finally beat it when you've figured it out, which reminded me of some good games from the past. Way past, that is... This game also respects the players intelligence and maturity, and won't try to hand you everything sugar coated.And then there's the story, and the different branches of it. It definitely surprised me how much of a difference your choice might make in the game! It won't make it obvious either, so if you don't play the game again, or check the differences on a video, you have no idea what the changes are, how big they are, and how much they affect your playthrough. Certainly recommended for anyone interested in fantasy, rpg, good story, or just a good gaming experience.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												This was the best RPG of 2011, and for me, 2013 as well. After two complete playthroughs to get the full story, I believe this is the most well written story in a fantasy RPG to date. The combat is also a joy once you get the hang of it's initially unintuitive style. Witcher 2 is more narrative heavy than most action RPGs, but that's what brought me back for a second full play. Two years later the graphics are still striking to behold at times. This game is definitely not for everyone, especially if you get bored with long story sequences. Passive or casual gamers will quickly get lost in the narrative. It was the most enjoyable RPG played by me the year it came out, and I was hard pressed to claim an equal this past year when I played a second time.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												The Witcher 2 is unlike any rpg that came before, because of one word only "story." The witcher 2 might not offer a open world but what it does offer is a great story. Have you ever been lured in to a rpg with them saying "choice will change your game." Well, The witcher delivers in aces, not only will your choice change the future, but where you are in the world and the people you meet. Sure the're are set pieces and story character you have to meet, but i found they always had something new to say or a new quest for you to do. The choices witcher 2 supplies has you picking from one evil or another evil, with no one being greater than the other. You don't gain lightside or darkside points, you just are the way you chose. Combat is pretty straight forward, you have a sliver sword that kills monsters and a iron sword to kill humans. Potions can be consumed before a fight to say increase your ability to dodge incoming attacks or see in the dark. Geralt of rivia has large skill tree, and each point you put it makes you feel stronger, wither it be strength, wisdom, or alchemy. Geralt the character you lead through this adventure is a anti-hero to a T. Geralt's profession is monster slaying, with a bit of humans on the side. All and all I enjoyed the game, set paths and hand holding hurt the opening, but what is to follow is indeed a rpg to be had. P.S with your steam purchase you also get the game "DRM free" from Good Old Games website as well.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
												Picked it up for € 3.99 on special offer and boy, was that a deal. People talk about "the graphics", but that's the wrong term actually. Yes, the 3D engine is good for a 2011 game, but what really blows your mind is the LEVEL DESIGN. Screenshots don't do it justice since you really have to experience the diversity & complexity of the world hands-on. The entire visual design of the game is just so masterfully done that I don't even mind the fact that it regularly crosses the threshold of kitsch I can tolerate. Especially the sex scenes could do with a little less stilted moaning & catwalk moves, and instead some more teasing & creativity in general.So while I'm recounting the downers here's the rest of them:- Animations (doors, climbing, taking/dealing damage etc.) sometimes lock other movement annoyingly long. Especially casting sometimes gets locked for no apparent reason, so I end up standing like a dork in the middle of battle while hitting the cast button until it finally happens.- Male characters are quite well done, both visually, substantually and vocally. They are diverse and relate to the world in a meaningful manner. Female characters however seem generally a little more shallow. There are very few meaningful female roles, and all female characters in the game seem to fit a much more narrow blueprint. They look more alike, they act more similar, heck, they even seem to be all the same age. It's like somebody wanted all the women to fit a particular stereotype of "hotness" which gets boring very quickly (I still like Triss though, but she's about the only deep female NPC).Other than that I really can't think of any more downsides to this game, so since the ups have been discussed in other reviews extensively, it should be clear that this is a SUPER-awesome ARPG.

content:
Posted: January 8
Rank: 8.5/10Recommendation(s): Play another Witcher title before (The Witcher 1)Major Theme: Slightly sluggish, but a great mix between 1 and 3.Bought at Price: $2.75 - Steam SaleI honestly thought I was going to have enough will power to play the Witcher series in order, but that turned out to be not the case. The first title turned out to be so dry; it was equivalent to having a dry mouth, being dragged face down in a desert for kilometers. There was a serious lack of humor, but the combat system proved to be greatly overhauled. While the system having its own new issues, made gameplay more pleasant than the machine like structure of the first.Graphics are vastly enhanced from the first, but still do not compare anywhere close to that of the third (and last?) Witcher title. Maybe that’s why they called it the “enhanced edition”. On that note, I cannot describe the difference between the two editions, as I have not played the original release.While the story was logical, and easy to follow, was a little let down. By no means was it horrible or not worth playing, it just again lacked humor. At some points in the game, you will find yourself playing a part just to move the story along (which felt very much like the first game in the series).I probably will not be replaying this title as I will be doing with the 3rd, but that should be no judge of quality.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2016
												Note: You do not need to have played the first game in the series to play this. Many people turn it away due to it´s poor graphic quality. I say give it a go. If you can´t stand "old style" games you will however easily get immersed into The Witcher 2.  CD PROJEKT RED has brought Andrzej Sapkowski´s novels to life. I am 100% certain no other company could have done it as marvelous as they have. (Yes I have read all the books.) You are in for a real adventure with this one. If you are into linear RPG style games + Some added optional quests in each zone. The optional quests sometimes yeilds something you can always use as examples - Potion recipes, a treasure map, a book with useful information about some of the creatures you are battling or they can have some information about known characters. Then there´s the lustful side to Geralt. Sometimes you will be awarded sex with very graphic imagery and profanity. It´s a adult game so of course adult situations will occur.This is not your usual RPG -  You will come to love Geralt whether you´re a guy or a girl. The witcher 2 is a wast game with many memorable characters and monsters that you will meet on your quest to find out who the Assassins of Kings is. The game is divided into three acts each with their own unique environment. This is truly a epic game that deserves all the awards it has won. You will need to play through the game more than once (or watch a youtuber) play as in all RPG´s your decision has in impact in the world. Each decision needs to be considered as you will not know how it will impact the story ahead. One question that might seem insignificent can have a very big impact further on. I have played this game for many hours searching and discovering hidden caves with monsters or a tomb with a treasure chest. If you are not customed with this sort of game don´t go Hard mode and make yourself frustrated resulting in you not wanting to play anymore, however if you are up for a challange go ahead, there are so many magnificent encounters and I do believe playing them for the first time on Hard and not giving up will really reward you it will get your adrenaline pumping when you have just beaten a hard encounter.          Gameplay        10/10             Story        9/10    [/tr]         Graphics        10/10 for it´s release year                Combat        7/10

												First let me say The Witcher 2 is an incredible game that should not be missed by any fan of the RPG genre. The goods are as follows-Great combat that combines magic, swordplay, and crafting very effectively-Excellent story that's well written-Good voice actingThe cons are as follows-Bad map system. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												Geralt of Rivia has returned, and with warm welcome. The Witcher series is becoming one of my favorites within my list of fictional sagas, and this game certainly delivers on all fronts.Assassins of Kings pulls no punches. It starts off with an incredibly beautiful CGI introduction that rivals even the best studios. Once you start the game, you're thrown right into war, and the rollercoaster ride hasn't even reached the first hill at this point. Geralt's adventures are plentiful - every quest, whether tied into the main questline or just a trivial matter, fits within the world and doesn't feel disjointed or forced. The graphics are certainly a huge step up from the original, and still hold up well as of this review (May 2015). I have a AMD 7970 3gb card, and still can't even run this game on 'true' max settings - mind you, the only thing holding me back is the 'Ubersampling' option, which looks unreal, but cuts framerate to a halt on most systems. It's reserved for the 'best of the best' and not many can run it, even today. Aside from that setting, the Witcher II is still beautiful in every respect. The coastline city of Flotsam feels salty and dirty. The nearby marshes displays a sticky, dense fog that utters caution within the unknown. Details such as these are scattered throughout, and you'll never find yourself tired of the eye candy.For those who played the original, the combat is a huge breath of fresh air in comparison. Gone is the timed left clicking jumbled mess, replaced by real time combat. You can light attack, heavy attack, or block/riposte. That's it. Despite this well-needed change, however, the fighting can get rather intense, especially on harder difficulties (I played on Dark). Dodge (basically roll) is your best friend. You will find yourself rolling out of harm's way so often, it's not even funny. Roll or die, that's about what it comes down to. 95% roll, 5% swordfighting. Apparently Sonic the Hedgehog is Geralt's spirit animal. All the original Signs are back - Aard, Yrden, Quen, Igni, and Axii. In this game, Quen is your best friend. It will save your life countless times - my advice is to invest in upgrading it early. That said, there is a simple yet effective skill tree for Geralt's Signs and other abilities, split into four parts - Training, Swordsmanship, Signs, and Alchemy. Allocate points to the playstyle you like - you'll typically never level them all, so choose wisely. Briefly touching on loot here - swords and armor are much more plentiful than the first game, which is nice. However those who import Witcher 1 saves will find that their imported content won't last long until a trade in, which is disappointing, especially with one particular weapon you acquire from the first game that its storyline seemed to hold in high regard.The story is certainly good, and not too over the top (well, aside from a detail or two). Geralt's choices have much weight in this game, and you'll find more impactful choices than in the first iteration. Also included are various ways to get information in the dialogue options - persuasion (Axii), intimidation, and so forth. I'm not sure if its based on your current skills or a random number roll, but its a fun take on the 'click to ask X question' bit.My only real gripe with this game, other than the occasional dodgy combat roll, is the Steam achievements. The game practically forces you to play twice to get absolutely every achievement. 100%'ers, beware. The insane mode alone is risky - one death and your save games become null and void. Overall, this is an tremendously enjoyable sequel. Not as long as the first, but it has depth and production quality. Definitely worth a playthrough or two! (Note: This game has 'something after the credits'. Stick with it!)

content:
Posted: June 6, 2015
												The Witcher 2 is a vast improvement over its predecessor, and, as the franchise is known for, has many new and variable tropes for a Fantasy RPG game. To highlight some of the game's best features, The Witcher 2's combat is reminiscent of Batman: Arkham Asylum, but requires far greater skill and preparation. I'm not new to Action-RPG's by any means, but I found the first half of the game very challenging and new to grasp, which is a good thing. The combat is by far the most enjoyable, compelling, intense, and straight forward experience I've had in a while, and for the first time, the magic, enchanting, and alchemy systems aren't overly convaluted.The story of The Witcher 2 is dark and riviting, and is filled with lots of mystery, political strife, and several player-driven decisions during major events. The only complaint is that the game takes too fondly to the objectification of most, if not all, of it's female characters. I won't get into detail, but if you're ok with that, then I highly recommend playing The Witcher 2 for a new Action-Adventure-RPG experience.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												The Witcher 2, is my favorite game of all time. Here is why:When you first get into this game, one of the most incredibly made cinematics bids you welcome to the world and story. I am amazed that a small company like CDPR (used to be) could possibly deliever one of the most beautiful PC titles of all time, even in 2014. But these guys did it right. With a huge focus on story and it's characters, this game slowly opens up for a world that has so much more depth and feel to it than many other AAA open world games. This world has the advantage on being based on a great bookseries and a having a company behind it, that has the best intentions for everything that is behind it.It can be confusing to begin with, but without a doubt fully playable, without having played the first installment of the series. The mechanics can be a little clunky, and the developers have been forced to limit the world to big explorable areas instead of making it truly open world. But it works out for this game - Simply because everything you CAN do, is so incredibly detailed and perfected in every way. The lore and story is absolutely amazing and along with a great soundtrack and mindblowing visuals, it adds up to be the very best game I've ever played.I write this review after completing the game several times, on each difficulty and gathering all achievements. It is extremely challenging in beginning, but in this game, preperation and strategy, is highly rewarded. This is what makes this game so different and so much better from other games:- Choices matter. The choices you make can change the story completely. There's actually two completely seperated chapters based only one single choice in the game. It makes everything so much more interesting.- Everything is means something. There's no generic sides quests, like you know it from Skyrim and WoW. There's a lot of content, but they are all well thought out. You won't be forced to gather resources for hours - It will make sense in the end.- The story is so rich and incredibly well put together. Unlike many other RPGs, you don't get to costumize your character, but also means that the story becomes much more personal, mature and interesting. - The world, based on a book franchise, that I have now read, because of my love of the game gives this game a huge advantage. The lore is deep and detailed and CDPR has truly taken care of this in the best way possibly. This game also features some of the best soundtracks I know of.I am incredibly excited for The Witcher 3. And I believe that, to be the only game to ever beat this. That experience will show a truly open world, with a much bigger budget and therefore, far fewer limits. The simple fact, that the main story is around 50 hours long, says a lot about how important the story is in this franchise. I would recommend anyone who want to play Witcher 3: The Wild Hunt, to begin here. It'll give you a wonderful time, and prepare you for the third installment. I like the first game as well, but I think it might be a little too outdated by now. TL;DR: If you want to be a medieval jedi knight, you should play this game. And who doesn't want to be a medieval jedi knight? Seriously?

content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
												Picked it up for € 3.99 on special offer and boy, was that a deal. People talk about "the graphics", but that's the wrong term actually. Yes, the 3D engine is good for a 2011 game, but what really blows your mind is the LEVEL DESIGN. Screenshots don't do it justice since you really have to experience the diversity & complexity of the world hands-on. The entire visual design of the game is just so masterfully done that I don't even mind the fact that it regularly crosses the threshold of kitsch I can tolerate. Especially the sex scenes could do with a little less stilted moaning & catwalk moves, and instead some more teasing & creativity in general.So while I'm recounting the downers here's the rest of them:- Animations (doors, climbing, taking/dealing damage etc.) sometimes lock other movement annoyingly long. Especially casting sometimes gets locked for no apparent reason, so I end up standing like a dork in the middle of battle while hitting the cast button until it finally happens.- Male characters are quite well done, both visually, substantually and vocally. They are diverse and relate to the world in a meaningful manner. Female characters however seem generally a little more shallow. There are very few meaningful female roles, and all female characters in the game seem to fit a much more narrow blueprint. They look more alike, they act more similar, heck, they even seem to be all the same age. It's like somebody wanted all the women to fit a particular stereotype of "hotness" which gets boring very quickly (I still like Triss though, but she's about the only deep female NPC).Other than that I really can't think of any more downsides to this game, so since the ups have been discussed in other reviews extensively, it should be clear that this is a SUPER-awesome ARPG.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												The Witcher 2 is unlike any rpg that came before, because of one word only "story." The witcher 2 might not offer a open world but what it does offer is a great story. Have you ever been lured in to a rpg with them saying "choice will change your game." Well, The witcher delivers in aces, not only will your choice change the future, but where you are in the world and the people you meet. Sure the're are set pieces and story character you have to meet, but i found they always had something new to say or a new quest for you to do. The choices witcher 2 supplies has you picking from one evil or another evil, with no one being greater than the other. You don't gain lightside or darkside points, you just are the way you chose. Combat is pretty straight forward, you have a sliver sword that kills monsters and a iron sword to kill humans. Potions can be consumed before a fight to say increase your ability to dodge incoming attacks or see in the dark. Geralt of rivia has large skill tree, and each point you put it makes you feel stronger, wither it be strength, wisdom, or alchemy. Geralt the character you lead through this adventure is a anti-hero to a T. Geralt's profession is monster slaying, with a bit of humans on the side. All and all I enjoyed the game, set paths and hand holding hurt the opening, but what is to follow is indeed a rpg to be had. P.S with your steam purchase you also get the game "DRM free" from Good Old Games website as well.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2013
												The Witcher 2 is the much anticipated sequel to the original The Witcher. Featuring a brand new engine, intense combat and a returning cast of characters.As much as I like this game there are fairly pronounced flaws if you were a player like me, who went through the original game. Everyone except Geralt got a new voice actor, and as a result everyone feels really different for some reason. Alongside that, importing your saved game from the original is very pointless. Your magical swords and unbendable armor that previously saw you through massacring armies of enemies, now has you selling it for the first new bit of equipment. Not only that but a lot of your choices simply do not carry over. In the original game for instance Geralt could choose to romance another girl instead of Triss named Shany. Who replaced Triss from then on in the story and was just as important. You could also choose to side with the Squirrels, who start out in this game wanting to murder you despite whatever import you might have had.Aside from this the game is perfectly flawless, your choices are very pronounced and your consequences very real. I just wish the game had a bit more perspective on where it came from and where it was going.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												Really damn good game overall. Good graphics, a great mature story and setting, gameplay is astronomically better than Witcher 1. That being said the combat while a million times better than the game before is still lacking, but its cons are outweighed by the pros of having to use intelligent decision-making to prepare for fights which is something that is completely missing from almost all modern RPG lately.Remember when you had to drink that potion of fire resistance so you could fight that dragon in Skyrim? Or you had to keep a stash of holy water so you could fight vampires? Me neither.In Witcher if you do not prepare to fight monsters like a Witcher you will fail miserably, and rightly so for thats what sets apart Witchers from just really juiced up monster slayers.The game does suffer from trying to be too cinematic, but fortunately this is only for the Prologue. Its recommended that you play Witcher 1 before playing this but you really don't need to as Witcher 1 can be a bit of a chore to play.I would argue that the most important aspect of this game is the mature story, if you are not very into story driven gameplay then I cannot recommend this to you.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												Just finished The Witcher 2 and I got to admit it's like it tries to be both a RPG and a VN, yet fails (as I see it) to be either. I guess that's just because I like my RPGs to be action RPGs and my VN be no action (in the sense of text and choiced only, nothing else). Yet I will recommend it for I suppose it's not that the game is bad, it's that I wanted not the things this game has to offer me and it's kind of my fault for not having thought this through.The fights are either too short (too few enemies) or either too hard (too strong enemies) the only fun being those fought when approaching the Harpies nests and on the Vergen's walls. Oh! And no experience for you, level up via the quests only, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ (well, you technically can gain 2-3 levels by fighting during the game, but you have to fight loads of monsters, more than the game actually gives you. And you will not get the exp for them after some time, so no grinding for ya). The loot is poor and you are poor as the Price/Sell ratio is like x5, more for better items (buy for 2500, sell for 100, yeah, right. Or the crafting! Buy a recipe for 100 gold, buy ingridients for 150 gold + pay 20 gold to craft a subart... which you can buy for like 25 gold. Why, again?). Do I have to mention the horribly sluggish system of potions, alchemy, crafting, trading and menus in general? I had to ggole how to switch off the mouse smoothening (there is not a single PC player happy with mouse acceleration/deceleration)The "VN" element is... well it's not bad in and of itself, yet the differences in the endings are minute and the dialogue is diluted by the need to fight - or just run around - in between. So I won't be playing it through again, not in the nearest half a year, at least, I see no reason to. Fun is heavily diluted. For me at least.What an irony, but for the aforementioned combination the game might have been actually fun for me. Like if the action RPG elements were to be enhanced and stripped off of all the dialogue nonsense OR if the VN elements (well it's kind of R part of the RPG, so you should give them credit for that) were to be enhanced with meaningful differencies in endings and without the need to have to fight 2-3 enemies in between (come on, 500 enemies slain only after playing for good 30 hours?)But I assume all the modern "story rich" RPGs are in some way like that (ME, DE, whatever else). Or am I mistaken and the fighting system and other "action" elements of an RPG in those are fine?All in all I suppose personally I should have picked the Skyrim instead. Or Diablo 3, still haven't played but for its Demo.

Posted: July 3, 2015
												After messing around with the tutorial and prologue, I never truly gave the Witcher much of a chance. It appeared to have a deep story and well-developed setting, but I didn't particularly enjoy the combat with a keyboard and mouse. Returning with an Xbox 360 controller, I now find the combat thoroughly enjoyable. The controls take some time to learn, but the combat is fair and requires thought (unless playing on easy). I am at the start of Chapter 2 and have officially become hooked on the Witcher universe. This has been one of my most enjoyable playthroughs this years. I greatly look forward to continuing the story in Witcher 3. If you are a fan of fantasy, adventure RPGs and clever dialogue, then I highly recommend the Witcher 2 Enhanced Edition.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
												Picked it up for € 3.99 on special offer and boy, was that a deal. People talk about "the graphics", but that's the wrong term actually. Yes, the 3D engine is good for a 2011 game, but what really blows your mind is the LEVEL DESIGN. Screenshots don't do it justice since you really have to experience the diversity & complexity of the world hands-on. The entire visual design of the game is just so masterfully done that I don't even mind the fact that it regularly crosses the threshold of kitsch I can tolerate. Especially the sex scenes could do with a little less stilted moaning & catwalk moves, and instead some more teasing & creativity in general.So while I'm recounting the downers here's the rest of them:- Animations (doors, climbing, taking/dealing damage etc.) sometimes lock other movement annoyingly long. Especially casting sometimes gets locked for no apparent reason, so I end up standing like a dork in the middle of battle while hitting the cast button until it finally happens.- Male characters are quite well done, both visually, substantually and vocally. They are diverse and relate to the world in a meaningful manner. Female characters however seem generally a little more shallow. There are very few meaningful female roles, and all female characters in the game seem to fit a much more narrow blueprint. They look more alike, they act more similar, heck, they even seem to be all the same age. It's like somebody wanted all the women to fit a particular stereotype of "hotness" which gets boring very quickly (I still like Triss though, but she's about the only deep female NPC).Other than that I really can't think of any more downsides to this game, so since the ups have been discussed in other reviews extensively, it should be clear that this is a SUPER-awesome ARPG.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												This was the best RPG of 2011, and for me, 2013 as well. After two complete playthroughs to get the full story, I believe this is the most well written story in a fantasy RPG to date. The combat is also a joy once you get the hang of it's initially unintuitive style. Witcher 2 is more narrative heavy than most action RPGs, but that's what brought me back for a second full play. Two years later the graphics are still striking to behold at times. This game is definitely not for everyone, especially if you get bored with long story sequences. Passive or casual gamers will quickly get lost in the narrative. It was the most enjoyable RPG played by me the year it came out, and I was hard pressed to claim an equal this past year when I played a second time.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8
Rank: 8.5/10Recommendation(s): Play another Witcher title before (The Witcher 1)Major Theme: Slightly sluggish, but a great mix between 1 and 3.Bought at Price: $2.75 - Steam SaleI honestly thought I was going to have enough will power to play the Witcher series in order, but that turned out to be not the case. The first title turned out to be so dry; it was equivalent to having a dry mouth, being dragged face down in a desert for kilometers. There was a serious lack of humor, but the combat system proved to be greatly overhauled. While the system having its own new issues, made gameplay more pleasant than the machine like structure of the first.Graphics are vastly enhanced from the first, but still do not compare anywhere close to that of the third (and last?) Witcher title. Maybe that’s why they called it the “enhanced edition”. On that note, I cannot describe the difference between the two editions, as I have not played the original release.While the story was logical, and easy to follow, was a little let down. By no means was it horrible or not worth playing, it just again lacked humor. At some points in the game, you will find yourself playing a part just to move the story along (which felt very much like the first game in the series).I probably will not be replaying this title as I will be doing with the 3rd, but that should be no judge of quality.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												The Witcher 2, is my favorite game of all time. Here is why:When you first get into this game, one of the most incredibly made cinematics bids you welcome to the world and story. I am amazed that a small company like CDPR (used to be) could possibly deliever one of the most beautiful PC titles of all time, even in 2014. But these guys did it right. With a huge focus on story and it's characters, this game slowly opens up for a world that has so much more depth and feel to it than many other AAA open world games. This world has the advantage on being based on a great bookseries and a having a company behind it, that has the best intentions for everything that is behind it.It can be confusing to begin with, but without a doubt fully playable, without having played the first installment of the series. The mechanics can be a little clunky, and the developers have been forced to limit the world to big explorable areas instead of making it truly open world. But it works out for this game - Simply because everything you CAN do, is so incredibly detailed and perfected in every way. The lore and story is absolutely amazing and along with a great soundtrack and mindblowing visuals, it adds up to be the very best game I've ever played.I write this review after completing the game several times, on each difficulty and gathering all achievements. It is extremely challenging in beginning, but in this game, preperation and strategy, is highly rewarded. This is what makes this game so different and so much better from other games:- Choices matter. The choices you make can change the story completely. There's actually two completely seperated chapters based only one single choice in the game. It makes everything so much more interesting.- Everything is means something. There's no generic sides quests, like you know it from Skyrim and WoW. There's a lot of content, but they are all well thought out. You won't be forced to gather resources for hours - It will make sense in the end.- The story is so rich and incredibly well put together. Unlike many other RPGs, you don't get to costumize your character, but also means that the story becomes much more personal, mature and interesting. - The world, based on a book franchise, that I have now read, because of my love of the game gives this game a huge advantage. The lore is deep and detailed and CDPR has truly taken care of this in the best way possibly. This game also features some of the best soundtracks I know of.I am incredibly excited for The Witcher 3. And I believe that, to be the only game to ever beat this. That experience will show a truly open world, with a much bigger budget and therefore, far fewer limits. The simple fact, that the main story is around 50 hours long, says a lot about how important the story is in this franchise. I would recommend anyone who want to play Witcher 3: The Wild Hunt, to begin here. It'll give you a wonderful time, and prepare you for the third installment. I like the first game as well, but I think it might be a little too outdated by now. TL;DR: If you want to be a medieval jedi knight, you should play this game. And who doesn't want to be a medieval jedi knight? Seriously?

content:
Posted: August 24, 2012
												The Witcher 2 is an exemplarary sequel that manages to build upon the strengths of the Witcher 1, namely it's combat mechanics and plot twists, while addressing and improving on it's predecessor's flaws . An outstanding Role Playing Game, no two replays of this game will ever be the same. In the Witcher 2, you are thrust into the character of Geralt of Rivia, famed monster slayer and unintended savior of a king, where you must make the decisions that alter the fates of not only the protagonist but the world and its many characters about him. Its a compelling narrative about maintaining neutrality in a world that is morally ambiguous and deceptive. You will feel the sting of unintended consequences, and with a variety of supporting characters, all whose lives and motivations you will come to understand, decisions in this game are not made lightly . Aside from its storyline, the actual mechanics of the gameplay are superbly executed. Combat is visceral and tactical. Magic, Alchemy, and swordplay are your means of defeating your enemies, and the Witcher 2 introduces a menagerie containing all sorts of monsters, both fantastically gargantuan & sometimes human, whose strengths/weaknesses must be taken into account, especially on the hardest of difficulties. In the end, the Witcher 2 is a satisfying video game with a storyline that leaves it's impression upon you because of it's relation to your impact as Geralt. I'm optimistic about this franchise and look forward to future sequels.
