number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 19, 2015
The ConsipracyCD Project RED have sold their souls in exchange for creating perfect digital art.The Original ClassicI remember back then, when the first Witcher came out it was something refreshing, captivating, even good, but still it wasn’t spectacular, despite some people calling it a new best RPG. Among its great strengths in story, quests, art and music it definitely had glaring issues: most notably, some annoying (to the point of being silly) combat moves and the fact that a good two thirds of it is spent in some sort of swamps, sewers and similar-looking dungeons.There was no hint of something huge coming ahead.Enter the Mighty SequelBut suddenly and unexpectedly, The Witcher 2: Assassin of Kings is upon us. And here I am, trying to review it with my jaw dropped and dangling somewhere around my knees.You are Geralt, a witcher — a professional monster slayer caught in a midst of political conflict, intrigue and soon after that, on a long quest to clear your good name and discover more pieces in attempt to solve a puzzle of Wild Hunt and your dark past.Now this is something like ubelievable upgrade over previous installement, unmatched by anything in recent history. Everything you can possibly think of have been drastically improved, expanded and taken to breathtaking levels of visuals, music and sound. All environments are unique and are extremely rich in details: there’s no copy-paste ever.The characters, even NPCs, are alive, deep and interesting. There’s no other RPG where you would stop just to listen to NPC talk and smile at some story they tell each other. Every place, every spot, be it in town or outside, has an event connected to it and some amazing quest you can take on: escape from prison (be a master of stealth, or you can make it a little rough), participate in an assault on rebellious town alongisde king and teach his stupid son some good lesson, prevent military abuse of innocent civillians by beating an officer in a one-on-one swordfight, and get away with it because your king favors you so much; visit abandoned and haunted asylum to calm down the spirits of its victims and learn about its grim past, uncover treason and crime, take a taste of dirty medieval town life by participating in brawls, dice poker and arm wrestling games — and earn some additional coin with that!But There’s Much More!Meet mages, trolls (friendly and not so much), fight a giant Cthulhu with a sorceress by your side, join elves in their guerilla struggle against humans, assist dwarves and visit their mysterious town hidden somewhere deep in the mountains or, if you rather prefer that, stay in a dirty human military camp and become a new star of its colloseum-like fighting arena. The choice is always yours: so be prepared to take it and face the consequences (or enjoy them :-).CombatAnd did I even mention how great fights can be? Devise your tactics, approach and hunt monsters: all different, inhabiting their own areas and requiring unique means to successfully kill; pursue finest gear upgrades to assist yourself in your dirty job. Harvest for ingredients during your trips outside to brew and drink awesome poisions (of a witcher sort) and acquire inhuman powers for a short amount time. Buy materials, schematics and construct deadly traps, bombs and daggers to leave your enemies no chance. Approach several knights that dared to threaten you and perform a powerful finisher move, killing them all at once. Redirect arrows back at your enemies, use powerful witcher magic tricks to trap or stun your foes: block, riposte, perform a quick roll away, then jump and cut your unfortunate foe through while he recovers from a good blast of your yrden (not a typo). You have to fight dirty: you have to fight like a witcher.And all that above is just barely one third of what is in store for you.ConclusionI have no idea how CDPR were able to pull that all off.(Disregard my hours, I own it from elsewhere.)* * *[A blast of fire from dragon’s breath]— Witcher, how do you fight something like THIS?!— You don’t, you run.— Some professional you are!Outstanding.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												Alright, I'm here! I'm very late to the party, but finally I'm here. It only took close to five years. What took me so long, you ask? Well, part of the answer is that I'm not that into RPGs, but I've heard so much good about The Witcher 3 so I had to play the second to be able to import the save file to the third game. "But why didn't you play the first game?", good question. I did play the first game for some hours, but as many others I stopped due to it's fighting mechanics being really bad. Storywise, it was just fine.So, what did I think about this game? It's a great looker, even though it has been five years since its first release (Enhanced Edition was released a year later). The voice acting is as solid as expected - especially Geralt's voice. The background music is really fitting and ups the mood for the player, really bombastic and energetic music when there's a huge battle against a dragon or something like that. The story was great and can't wait to see how they continue it in the third game.But most of all - if you're a fan of RPGs and you haven't play this one yet, I do recommend you do that. When there's a sale, you can get this game for less than €5, that's NOTHING.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												The Witcher 2 continues the epic story of professional monster slayer for hire; Geralt of Rivia. If you have played the first game you will probably already have an idea of what you can expect. The Witcher 2 begins a few months after the events of the first game. If you haven't played the first you may be a bit at a loss with regards to some elements in the story.Without spoiling the story you proceed through the game searching for the 'kingslayer' and the choices you make will ultimately decide the ending of the story you get. (This ending can then be transferred to Witcher 3.) You follow one of two main story paths. You either can side with blue stripes commander Vernon Roche or with Scoitatel renegade and guerilla fighter Lor'veth. The combat in Witcher 2 has been refined considerably from the first game. whereas the first game relied on a timing mechanic; The Witcher 2 adds in things like parry's to the mix. I strongly recommend playing the first game prior as it will give greater context to the events that occur in this follow up. I also strongly recommend playing this game prior to Witcher 3 for the same reason. However the Witcher 3 does a decent job of providing additional information about the world and characters. You can find these in in-game character profiles as well as books you can find during your playthrough.As you can see it took me about 40 or so hours to play through the game. But this is a game where your investment will pay off with a satisfying conclusion that you can then build on in the Witcher 3. If you are looking for a deep story driven RPG where there is no 'right' choice; and for those choices to matter? Witcher 2 is a fantastic choice.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												*Disclaimer A: This is an ongoing review, I'll update it once I progress further into the game**Disclaimer B: This review was originally a negative one, it now has been edited*Thank you, killJoy12345! My initial review was very negative. It was based on me trying the game with a controller. Here is recommendation no.1: Do not try to play this with a controller. Who knows, I am sure some will succeed playing the game with one... I didn't. At all. The tutorial alone, attempted with an Xbox-controller, frustrated me so much that I had to quit right in the middle of the arena. It just felt so incredibly imprecise, confusing, clunky and weird. I compared it to being drunk out of your mind while trying to control an overloaded 40 ton-truck with a wobbly old joystick from the early 80s or something. I quit and uninstalled, not bothering to try again as I had bought this for like 3 bucks during a sale. I have changed my mind very much, and am falling more in love with the game the longer I play it, and I think I start to understand just why the game is so revered. I am now playing this with a mouse and a keyboard. The mouse to look around and using my attacks, the keyboard for moving. I use a Razer Naga, and with the number keys on its side, it's quite easy to control using the standard/default key settingsWith these numbers (with the Naga or keyboard), WASD, Q and R plus the Alt key to target-lock, the controls get much better. I'd also recommend to adjust the mouse settings, and lower the sensitivity. With the naga, it's set to the lowest possible value. This works well for looking around without being too slow, plus it is precise enough to handle the arm-wrestling minigame (which you need for a quest, where you do that instead of paying with money). Said arm-wrestling takes a tiny bit of practice, but I was then able to beat most opponents. Now for the game itself. Graphics/Setting/storyI said that the graphics are merely ok. I kinda stick to that, even considering the game isn't brand-new. They're quite pretty, but they're not exactly total state of the art even for the time it came out IMO. They ARE quite atmospheric though, and help to suck you into the game. And gee, there is a lot to be sucked into, as the game REALLY is quite addictive and enticing IMO. The story is quite interesting... a bit of cliché sometimes, but mainly a well-written and multi-layered story. Depending on how you want to play Geralt, you can be either a nice goodie-two-shoes, sticking to a moral high-road, or you can be a rather intimidating, threatening and sinister figure, doing whatever it takes to achieve his goal. The dialogues are nice, sometimes you have to pick your answers quickly. I am not that far into the game yet... I mentioned this will be an ongoing review, I will add updates once I progress more. So far, I am VERY into it, want to see how the story plays out, want to learn more about the world it is set in. Handling/Controls/FightingI mentioned above that the combination of KB plus Naga works quite well. I still need to practice a bit, as some of the controls are a bit...wobbly. It sometimes takes a tiny bit longer to target a lootbag, ladder, climbing/point. Fighting feels pretty dynamic, and you can succeed even if you don't target-lock enemies. So far, it was pretty much up to me how I wanted to fight mobs... using mostly swords, signs or quickslots (traps/bombs/daggers). I am sure that later on, you need to decide on some of these for specific mobs, acting with a bit more tactic, while right now, I am slashing my way through the mobs rather easily while throwing in an occasional Aard or Ignis for tougher mobs or those that shield themselves. Regarding controls and handling, this game gets a 7 or 8 out of 10 so far. I wish it'd feel a bit more precise especially out of combat, when you pick up stuff or loot. Not as good as some AC or Arkham-titles in my opinion.Update: Just did the first boss fight, and it was tough. I did have to do some research on YT. An NPC gives you SOME hints during the fight, but Im not sure how much they'd help to figure out the correct tactic without help. However, I eventually beat it, and it was quite satisfying. Soundtrack/Voice actingVery very nicely done. The music isn't annoying you, it rather adds to the atmosphere, and even with quite a few repetitions, it doesnt get boring. Pros:- Graphics are decent to very nice. Not mind-blowing, but pretty dang good.- Music and voice-acting are very well done and work nicely for the vibe.- FIghting feels dynamic... even if sometimes it's buggy (fighting my way out of a prison often had me light or extinguish torches on the wall while trying to actually slash away at a guard. Didn't die, but the combination of "use torch with left-click, slash at opponent with... left click" wasnt helpful.I hear Witcher III will be even better when it comes to controls.- Interesting and deep story, very nice to follow and read, even though there are a LOT of plotlines and chars, so maybe some extra research at a wiki would be helpful to understand it better. Cons- Controls often are a bit too wobbly, not quite precise enough. If they weren't, the game would be close to absolutely perfect. This doesn't apply much to the fight, but more to everything in between.- 2 crashes so far, hope this doesn't happen more often. The game does autosave, but I recommend to manually save from time to time. 2nd crash was on exiting an instance, and not even CTL AlT DEL would help to close the crashed game (funny: the "loading icon" was still moving, but the game had crashed)- One big immersion-killer: You can't jump. Yes, you can jumproll in certain directions while fighting to dodge attacks (direction key plus space, took me a bit of practice). So this powerful demon hunter walks through the area, and there is a 10 inch rise in the landscape... you can't raise a foot or jump up, you have to walk all around it. This kinda kills the immersion and feels weird. I guess they wanted to do this to guide you with paths in between rises, but that adds a "on rails" feeling while also feeling very unnatural. - Some of the QTEs are very fast and you might fail a few times, especially since the first ones happen quite surprisingly. DOn't worry, they won't kill you quickly, you just need to adjust quickly in order to succeed. YMMV:- Your questlog fills up rather quickly. A lot of the quests have a tracker to help you find the right spot and person, but some require you to think or search a bit. Also, read the questlog (which is well-written!). If you are used to WOW-type questing, with handholding to the extreme, TLDR-summaries at the bottom and trackers for every single quest, you might have to readjust. - Some might dislike the minigames like the wrestling. It does take practice for sure.- The menus can be quite overwhelming at first. Alchemy, talent trees, meditation etc... take your time.And that leads me to one big piece of advice: I think (at least so far) this game is MUCH more enjoyable if you take your time and savor each step. Watch the cutscenes. Read the questlogs and information provided. Enjoy the quests and solving them instead of trying to rush through them as much as possible. Try some different approaches to fights, don't ignore the quickslot items or potions or signs. If you prefer swordplay, then go ahead, but I recommend to try different styles, or mix them up a bit. I haven't fought a boss-yet... so far, the game hints that it will be a bit of work to kill the first one, and requires tactics. I hope it does, and I hope I will figure it out.So, for now: A solid 9/10, very fascinating and immersive, with a cool story, cool main-character, a very nice and sinister vibe to it (the 18-rating is pretty appropriate as far as I can tell), and it's obvious that a LOT of work went into this. WILL UPDATE!

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												They took everything great in the Witcher 1 (the story, the dialogues, the immersion...) and made it better by upgrading the graphics, the gameplay and the character design. I really recommend this game, and if you plan on playing the 3rd, don't hesitate to play this one too (or even the first one if you are not afraid of the difference in gameplay).I have only sided with the Scoia'tael yet (same as in the Witcher 1 as it seemed to be the only reasonable choice to me) but I already know that I'll replay it siding with the other faction as both groups are ambiguous.I would just recommend to take a few mods to make it more enjoyable (nexus account is free) :http://www.nexusmods.com/witcher2/mods/276/? : automatically hides the UI out of combat.http://www.nexusmods.com/witcher2/mods/697/? : Geralt is supposed to use pirouettes, not rolling on the ground, this mod just changes the animation for dodges to make it more book friendly.http://www.nexusmods.com/witcher2/mods/115/? : this one is maybe the most important as the most annoying thing in this game is that all items are way too heavy (including all ingredients for potions/bombs)A few advices for beginners : I see people complaining about the tutorial at the beginning... it's actually because there isn't really one ; I would then recommend anyone to just check the different controls online, recommend you to use potions (always use the regenerative one), oils on your blade (they increase dramatically the damages you deal to enemies) and runes on your weapons and armors. The steel sword is for the humans and the silver one is for all kind of monsters, and if you have a doubt wether it's a monster or a human, use the silver one.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												The Witcher 2 was a wonderful game in all aspects and a major improvement over the first game in the series. Geralt isn't only dealing with Temeria anymore. The fate of all the Northern Kingdoms is at stake. The story and narration lives up to the hype of the first, and in fact, has Geralt making many more decisions with varying consequences. Characters are much more fleshed out. Be prepared to face situations where you're wedged between two characters that you like, only being able to help one of them. Many times, decisions simply don't have a right answer, and other times it can be good vs bad mystery that you have to decipher by paying attention to clues given to you. You get to shape Geralt to become the character you want. My main complaint, is that the game eventually forces you to a fork in the road. This decision essentially takes over a full chapter in the story, and I although you get to visit places from both paths in one playthrough, you can end up missing a lot of important story elements if you aren't careful. I ended up glossing over the sidequest for an important character in the Witcher 3 because I was so invested in finishing the main quest. It's also totally neat to see decisions carry over from the previous game, and don't forget, the decisions you make also carry over to the Witcher 3!Combat has been completely overhauled. Say goodbye to the timed clicks, because the new combat system is entirely momentum based. The new perk tree allows Geralt to fight as a swordsman, a mage, a hunter, or any combination. Sword swings are dictated with the left and right mouse buttons, alllowing Geralt to alternate between fast or strong slashes. Enemies will flinch when attacked, giving your offenses a sense of weight. Spells and sidearms can be conveniently selected and used via a quickbar, and Geralt can roll around dodging attacks like a madman. There's still much room for improvement, however. Fighting still feels a bit clunky at times, and ragdolls (or the lack of) can make killing enemies really awkward because they just topple over. Attacks from bosses can also have extended hitboxes, as I have died many times over after getting clipped by an attack that was seemingly out of my range. Rolling may become your primary means of mobility, and it can be troublesome to use. Enemies will tend to swarm you, and blocking/reposting leaves you vulnerable from other angles while rolling may tumble you into other enemies. It's all about tactically positioning yourself, which can be seen as a welcome challenge, or an eventual annoyance. I will definitely say that there is a high learning curve to this new combat style. Unlike the first Witcher, which has Geralt acquire each of his Witcher signs throughout the game, the Witcher 2 throws all of the signs at you at once, along with a load of projectiles and potions which aren't explained very well at all. I totally failed the tutorial, which suggested for me to play on easy. I was still able to complete the game on hard, but it was far from easy. Aside from the main gameplay, you can also participate in dice poker, arm wrestling, and brawls (QTE simulator). They weren't that fun, but hey, they're not nothing.Graphically, the game is beautifully designed. The forest outside Flotsam was densely packed with greenery and looked totally sinister at night time. It was dissapointing that there were no major cities to explore, but each settlement Geralt visits has a unique rugged atmosphere. I do think that the world is a bit oversaturated, though. Colors tend to be very sharp. Characters also have great face textures, and unique characters have great memorable designs. Unfortunately, a lot of models are reused throughout the game for minor characters. The music, although my least favorite of the three Witcher games, still isn't bad at all. There was a wide array of scores that fit both emotional and intense scenes from the game. To me, the soundtrack just sounded more like stereotypical fantasy music as opposed to The Witcher or The WItcher 3 (hands down my favorite!). Still, try listening to the song Sorceresses. It's quite enchanting.In the end despite some flaws, The Witcher 2 was a true fantasy RPG mixed with exceedingly challenging yet rewarding combat. I highly recommend playing the original Witcher to get a better sense of the massive story/world and a basic handling for Geralts abilities. It is defintely an exciting experience to learn about the world of the WItcher. Pros:-Great interactive story filled with morality-based decisions-Challenging but rewarding combat-Interesting and well designed recurring characters-Beautiful level design-Solid soundtrackCons: -Combat can seem a bit unrefined-Newbies to the Witcher may have a hard time finding their footing-Fork in the road can cause you to miss some story elementsTL;DR: Play as Geralt of Rivia, the White Wolf, as you choose the lesser evil, mess around with spells, roll all over the place during fights, and die a lot.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
												The tale continues and it looks pretty impressive, but it's quite fundamentally different in all the ways that made The Witcher loved or hated or just extremely annoying and yet it's more of the same and a lot you've never read before. It can be quite entertaining, which compensates for the boring and frustrating parts, but it really leaves me with a mixed feeling. The good parts isn't about gameplay at all, but the bad and really bad parts is all about gameplay. Graphics, music and voice-overs are all pretty well done even though the language can be really weird and far too modern at times. Combat is completely different than the first game. The first Witcher game punish you for clicking too much, too soon or too late. I didn't like it, because that was also a twitch-fest. Not about clicking a lot, but clicking on reflex and a timed one of that. This game on the other hand punishes you for clicking too little all the time. It's also a much more hand-held game that constantly flashes buttons to push during brawling and wrestling is a total click-fest and it happens quite often that the game ignores its own features and mechanics and flashes the primary button to push to advance the story. People that mention being Geralt of Rivia in their reviews are totally wrong. At best you are a puppet, at worst you are just a spectator, but it's all just a story and the telling is pretty good. Geralt just happen to be the lead actor and therefore the game mostly puppeteer you as him, but on occassion it switch characters and leave you to make that one lose or moonwalk just because it can. Sometimes it changes the game into an isometric platformer.. Other times it let you jump or climb the same step.. But never the one that would be a shortcut and mostly never anywhere where it would have been really useful.. It takes control away from you to show you moves that you wish you could do on your own, but it never let you. During the first chapter you have to deal with a huge creature.. You can make a trap for it, but the Trap isn't like any other trap.. You can't deploy it randomly, there a few select spots where you are supposed to left-click to use it - not at all like a trap. It happens quite a lot that skills that normally work in one way has to be used in a completely different hand-held way.. Several times during this fight, the game will switch your game view or flash a button, both the LMB and the RMB and then you also have to use the Space bar.. I really resent games like this, because I don't feel like a player at all, but like someone who is being played with a bunch of twisted developers laughing in the corner gloating about what they made me do.. It's really humiliating. During an interrogation of a prisoner you are supposed to use a particular sign to calm the prisoner, but you are not supposed to select the sign and fire it.. You are supposed to move around the prisoner to a specific spot where the game will flash you a LMB to activate the sign and then a click-fest ensues. Epic fail, again. No more Pin-ups. The trophy hunting for babes is virtually non-existant. There is only one new trophy (with an Achievement for it) without a pinup.. You also get to do Triss again, but somehow it feels more like kissing your sister with the recycle of an animation that is virtually the same for every prosti--tute in the game. There is a actually a lot of women in the game and thus a hell of lot of missed opportunities and the reason I bothered faking interest in any of them was because of the Pin-ups of Witcher 1. Pointless. Unfortunately the game is also much more unresponsive, slower and clunkier than ever before and it has a lot of immersion breaking cutscenes in combat, where your view changes and the game changes your direction or the game shows off some vicious killing blows that ends with you dying once the game stops gloating about how awesome it would really like to be and relinguish control to you again, because during all these cutscenes, where you see everything in slow-motion, the rest of the game moves at normal speed.. Seriously?!  It happened a lot that I was keeping a distance to foes and trying to single them one at a time and then suddenly I would lose control as the game would show me some particularly vicious move and as soon as I finished I was completely surrounded by that group of enemies that I had kept a distance too.. And then there is nothing to do, because every Sign, Move and Bomb has a substantial trigger time that is easily interrupted by enemy hits.. It's a bit hard not to recommend this game, even though I've often been tempted to do it, because even though it has an insurmountable lot of flaws and too much hand holding it is a pretty great and intriguing story and it has value for two replays, because there are two branching story lines (Either you go with Roche and you get one special Chapter 2 or you go with Iorveth and you get a different Chapter 2) that changes the middle part before it finishes up to the same end. Why would I not recommend this game? Well, for one thing most of the fanbois seem to think that this is the greatest RPG of all times even though it's virtually not a RPG at all. It's pretty much "only" a great Action Adventure with some light RPG Character Building elements. Thinking of this game as a RPG at all really turned me off in the beginning. Picking dialogue is .. like pushing play to a non-interactive cutscene of conversation.. Just like in the first Witcher, there is a massive level of missed opportunities to step  into character. And just playing ONE class.. It doesn't matter how much or little else you can do with Geralt, because he's a two-handed swordman that either wields a steel sword or a silver sword. He's neither good nor evil, not even when he pick a side. If not-picking means less gameplay, not-picking is not a valid option. The combat is a huge click-fest and has a bit of OOMPH about it, because in the first fight in the game 60% of all players unlocked the Perfectionist Achievement where you kill 10 foes without loss of vitality.. But even though it's a bit entertaining it's just a means to do something else, but the worst part is that the game often falls flat on your face when faced with mortal danger and when you realize there is one and only one solution how to kill a boss it really cheapens the experience. Frustrating at best, forgettable at worst. Never gratifying. Dialogue is all scripted. The game is literally drowning in missed opportunities, but then again, it's on the rails of a book..  I guess this game represents what Blue-Ray wanted to be. (Partially) Interactive Movies. I played this game on PC with Mouse and Keyboard. On a system, that were pretty high-end 5-6 years ago, but is somewhere in the middle now. The game decided that I should play on High, but I picked a custom setting closer to Medium and enabled Morphological AA to smoothen out the picture. FPS were about 45-50 at all times during gameplay. This is really a game where a programmable mouse with an X-Fire button is a bliss. On my old and venerable A4-Tech X7 I have this X-Fire button that shoots Triple-left-clicks at the speed of light which saved me from more horrible gameplay than I can count legs on a caterpillar. I imagine it would probably be better suited for a Gamepad or an XBox experience, because all the fancy moves are double taps, which is really quite silly, because it's the only useful way to move in combat at all. In Combat "rolls" should have been the default action. I played it twice, first on Hard to Easy and second time on Dark, each one on one of two different paths. This is the first time I felt the need to use a Walkthrough. Not because it was hard, but because it was so bloody annoying at times and slow moving.

content:

												I really wish they would quit advertising this game for linux on the front page of steam.. Keep selling it for linux if they must, but its advertisement as being available for steamos/linux has been on the front page for far too long. This is not what we want linux noobs to try and play and think this is what linux gaming is about.. they have heard enough crap about gaming on linux and this only adds fuel to the negative press linux gets as a gaming platform. Yes it starts up.. and yes you can technically "play" it. Though I cannot suggest anybody play this title in linux. I had picked it up on sale and never really played it until the linux version came out and I finally got excited for it only to be really let down. It is NOT a native linux title by any stretch of the imagination as it uses a "wine type" wrapper to make it run on linux. So just deal with it and play this game on windows if you are going to play it. I will not "not" recomend this game as it's gorgeous if you have the hardware for it and from what I have played is a great game. I am just adding to the growing list of warnings about this title for linux so the linux noobs don't get the wrong idea.EDIT* Forgot I wrote this, I should note that they made great strides in getting the performance of the EON wrapper to a much more acceptable level and I can actually recommend it to be played in Linux now. Don't expect it to run as well as in windows but it is certainly acceptable IMO.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
												Great story, great characters, great graphics, great game. It surely has it's flaws, some of them bigger than others, but then again what game is perfect?The biggest problem I had with this game was that it has been crashing quite a lot, usually that's not a major problem as long as you quicksave frequently but it's annoying regardless.I've been playing on the highest difficulty (which is "Dark"; "Insane" is the same but won't let you save) and gameplay wise I had the feeling that the difficulty curve was a little off as it started out pretty hard but became fairly easy towards the end. That being said I know that it's nearly impossible to perfectly balance an open world game as this one and on the upside this game supports all sorts of mods so you can tweak the gameplay to your liking.The combat feels rather clunky at first but I found myself getting used to it within a short period of time, nonetheless I think that having the ability to (hard-)lock on enemies would have vastly improved the combat experience (while there is a lock-on system present, it's kind of useless as it doesn't lock your camera as well). Also a little tip, make sure to max out your rolling distance as soon as you can.Another freature that I'm missing in this game is a New Game Plus of some sort (starting over with your current gear but stronger enemies), the game offers great replay value so it's a mystery to me why nothing alike was included.While you don't need to play Witcher 1 in order to be able to follow the story of Witcher 2 (the stories aren't even related for that matter), I would still strongly recommend to play Witcher 1 first as many of the main characters are returning and knowing the backstory from Witcher 1 will make your experience in both Witcher 2 and 3 superior.TL;DR:In contray to Witcher 1 this one isn't an old school but a "modern style" RPG and it's a pretty great one at that. Buy it.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												The Witcher is a dark, gritty, and mature RPG. It is probably one of the most grounded, and interesting RPG I've ever played. The Witcher itself is based on its famous novels written by Andrzej Sapkowski. Geralt of Rivia, The White Wolf, is a monster hunter for pay. Throughout Geralt's journey through Temeria for work, he is conflicted with political issues that arise after the events at Vizimia; this takes place during the Witcher 1. Geralt is now faced with treason, and is set out on a journey to clear his name. The Witcher 2 has a though provoking story that requires your attention. Books you pick up, as well as notes should be read. The books you find will tell you the history of the Witcher universe, and give you tips when fighting difficult opponents. You will also be making choices that actually do make a difference within the universe. The combat in the Witcher 2 is probably its weakest aspect. It is, however, much better than the combat system introduced in the Witcher 1. In the Witcher 2, you are required to roll around during almost any combat situation. This effectively makes signs, or any other defensive abilties obselete. The Witcher 2 requries a necessary playthrough as its story, characters, and universe are provoking. Even if the Witcher's combat system is medicore at best, it won't stop you from enjoying the numerous other aspects that the Witcher does correctly. Summary: Positive:+Story+High graphical fidelity+Unforgettable charactersNegative: -Combat

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												Performance:Really impressed with how well-made the new engine is. Loads faster(which is kind of surprising because the first game's load times weren't even long), stutters less, and, of course, looks prettier. And I mean much prettier. You don't expect games that look this much better than their prequels to actually perform better than them.The only things about it that I don't like are the differed rendering(alternate form of rendering that only supports [and works] [with] a form of anti-aliasing that has been specifically coded into the game, cancelling out any kind of AA forced on from your graphics control panel. Use SweetFX for AA.), sharpness filter(you'll wanna turn it off in your user config, but make sure to force Anisotrophic Filtering on), and the bloom. The bloom.. I usually am ok with bloom in my games, but I had to turn this game's off. There is just too much of it. For my eyes, anyway.Graphics settings:Many graphics settings available for tweaking. There's a lot you can make changes to that will help the game run better on your rig, if it needs itControls:Controls are greatly improved. Dodging actually works consistently, unlike in the last game. Same with parrying. Same with attacking. I remember instances in the first Witcher where the system sometimes wouldn't let me attack opponents if they were close to me or surrounded me or just didn't let me attack them(while not stunned, etc). When attacking, you use either the left or right mouse button. Either are for heavy or light attacks. Is not like the first Witcher where you select an attack style and click on a foe. The buttons are the styles, so they have to be used/pressed after each attack. Can be combined.They took out the feature that let's you press/hold a button/key to highlight/display whatever in view can be interacted with, as well as the the feature that's you select what you want to interact with the cursor, while you hold/press a button. It's not that big of a deal not having it, but you now have to just run up to something you see, and click on it to do whatever with it.Gameplay:Am a few hours into the game, but can say it's very much like the first. Only, better.Combat is same, but more engaging. Also kinda harder(but I was playing on Dark/Insane difficulty.). You can meditate anywhere(no fireplaces/characters needed) that wouldn't be considered dangerous(out of battle, not in the presence of enemies). Inside or outside.So far, the choice system is still here. I've been in situations in the game where I could, as an example, stop a crime or let it follow through. There are also sub-choices, which can sometimes be made after main choices have been made. Good/bad/etc ones are available.EDIT:Overall:Have since spent more hours playing the game and am enjoying it. The story is very much still that of The Witcher's, and the gameplay is very fun. Good combat, and there more options for interacting with characters you encounter than there were in last Witcher game.The game feels like it was made on PC, which is awesome. Same as the last game. Same level of detail in the enviornments, great graphics, and doesn't feel like some technically-constrained console port."coughs" Skyrim "coughs" Fallout

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												The Witcher 2 isn't a perfect game. The inventory system is pretty terrible compared to Witcher 1's, blade oils and potions have been downgraded significantly  (and  the timers for them, now reduced to a few minutes at most, don't seem to pause during dialogue, meaning if you don't skip through dialogue after reading the subtitles you might spent several potions and oils preparing for a fight only get into a pre-fight dialogue and have them all unwittingly wasted away), and the magical signs in turn have been buffed to the point of almost being broken, with Yrden in particular rendering most bosses trivial. The dice poker is now a single-round exercise in trying to move your mouse as microscopically as you can in order to not cause every dice to go canonballing off of the board, and the fistfighting diversion is now just a bunch of QTEs.But when you look past all that, The Witcher 2 is by far one of the better RPGs of its generation. The dialogue and general writing are great, and the politics and general lore are more fleshed out and interesting than in the first game. The quest design in general has been greatly improved, and even though there are less monster hunting quests than in the first game they're generally deeper, involving you researching the monsters and doing specific goals to fully eradicate the threat instead of just lobbing off a few heads and turning them in. The game is overall shorter than the first game, but only because it branches off after the first chapter and essentially becomes two different stories which then further branch out, leading to plenty of replayability. You'll have forgotten all of the flaws I listed up above within the first chapter of the game, and it's overall definitely worth a purchase if you're into RPGs.

												BUY THIS GAMEV.I. -  variable immersion  ->  You can immerse yourself in the witcher world as much as you like.The harder mode you select the more you will be immersed.  YOU (not your character) will NEED to learn how to make the best/cheapest potions, swords, armors etc. And you WILL need to use them in order to finish the game. Hard=Rewarding combat -> In the beginning you might find the combat hard, but if you spend some time in the "Arena" (an Arcade like mode that you can play before you start the story , you can practice and learn the combat). Killing a monster makes you feel like a real witcher , because it requires skill and THOGHT.Great side missions ->  The side missions are NOT  repetitive. In each area you will have contracts which you don`t have to  take, they are not even mentioned in the story , you will have to find the board where they are posted on. They EXPAND the world of the witcher.  There are huge areas that you might not even see if you don't take on the side missions.GREAT DEVELOPER -> This team has updated their game with DLC for FREE since 2011.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												This is my favorite RPG of all time. FULL STOP. You are hearing this from someone who played Planescape Torment, System Shock 2, Baldur's Gate, Fallout, and so on...The amount of meaningful choices in this game is immense, you can even change 2 entire chapters of this game just because of ONE choice. The story is really intriguing, filled with political and racial conflict, while still maintaining a very personal feel and with some great characters to accompany you on this journey.The combat is probably the most divisive element of the game, some will enjoy it (like I did), and others won't (at least it's a better combat system than the one in the first Witcher).Technically, it still holds up today, and this was released in 2011, although some animations are a bit robotic, but that is something omnipresent on RPG's, so I let it pass. Both the voice acting and music are great.Honestly, if you like RPG's, just buy this, it has some insane replay value, great modding comunity, and you can catch it on sale on Steam regularly. Must Own!!!!

content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings is one of the finest examples of how great an RPG can be. There's simply no competitor that can touch it in terms of poise, characterisation and storytelling, or the way in which it treats you not as a player - someone to be pandered to and pleased - but as an adult, free to make your own mistakes and suffer a plot in which not everyone gets what they deserve.In the end, The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings is a visually impressive game that contains a very sturdy gaming engine. If you haven't played a traditional RPG in awhile, the learning curve is a little steep and challenging at the start but once you have the experience under your belt and selected a direction for your character, battles will slowly become easier but fortunately there is always something along the way to challenge you. This is what RPG's are all about and I sincerely hope that this game will become the template for games to come on the PC.I Consider the Witcher 2 Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition is the Best RPG Ever Made!  I RECOMEND THI GAME!

content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
  8.60 Out of 10	 The Witcher 2.Sigh..This game.It was released on 2011,a year when another great game did release,Skyrim,from the Elder Scrolls Series,which..lets say...made The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings...go a little more ''underground''.However,this game apart  from the beautiful graphics,complex gameplay,and great story,it actually treats you like an adult![adult scenes,(not porn scenes!)]Personal Completion Length : 38 hours.Disclaimer : I Bought Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings when i used my older computer.Bad news were,i couldnt play this game,because that pc was ancient and..i had to buy a new gpu. Lets Continue on the Critics,shall we? Story 8/10	 The Main Protaganist-You-Geralt,a Witcher,which suffers from Amnesia.The Main Antagonist,Letho,An assassin of Kings,which is also a witcher,murdered king Foltest,and the people believe that Geralt is the assassin.Geralt now has to find Letho and clean his name.Whatever you do,you will be chillin with your buddies,Zoltan and Dandelion,and your Sexy girlfriend,Triss. Graphics 9.5/10	  The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings' graphics and visuals are absolutely STUNNING,even on low settings.Beautiful scenes and views,gorgeous and detailed world,this game will make you take a break and start screenshotting. Gameplay : 8,6/10 	One thing i loved about this game,are the swords.Geralt uses 2 swords,one steel,which is effective against humans,but ineffective against non-humans.The other one is a  silver,which is effective against monsters,but ineffective against human creatures.Furthermore,The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings , has a great variety of items to craft,from armor and swords,to   potions and bombs.The Perk System is also good.There are 4 tree perks,Magic,Alchemy,Swordmanship and Training,which is the basic,you need to complete this one,to unlock the rest.The game lets you choose your destiny,where most of your choices will change the story,which is something i loved.The Combat system was also positive,you can use 5 spells,from igniting your enemies,to actually controll them.Finally,the game keeps saving and saving,a positive thing that lets you play again and again and change the plot.One of the negatives,was the targeting system,was kidda bad and difficult to use.also,there were long routes,which were great to explore,but..there was no fast travel..something which made the game a liiiiiiiiiiiiiittle boring.The Worst,lets say part of the game was the tutorial,a total disaster,which doesnt really teach you how to play.lets say,you need to experience the game yourself. Controls 7.3/10 Keyboard controls were kidda awkward and difficult to use,but time after time,you get used to it. Sound 9.2/10	 The Actors who voiced the characters were pretty decent,and made them sound pretty reliable.Also,the sound effects were pretty good too(i enjoyed the combat while wearing a headset)And finally,the OSTs were magnificent

content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
												I started this game right after finishing The Witcher and the biggest improvement between the two is definitely the gameplay, namely combat.  I have very little bad to say about it other than that some of the strategies you can abuse (namely always have Quen up when fighting) make some of the fights a little dumb, but really any monster can kill you if you aren't paying attention and I really like that.  It makes the world feel very real that all monsters pose at least some threat throughout the entire game.I suppose the only other gripe I have is how poorly optimized the game is.  I should be able to run this maxed out with no frame drops at all, but there are times when I get pretty poor FPS and it has nothing to do with my system and everything to do with the game itself.  That said, there are some pretty fantastic sights to be seen in all the different locations the game takes you.  For a game that's about 5 years old, it has aged surprisingly well graphically.All the small negatives aside, this series is seriously one of my favorite of all time now.  The story telling is top notch.  The way the world and Geralt evolve as the story progresses is superbly done.  All progression feels extremely organic, especially from one game to another (where you can import saves that will keep your decisions intact ala Mass Effect so you can have YOUR Geralt through the entire series if you so wish). In addition to feeling organic...it just makes sense.  The way the politics change with your decisions or the decisions of other characters in the game...nothing feels contrived or silly because t's all justified by the world that has been crafted here.I can't recommend this game enough.  At times it gets frustrating because there are definitely some fights that will take a few tries to beat, but it is also rewarding in the sense of accomplishment, but also in the sense of story telling.  Any fan of RPGs where your decisions actual matter worth a damn should already be playing this, and if you have the stomach for it make sure to pick up the first game as well.  Both games took me just around 30 hours to beat (all quests for the given paths I had chosen completed) with a fair amount of exploration (which you should always take advantage of because you never know what cool weapons you'll find)...the ability to transfer saves from one game to the next (and even into The Witcher 3), really sells me on the idea that it's the right way to go if you're going to really get into the series.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												As nearly everyone seems to be saying, this is an excellent game. Great RPG elements, great plot, wonderful difficulty, wonderful graphics, etc. All of this praise applies to this game, keep that in mind. Two important things to say, if you already can't tell, this isn't a a game for kids, the M rating, if written down, would take up a standard office paper. Second, this game has poor optimization for particular builds of computers, don't let this scare you away, but if you are on the lower end of the spectrum when it comes to minimum requirements, you should check online to ensure your gaming experience will be satisfactory, I was decently ahead of the minimum requirements with a 2.9GHz dual core (AMD) and a Nvidia Geforce GT 240 with 1GB DDR3 VRAM, with 8GB of 1833 Mhz of "normal" RAM. This said, being reasonably well ahead of the minimum requirements, I had to set every graphics setting to the lowest possible setting, and then set my resolution to 800x600 to play at a playable FPS (30). In defense of CDProjektRed, I did have an "interesting" graphics card at the time, and have since moved to a more "standard" card. Everything under consideration, this is an excellent title.

Posted: November 28, 2015
												The game is awesome! It has got it all: graphics, thick branching story, serviceable combat mechanics, and occasional nudity. The story is so rich that it actually bogs down the experience in the prologue. Tons of characters with their own public or hidden agendas drop in and out. After a while they become familiar enough, making the tons of plot twists impacting. The combat also has a rough start, in learning curve and outright weakness of the protagonist. Once you learn the basics the combat can make you feel like a skilled video game swordsman. Although, the hardest battles are a matter of long-winded tedium of exploiting the same combat techniques used in any other battle.All these elements compile to make an RPG that may not have the drowning, yet shallow, expanse of Bethesda games, but does dive deep in the few acts it contains.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2014
												CD Projekt RED is now widely regarded as the 'new Bioware' in terms of quality and polish. I cant really argue with this CD'PR built an RPG that's hardcore but nonetheless accessible in The Witcher 2, and the the Enhanced Edition improves on an already amazing game. Let me also state that while you can jump into the Witcher 2 without playing the original Witcher, I would not recommend it. The game does little to help players new to the lore find thier feel, but the EnhancedEdition does come an introduction in the form an animated scene. However this will not explain most things, and I would seriously recommend playing the first one first as it's also a great game, though rather dated. The world of The Witcher 2 once again takes form loosely based upon the books of Andrzej Sapkowski, drawing upon its dark and merciless idiosyncrasy to weave a dire environment where humans and nonhumans are looked upon in stark contrast to one another, where each of the planet's inhabitants are imperfect and flawed in some untenable way. Whether its a band of elven warriors going by the name of Scoia'tael (or "Squirrels" as their malevolent opposers refer to them) fighting to end the racist remarks of their human counterparts, or the soldiers and politicians seeking to take more and more land and freedoms away from the so-called terrorist elves, everyone carries with them a vengeful agenda that threatens to ruin the very fabric of society and its citizens that only wish to live a normal, common livelihood. It is easy to start to dislike some of the main charecters, but as you learn more about them, you'll start to like them. A definate example would be Roach who'll be your friend (possibly) throughout the plot.Geralt, the feared and exalted monster-slaying mutated human with a knack of getting caught in unfortunate predicaments, finds himself imposed into a dire situation. After participating in a drawn out battle with an army of traitorous soldiers attempting a coup de tat which serves as the games tuetorial, Folest, King of Temeria and Prince of Sodden, is murderd, having been slain by a tall, lion-sized man who bears the traits of a Witcher standing only feet away from where the oblivious Geralt was standing.The mysterious murderer escapes out a nearby window right before the king's guards show up and arrest the silver-haired wolf at the scene of the crime. It is this powerful narrative that has been carried with such fanciful grace over the past two games in The Witcher that has turned it into a sort of a relic among others in its genre. The world, its characters, and the vivid atmosphere have all been fashioned in such spectacular fashion that anyone with even a hint of an eye for natural beauty will find a lot to love in this paramount magnum opus from CD Projekt RED. Utilizing a brand new engine built from the ground up for their newest project, called the RED Engine, The Witcher 2 is no slouch when it comes to spitting out rigs. The game looks phenominal and even stands up to the Crysis3 and StarCitizen in graphical Baws'ness. Many computers will struggle to run this game at high settings, let alone on ultra, which is where this game can blow your eye sockets off. Fortunately, there are a bevy of graphical options to choose from to ensure that your computer is always making the most of where it can perform at. If you have a capable machine, however, it is hard not to get lost in the pure splendor of it all when you are in the middle of the game.Animations flow smoothly, vegetation is fluid and alive, environments seem to stretch on for miles, and characters come alive as they all perform their cyclical routines day in and day out. Crowded cities and large open environments do a great job at establishing a well-realized and heavily detailed world for Geralt to roam around in athough in the later portions of the game it does feel a little sparse.Now the cons:-It has incredibly lousy (though bearable) mouse-clicking combat that requires a good amount of utility to get used to the way Geralt moves around. I'd advise a 360 controller if possible.-The ineptitude of the tutorials given to the player that do little to actually do what they are designed to do.-The questing system does a great job in causing a massive headache, especially when it comes to navigating without a compass; and a polarizing journal system. The story can also be a little too convoluted at times, with characters and locations being introduced on an almost constant basis that it can be difficult to follow if one is not paying close enough attention to it. I like a game which doens't hold your hand, like the old Morrowind quest system. But this feels couterproductive and clunk. To make matters worse. All the menus are aplit up into groups, but they cant be scrolled between, and I envariably found myself clicking random keys to find the inventory or quest log hotkey. Doesn't really matter though. In the end W2 is one of the best PC games out there, and a must play for someone who wants a dark and gritty (As you've probably heard, there is quite a lot of boobs in this game) tale with insane graphics and a great story.9/10

content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												Performance:Really impressed with how well-made the new engine is. Loads faster(which is kind of surprising because the first game's load times weren't even long), stutters less, and, of course, looks prettier. And I mean much prettier. You don't expect games that look this much better than their prequels to actually perform better than them.The only things about it that I don't like are the differed rendering(alternate form of rendering that only supports [and works] [with] a form of anti-aliasing that has been specifically coded into the game, cancelling out any kind of AA forced on from your graphics control panel. Use SweetFX for AA.), sharpness filter(you'll wanna turn it off in your user config, but make sure to force Anisotrophic Filtering on), and the bloom. The bloom.. I usually am ok with bloom in my games, but I had to turn this game's off. There is just too much of it. For my eyes, anyway.Graphics settings:Many graphics settings available for tweaking. There's a lot you can make changes to that will help the game run better on your rig, if it needs itControls:Controls are greatly improved. Dodging actually works consistently, unlike in the last game. Same with parrying. Same with attacking. I remember instances in the first Witcher where the system sometimes wouldn't let me attack opponents if they were close to me or surrounded me or just didn't let me attack them(while not stunned, etc). When attacking, you use either the left or right mouse button. Either are for heavy or light attacks. Is not like the first Witcher where you select an attack style and click on a foe. The buttons are the styles, so they have to be used/pressed after each attack. Can be combined.They took out the feature that let's you press/hold a button/key to highlight/display whatever in view can be interacted with, as well as the the feature that's you select what you want to interact with the cursor, while you hold/press a button. It's not that big of a deal not having it, but you now have to just run up to something you see, and click on it to do whatever with it.Gameplay:Am a few hours into the game, but can say it's very much like the first. Only, better.Combat is same, but more engaging. Also kinda harder(but I was playing on Dark/Insane difficulty.). You can meditate anywhere(no fireplaces/characters needed) that wouldn't be considered dangerous(out of battle, not in the presence of enemies). Inside or outside.So far, the choice system is still here. I've been in situations in the game where I could, as an example, stop a crime or let it follow through. There are also sub-choices, which can sometimes be made after main choices have been made. Good/bad/etc ones are available.EDIT:Overall:Have since spent more hours playing the game and am enjoying it. The story is very much still that of The Witcher's, and the gameplay is very fun. Good combat, and there more options for interacting with characters you encounter than there were in last Witcher game.The game feels like it was made on PC, which is awesome. Same as the last game. Same level of detail in the enviornments, great graphics, and doesn't feel like some technically-constrained console port."coughs" Skyrim "coughs" Fallout

content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												This is a good RPG with some really impressive graphical and visual effects. Especially the lighting effects looks astonishing. The story is mature and rather complex, but I couldn't really appreciate it as much as others have done. Maybe it was because I haven't played the first game and therefore missed out on some parts of the overall story and the lore. Either way I thought it was a little bit too confusing at times, especially when the facial expressions and character animations wasn't very good.I also thought that the menus could've been better - they often felt slow, unresponsive and very irritating.But the thing that kept me playing was the superb combat! The feeling when you fought against a large number of enemies at the same time and you had to think tactical to survive was really rewarding!Overall, I enjoyed the game but was a little disappointed with the story, mostly because I've heard a lot good things about it. I do recommend the game though, especially if you want to test what your computer is capable of.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												Fanastic game, graphics are beautiful and the environments stunning, characters are very detailed and each one feels unique (unlike the identikit ones on Skyrim that are all voiced by the same 3 people) It's linear, yes, but thats because it has a story to tell and wants you to fully immerse yourself in the experience. Some big decisions to make throughout the game that will change how the story pans out, and I will definately be playing through it again to get the other endings.This one will be tough on your graphics card, even some of the newer ones at max settings may struggle a little, but as you can see from the screens it is a gorgeous looking game.My only dislike was the whole potions and meditating thing, wasn't a fan of that really, but other than that this game is a must play for any RPG or fantasy fan and I cannot wait for the finale, Witcher 3

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful16 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												Saved an elf woman.She repaid me with sex.10/10 would save again.Now, speaking seriously, this is a good game. It really is. I didn't play the first one that much - I didn't feel engaged. The world was interesting, but the way it "felt" didn't get me and I got a bit boring. But heck, I wanted to play the second one, because I tried it once at a friend's house when it came out and I had good memories lingering about it.So I bought it.And I did good.The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings is quite the improvement. Everything feels better executed. The game is more politic-centered, compared to the first one (for what I can tell). Combat is more polished - though it could be better. The world you play in is stunning, full of rich developed characters with whom you may bond - or not. Your choice. After finished the first Act, I found mysfelf desperate for more and more. Good thing is - I received it. More and even more goodness.Flaws? Not many. There are some things that I would have liked to be a tad different. For example:1) Conversations with your pals; sometimes they feel a bit plain. I mean, unlike Mass Effect, for example, where you usually have more possibilities on this matter, here conversations more often fall into some questions regarding the (politic) plot and nothing more. No hanging out or anything like it, for the most part. 2) Final Boss Fight; too damn easy. For real.3) Animations; very few of them. Maybe it's asking too much, but still. And that's all I can think about right now. Minor things that don't really♥♥♥♥♥♥all over the experience at all. The Witcher 2 is, overall, a really great, great game. Story is quite good - with twists and all. Characters are easy to like or hate and the end leaves you hanging at the very edge, gasping for another final adventure - The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt. F*ck yeah I am ready for diving into that. Bring it.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												This is a good RPG with some really impressive graphical and visual effects. Especially the lighting effects looks astonishing. The story is mature and rather complex, but I couldn't really appreciate it as much as others have done. Maybe it was because I haven't played the first game and therefore missed out on some parts of the overall story and the lore. Either way I thought it was a little bit too confusing at times, especially when the facial expressions and character animations wasn't very good.I also thought that the menus could've been better - they often felt slow, unresponsive and very irritating.But the thing that kept me playing was the superb combat! The feeling when you fought against a large number of enemies at the same time and you had to think tactical to survive was really rewarding!Overall, I enjoyed the game but was a little disappointed with the story, mostly because I've heard a lot good things about it. I do recommend the game though, especially if you want to test what your computer is capable of.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												The game is awesome! It has got it all: graphics, thick branching story, serviceable combat mechanics, and occasional nudity. The story is so rich that it actually bogs down the experience in the prologue. Tons of characters with their own public or hidden agendas drop in and out. After a while they become familiar enough, making the tons of plot twists impacting. The combat also has a rough start, in learning curve and outright weakness of the protagonist. Once you learn the basics the combat can make you feel like a skilled video game swordsman. Although, the hardest battles are a matter of long-winded tedium of exploiting the same combat techniques used in any other battle.All these elements compile to make an RPG that may not have the drowning, yet shallow, expanse of Bethesda games, but does dive deep in the few acts it contains.

												Absolutely amazing... I've been a big RPG fan my whole life, and I feel robed for never have playing the witcher series. This is the first i've played of it, and it is fantastic. I will without a doubt be purchasing The Witcher 3, and future witcher games. This game is a must for any RPG fan... The story, decisions, the gameplay, lore... It's all superb, well crafted, and mature. My only complaint is the difficulty. Playing on hard was dumbfoundingly easy. I was able to defeat the end boss with less than 10 hits. By the end of the game, I was just too powerful. Hopefully The Witcher 3 will be more difficult.edit: MODS! My complaints about difficulty can be solved with modding! Thank the gods that CD Projekt RED allows for modding, the modding community is actually quite amazing (with all witcher games). Another great reason to pick this game up!

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												The game is awesome, dare to say one of the best rpg i have played in my life,besides i havent play many. :PI dont know if the combat system is better or worse from the 1st one,but its entire different.On one side,on the 1st witcher you can play only with the mouse with many clicks on the enemy, choosing combat style while you can carry 40 health potions like diablo and on the other side on assassins of kings you have to roll all the time in battles -maybe the basic element of combat on witcher 2- ,more usage of quen sign than the 1st and parrying the enemies trying to isolate them in order to kill them with the right sequence -from easier to harder -.If you get accustomed with that you get a spectacular result because combining magic & tactics, Geralt do unbielevable fatality combos presented with amazing cinematic style!Rarely i used potions-because u cant them drink inside the battle-,but instead of them i used all the time oils for both swords.Also here unlike the 1st witcher, you change more often your armor,swords etc...your build.What about journal?Amazing with many info for whatever you want about Geralt and his andventure-monsters,locations,lore-.Crafting/meditation/character/drink potion/ map/world map are all of them in one menu with submenus where i believe appear with the best way it can.Simplified with all info onscreen.Many times in order to kill more easily some enemies you should take guidance from journal/monster knowledge menu which exhibits how to kill more effectively some monsters.For example in order to kill queen enderga you must oil your sword with insecticide  oil, and dont hit her from the front because they have good armor and they are immune to magic,instead roll to side of the queen and hit her.Also when you attacked from many enemies,in any case you must not let them hit you from the back because the damage is 200% more. -can be halfed from skill tree-The same way works if you hit them from the back.Graphically the game is piece of art.Nothing more,nothing less. :PAlso in the game, many times you come on crossroads and you have to choose quickly with which side you go with a price that comes later from the other side where you didnt choose.Yet there are 2-3 missions which are full of stealth and i like it very much.Additional the game has big replayability because of the crossroads i said before.Finishing i would like to see Letho more often in the game.Finally i want to believe that in witcher 3 wild hunt, will have import save from 2 with the right consequences and will have bigger towns from witcher 2.I would like something like Vizima from the 1st.And something almost forgot if your loading times will be terrible big, then delete as many as you can savegames.Maximun 5 saves in order to load quickly as possible.

												Wow. What an amazing story. Although Witcher 3 is better in terms of combat and size, Witcher 2 is still holds far superior story and to be honest is more replayable although shorter.You seek to help Geralt the extremely powerful monster hunter recover his memory, and help establish or destroy entire nations and characters. 												After playing The Witcher: Enhanced Edition prior to this and literally 100-0'ing my enemies most of the time without much challenge apart from some bossfights i downloaded The Witcher 2 and started playing it the same way.
