number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												TL;DL - Game is so good. Combat is awesome. Good RPG element. A tale to be told.7/10Pro+ Awesome sex scene+ Awesome combat+ Awesome character+ Awesome story for main quest+ Awesome crafting mechanic+ Awesome graphicCon- Less sex- Less secondary quest- Less monster hunting- Less fun mini game.- Graphic can be too bright/contrast- Nerf of potion, oil etc. Full Review Second game in The Witcher series from CDPR.You will continue to play as Geralt, a witcher, after the event of the first game.You can tell how much CDPR have put they effort on this game to improve from the first witcher.The graphic is so awesome. Thanks for REDengine from CDPR themselves. It look better then most game these day.The world setting and location fit the world of witcher nicely.Combat have been improve a lot. More fluid and responsive. Really fun to play.Crafting and overall game mechanic is a lot more easier.These are the first few thing you will notice after 15 minutes in the game and you will get addicts to this game right off the bat.The main story of The witcher 2 is more intense, more mature and come with really hard choice to choose.Your decision can affect the whole game story. Make The witcher 2 have lot of replayability. It deserve to play at least twice. The charecters in The witcher 2 is also very interesting. You will learn to love or hate them as the story go. BUT  I rate this game less then The Witcher 1 (I rate first one 8/10).While gameplay and graphic have been improve a lot. The story of the witcher 2 not really appeal to me. (Is it just me that like the story of TW1 then TW2. I don't really like political element in TW2. I think it's a bit too much and I feel like political don't fit well with the witcher story)What really dissappoint me is secondary quest. There is less secondary quest to play in the witcher 2 and none of them is memorable. The monster contract in The witcher 2 is more deeper and harder to complete which I like but there is so little of them. Make it lost the feeling of being the witcher. There is also not much monster in the wild and not much variety.I don't really like the mini game is this one too. Poker dice is hard to read, fist fighting become QTE and arm wrestling is way too easy. There is also no romance card to collect (AKA less sex).The graphic is really good but at time it can be too bright and color and be too contrast. It does look beautiful but sometime it's just too much. Also, This maybe a tiny thing but the graphic and control option have to be adjust outside the game.Potion is one of the most important part in The witcher. In the witcher 2 you can brew potion, crafting and meditating without bonfire BUT you can't drink potion while in combat!! And the duration of potion and other buff have been decrease a lot. I understand that CDPR try to balancing the game since the buff can be to OP (In the witcher 1 potion last many hours depand on what kind while The Witcher 2 last 10 minute). But with duration of potion nerf and need of meditating to drink potion make potion in witcher 2 almost useless. If you prepare and drink your potion first it can go out of effect while in cutscene or conversation and if fight happan immediatly you can't drink potion. I often found that duration is too short and not enought while explore the area. But good thing is you can brew/drink potion anytime and you can upgrade your skill or equipment to make duration longer. I just found it quite annoying to keep drinking potion. Summary The witcher 2 overall is one of the best RPG experiance to have. Beautiful graphic and world setting. Very good combat and game mechanic is easy to understand. Deep story with hard choice to be made and lot of replayability. I may complain in a few thing about The witcher 2 but maybe I adhere to The witcher 1 too much.The witcher 2 is a must play in my opinion.PS : Sorry for my english.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
Do yourself a favour and play this before The Witcher 3...... Not because The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt wouldn't work as a standalone game. Actually it does, and it does it very well.I got this game on sale for 2,99€ a few days back. My only problem with this game is that I have already finished The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt before starting this game. Truth be told, these games look much alike. So for a 2011 game The Witcher 2 looks great and feels great. If I had never played The Witcher 3 I would probably consider this one of thegreatest games I have ever played. The story, dialogue, acting, combat - all of it is there and it's good.But here is the problem; none of it is quite as good as with The Witcher 3. If you have never played The Witcher 3 you wouldn't know all the tiny things you're missing when you're playing The Witcher 2. But if you already have, you got to admit that in comparison The Witcher 2 feels rather small, clunky, limiting and occasionally claustrophobically one dimensional. This is not exactly fault of the game itself, but because the sequel happens to be probably the best game ever made.So do yourself a favour and don't do like I did. Don't go straight to The Witcher 3, but play this one (and even the first one if you can stomach the outdated experience) first or it will be very hard to come back. Personally I've found the story itself intriguing and craving more for the world of The Witcher. Right now, being used to the best coming back to something almost as good isn't quite cutting it anymore.I will finish this game eventually, but I wish I had started from here, just because I would've enjoyed it more.Regardless, this game is easily worth the money.

number of helpful: 34 of 65 people (52%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												I have seen a lot of praise for this game especially for the PC platform on forums everywhere on the internet. And I have also seen a lot of this: "CDProjeKt Red is the only AAA game industry that cares about the PC platform"Well after playing the game this is what I have to say: The Witcher 2 Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition is a console game.Likes:- Great Cinematics and visuals. Clever use of post-process effects. Makes the graphics look great. Character models are very detailed.- Deep StoryDislikes:- Console style gameplay, all of it, the whole game- Keyboard and mouse controls are irritating. Tried the gamepad, the K+M issues were gone, but the gamepad has its own set of issues, the same issues for which i hate the gamepad in general. Finished the game with the keyboard and mouse except used the gamepad for arm wrestling(lol double meaning there).- You have to use a thing called as medallion to highlight pickup objects. Because it is very hard to see pickup objects manually. And that medallion thingy has got a cooldown. It's also hard to focus on pickup objects because of the player's 'running' to 'idle' state animation.- The minimap and the map wasn't exactly helpful. There will be some objective up a hill but you will end up in a cave directly below it. And the lack of fast travel just made it more irritating. It looks like the game wants me to memorize the directions to each place.- There will be some objectives that are right in front of you but you will have to circle around the entire town to reach that place since the player cannot jump over a fence or jump down to the floor below. This wouldn't have been a problem if it was only needed to be done once but you need to reach that same place again and again multiple times. The lack of fast travel again adds to the frustration.- The 'charm' option in dialogues always succeeds. No point in choosing other options.- Music is average at best. Not great use of sound either.- I hate memorizing stuff that isn't important to me. And the magic powers that the player has are in sign language, just made it more difficult to memorize. If it was English it would have been a bit easier. There were also some sign language puzzles. Who in the world knows sign language? There was a learning curve for me in this game. I don't usually expect a learning curve in a single-player game(after playing lots of games).- Some side missions get FAILED if you leave the area or progress the main story. I thought it was an open world RPG. Can't even finish objectives at my leisure. The game is linear for the most part.- The game wasn't technically impressive for me. There were a lot of loading zones/streaming levels(DOORS). Everything in the distance is either mist/fogged/depth of field blurred out. Basically everything you see in the far distance is of very low quality. And AFAIK there is no zoom functionality. And the third person camera helps hiding a lot of things. And I prefer realistic looking graphics than fantasy graphics even in a fantasy world.- Too many cutscenes. I wanted a game not a movie.- Show off.- Story can be overwhelming. Too many characters to keep track of, and characters are referred to in dialogues very directly some of which you haven't even seen or heard about yet. Poor presentation of story to the player. Ideally this should not be a reason for playing the game again.- Porny stuff doesn't add value to the game. This must have been a 'like' point for most people. People need to understand that this does not add value to the game. It might be needed for storytelling, but Witcher 2's scenes were deliberately inserted to increase player appreciation. If you are interested in such things go watch porn that is available for free on the internet. But don't praise a game because it has porny stuff in it.- On the other hand, the gameplay is completely childish and a kid cannot play this game because it has mature content.- The skill tree isn't very interesting. And you have to meditate to drink potions. Oh! Come onDoubtful:- I must be the only person who found the concept of a 'silver' sword ridiculous.Some useful Statistics:It's been more than 2 years since the release of Witcher 2. So some valid statistics are available. According to Steam achievements atleast 57.1% of players have started playing the game. And 13.8% of players have finished the game. That means only 24.17% players who have started playing the game have actually completed it. Ideally for a good single player game this percentage should be above 33. This probably means that most of the players either quit playing the game or got stuck somewhere indefinitely or they had better games to play or bought it just to watch the porny stuff in it and not to play the game. I hope this gives you enough reason for why this game is not recommended.Verdict : 78/100The Witcher 2 Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition is a console game.

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 12
												I love The Witcher and thoroughly enjoyed the original game for its depth, quality narative and pretty much everything else(Besides the combat which was still better than its successors). The Witcher 2 sad to say feels like a mere shadow of what it should have been. Where the first game felt immersive and fun to explore Assassins of Kings felt rigid and tedious. I actually had to force myself to finish it just because it felt so... Well... Not fun. I hate to say that but it's honestly how the game made me feel. Even during parts of the game where big stuff was happening it just felt straight up boring, and it just got worse as the game went on. Another thing I found strange is that pretty much nothing happens in this game. Sure you travel to different places in the world but for the most part nothing big happens at all, and even when stuff does happen it leaves a feeling of wanting more. Wanting more from a game isn't what one should feel while playing and engaging with a "Story rich RPG" you should feel like the story is big and mysterious leaving you guessing and wondering what could be next for the character. One last thing that I want to add is that The Witcher 2 is ludacrously short and ended abruptly seemingly out of no-where. I thought I was half way through when the credits started to roll leaving even more to be desired.All in all I realize that I'm being pretty critical but I mean if they were going to screw up the combat they could have at least given us a half way decent story. Oh well, hopefully The Witcher 3 will be better.

number of helpful: 21 of 40 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												Can't really recommed this one. The graphics are ok, but nothing to write home about considering it is supposedly an 'enhanced edition'. Story and lore seem to be dense from what I can tell after roughly two hours.Unfortunately, combat and interaction are breaking this game for me. Combat is extremely clumsy, it basically boils down to button-mashing, where at no point you have real control over your character, but rather mash buttons as fast as humanly possible and see what the game decides to do.Combat animations are basic, very basic, you'll sometimes stun an enemy wielding a shield, and when you strike him see a cut-scene like animation where your character delivers a killing blow to an enemy that does not have a shield.I started the game on 'hard' difficulty, and it took me about 10 minutes to discover how to exploit weaknesses in the AI to a point where I basically go through the fights either with no health loss, the other possible outcome being dying a rather cheesy death due to the no-control combat system.If I had to describe the combat system with one word, I'm sorry to say that word would be 'garbage', it pretty much ruins an otherwise decent game.Interaction is similary painful, there is one interaction key (left mouse), which is also one of your main fighting keys, leading to all sorts of unintentional interactions during combat, especially since the 'hot zones' for interactions are placed badly. This also inhibits game flow, you'll sometimes run towards a ledge, and then have to move around trying to find the interaction zone to actually climb it, there is no fluid 'run up to the ledge and climb it' like you'd expect.Got this very cheap on sale, if I had bought it for full price I'd say it was wasted money.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												I thoroughly enjoyed playing this game. I've completed the game four times now, and still have another play through to complete all of the possible outcomes for this game. The combat system takes a little bit of time to adjust to (mostly because you use one weapon for humans and a different weapon for monsters). However, after you get the hang of it, the game's true potential really comes to light. Amazingly developed characters, with a story told in Bardic fashion (by an actual Bard no less -- you meet him in the game). In short, I enjoyed this game so much, that I decided pre-ordering the third installment of this series would be worthwhile. *P.S. If you want to play the whole series, I strongly recommend playing the series in order.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												This game was amazing with a TRULY GREAT STORY. 92/100. Absolute definitely replayability with two major story arcs and many minor ones.It is Skyrim-like with action-RPG elements, but it is definitely not a true open-world game like Skyrim or The Witcher 3. You have pretty large areas for each chapter of the game and it works fantastically with all of the quests. I love the way that quests have multiple ways to resolve them and quests affect each other in a variety of ways. You actually need to listen (all voiced) and read the quest dialogue. This is not click-click-MMO quest type, thankfully!The combat is solid for action RPG but not perfect. I played with both mouse+keyboard and a PS4 controller. I preferred the controller by a long shot but the M+KB was definitely playable and I have seen opinions supporting both.The graphics are astonishing. If you have the card to handle it (r9 290/290x or 780/780ti) you will want to max it out AND edit the .ini file to increase view distances. Pop-in was not present at all when I did this, and distant objects were crisp and lush.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings picks up a couple of months after where the first game left off. Basically the story continues as Geralt of Rivia, a professional monster slayer, armed to the teeth (with everything an RPG protagonist need), traverses new locations and lands to thin the worlds monster and human population by a number.Almost everything is enhanced, and by almost everything I mean it, although there are some downsides. I'll list a few: Remember the clunky combat? Well not so clunky now, much more fluid, more fast paced and diverse. Better finishers (could be more of them), faster response and a well made mechanic. But the downside is lock-on, takes a while to get around it. I highly recommend playing with a gamepad.The alchemy and spells, haven't changed much, but still have seen much upgrading. Spells feel more powerful and the alchemy list has some new potions. Though inability to drink them mid-combat is unjustified.Meditate or should I say, wait, in Skyrim style, almost everywhere, but not too close to your enemies, duh.These are just some of the biggest additions in gameplay.Let's talk about the visuals. Not many games have been so atmospheric as The Witcher 2. The graphics are beautiful, though some might dislike the saturation in some places. It fits the world beautifuly and shows you great forests, mountains, cities and of course RPG's favorite - dungeons. And all this is accompanied by a great soundtrack, from haunting ambiances to rocking action and beautiful symphonic music.The story. If you have played the first Witcher, then you already know that Geralt is a master at getting into deep trouble. Well, this time around, kings are being killed, and Geralt is framed for killing one (Who saw that coming, right?). So Geralt sets out to find out the truth and clear his name in the process, also clearing out fools who try to stand in his way. Without telling any spoilers, there are many interesting surprises awaiting you, the plot does not feel dull at all.Now listen closely (or read). Choice - this time around it will impact the world and everyone around you heavily. For instance, choose your allegiance and the entire next chapter will be completely different, save for some of the main quests.So, altogether, the Witcher 2 took what was great in the first game and leveled it up to new heights, I highly recommend this game.9/10

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												One of the best RPG's I have experienced to date. Obviously the most standout thing on the surface is the graphics. While typical RPG's settle for bland and boring the world of The Witcher is colorful and well detailed. What really sells the game is the complex story telling, which features many different plot twists, and your choices actually influence the main storyline. Its not like Mass Effect where your choices don't mean anything to the storyline. Now the gameplay is difficult as long as you select normal or harder. You dont play as an OP badass, you can die after about 4 to 5 hits from about anything unless its a way lower level then you. Combat is hard, and you will need to plan ahead by drink potions before battle and seting up traps because you can drink potions while in battle and there is no health regen. How I would describe the openess of this game is semi-open world. You can travel freely among the land, but after completing enough main story quests you will travel to a new land, unable to go back to where you came from to complete unfinished side quests or anything you left back there. The game does this often so the best way to get everything done is sidequests first. It is a bit annoying to not be able to travel back but The Witcher 3 fixes this problem and is going full open world. Either way this a must buy for RPG fans and suckers for a good story, its a hell of a ride and the game doesnt treat you like an idiot, you will be presented with challenges that will make you s**t a brick. Now all i have to do is wait for The Witcher 3 and my life will be complete.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings picks up a couple of months after where the first game left off. Basically the story continues as Geralt of Rivia, a professional monster slayer, armed to the teeth (with everything an RPG protagonist need), traverses new locations and lands to thin the worlds monster and human population by a number.Almost everything is enhanced, and by almost everything I mean it, although there are some downsides. I'll list a few: Remember the clunky combat? Well not so clunky now, much more fluid, more fast paced and diverse. Better finishers (could be more of them), faster response and a well made mechanic. But the downside is lock-on, takes a while to get around it. I highly recommend playing with a gamepad.The alchemy and spells, haven't changed much, but still have seen much upgrading. Spells feel more powerful and the alchemy list has some new potions. Though inability to drink them mid-combat is unjustified.Meditate or should I say, wait, in Skyrim style, almost everywhere, but not too close to your enemies, duh.These are just some of the biggest additions in gameplay.Let's talk about the visuals. Not many games have been so atmospheric as The Witcher 2. The graphics are beautiful, though some might dislike the saturation in some places. It fits the world beautifuly and shows you great forests, mountains, cities and of course RPG's favorite - dungeons. And all this is accompanied by a great soundtrack, from haunting ambiances to rocking action and beautiful symphonic music.The story. If you have played the first Witcher, then you already know that Geralt is a master at getting into deep trouble. Well, this time around, kings are being killed, and Geralt is framed for killing one (Who saw that coming, right?). So Geralt sets out to find out the truth and clear his name in the process, also clearing out fools who try to stand in his way. Without telling any spoilers, there are many interesting surprises awaiting you, the plot does not feel dull at all.Now listen closely (or read). Choice - this time around it will impact the world and everyone around you heavily. For instance, choose your allegiance and the entire next chapter will be completely different, save for some of the main quests.So, altogether, the Witcher 2 took what was great in the first game and leveled it up to new heights, I highly recommend this game.9/10

												This game pretty quickly rose to be one of my favorites, it hit that high mark feeling I had previously had with Mass Effect 2. There are so many decisions and branching storylines, combat tactics and side quests that this game is easy to spend a lot of time exploring, definitely one of those games that got its hooks in me and wouldn't let go until completion. Cannot wait to play it!

Every area is gorgeous and challenging, and not knowing your way through a conversation could drastically change the tone of the game and the characters you play with. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												I've played my fair share of RPGs. Both the good, such as KOTOR, and the bad. Yes, I'm looking at you Mass Effect 3. I wouldn't consider myself a hardcore RPG player, but this has to be one of the best games I've ever played.First, the game itself is more of an action game with RPG elements. In this regard, it is a lot like ME, where all combat is realtime, and you aren't going to swing at someone, obviously hit them, and be told you missed, unlike its predecessor (although the first Witcher had miss animations). The gameplay is solid, and not quite like Mass Effect in that you have to keep moving instead of staying in cover. One nice thing is that you can glance at the lower left-hand corner to see the last few attacks and defends with their corrosponding damages.Next, the story is just plain awesome. I can't say much, other than while it was well written, the story is a bit on the shorter side, but no matter, as there are enough areas to explore and quests to finish to keep you playing for a long time.Also, the graphics are gorgeous, especially for 2011. They are, infact, much better than most games today.Finally, I'd say that if there is ANYTHING to complain about with this game, it would be that you cannot edit video settings or controls outside of the launcher. However, this is a minor complaint, and can easily be overlooked.Verdict: This game is a must have. As of the writing of this review, the game is only $4.00. I would gladly pay $40 for a game this well made.PS. For those of you who decide this game is worth the money. CD PROJEKT RED left a little "surprise" in the games files, concerning Triss Merigold. Let's just say many of you GUYS out there will probably be pleased with it, if you know what I mean...

Posted: July 10, 2011
												One of the finest RPGs I've played in years, The Witcher 2 is full of memorable moments filled with quirky characters, beautifully crafted cut-scenes and epic battles. Your story is driven by your choice, allowing for dramatic consequences and diverging game paths.This is the game where the visuals alone can win you over. There are times in the game where you'd just have to stop; take in the splendid vistas, and immerse yourself in the organic world of The Witcher. Aside from the awkward combat, and other minor annoyances; one can't be bothered when busy slaying giant kraken, ploughing Triss, brawling, or rescuing elven ♥♥♥♥♥s from burning buildings on maximum graphical settings. Recommended for traditional RPG lovers and for players who have the rig to run it on max ;)

												Witcher 2. The second installment in 'The Witcher' Series. Great game, great storyline. You continue where you left off in Witcher 1, but you won't be a complete stranger to combat now. It's eased up and loads of combo-ing fun! The game has the ability of picking up your previous choices from Witcher 1, so I *HIGHLY ADVISE* that you get Witcher 1 first, finish it, then start with this. The storyline is deep, loads of choices to be made.In the graphics department, this game nails it. Character models, weapons, terrain and environment, you name it, it looks great!Only problem is, it is heavy on your system. But, you can play on the lower settings. *Little* changes. Like the view distance. In short, it's a great game developed by CD Projekt RED worth the buy.Have fun!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												First off, know that The Witcher 2 is not a game that will hold your hand. If you're thinking about purchasing this, know that to get the most out of this game you need to be prepared to fully immerse yourself in the experience and pay attention to what is going in. This an adult, mature and complex game supported by rich lore and stunning visuals. The writing and storytelling is exceptional throughout and the moral ambiguity and choices are second to none. The gameplay, in particular the combat, is an acquired taste but offers a refreshing level of depth and potential for improvisation when compared to games in a similar genre. Sound design and voice acting is also of high quality, with the environments coming to life through impressive visual and audio support and characters each sporting distinct personalities and prejudices.It is also worth mentioning that if you have played the first Witcher game, your choices and gear will be reflected via an imported save in The Witcher 2, however the choices have limited effect and it is not necessary to play the first game to enjoy the second (however you will be at a slight disadvantage in some situations).In my honest opinion the experience as a whole is unparalleled, and The Witcher 2 is easily the most enjoyable and immersive RPG I have played in recent memory. I would also advise reading the books, in particular The Last Wish, Blood of Elves and Time of Contempt as these offer an interesting insight into the protagonist's past. But back to the game, overall I would highly recommend The Witcher 2 to anyone with at least a passing interest in the RPG genre, it is the definition of a complete gaming package with spectacular production values and a lasting impression.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												the witcher was a global phenom that apparently the US wasnt ready for during its original debut in 2007.  having read 5.5 of the original 7 novels i have a better understanding of the story to date, especially having played the first game.  but none of that matters as, introduced in the first game, our hero geralt, has no memory of his past, ie the novels.  either way, the witcher series is about the story of geralt of rivia, a witcher or professional monster hunter, who is dragged into a twisting and turning story of political bull.sh.it that he wants nothing to do with, but unfortunitly cant escape.Unlike the first game of the series, the graphics are far more refined, the story is much more cohesive, complex and inline with what original stories would lead to, and is exactly what CDProjekt were hoping to create with the first game.  not only does choice matter, it is essential to the very core of the game.  every decision has a consequence, whether you see it now or at the end of your journey.  this is the type of game that bioware has wet dreams about but instead sells you a half♥♥♥♥♥copy of.  litteraly the 2nd half of the game takes completely different paths depending on a not so simple choice in the 1st chapter.one of my personal favorite features is "survivor mode"...dont be fooled, combat can be extremely difficult in this game, but entering the arena is a nice change of pace that will give you some, albiet, over exaggerated practice, but it is a great time killer that will keep you going in the hopes taht you can get your name of the leader board.  highly addictive and extremely punishing to the say the least, especially at higher difficulty levels.sure theres flaws, very few games are without but this is a game, that even if you didnt play the first, will have you from beginning to end leaving you begging for more, and unlike most games that claim to be of the same ilk....*cough* mass effect, there actually is more to do that you can not do because of the decisions that you made the first time around.Buy this game now, especially being 5$ as it will give you some back info to Witcher 3.  p.s. if you can get your hands on teh novels, they are fantastic and really give a detailed backstory on most characters, especially geralt and his close companions.  trust me you wont regret this purchase <3

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												I'm not typically compelled to review games I purchase on Steam, but the Witcher 2 so thoroughly surprised me I had to say something.I had long avoided the Witcher series out of dislike for the apparently cliche main character, but as there was an absence of good RPGs to play this summer I picked them up during the sale on a lark. The first game I played a couple chapters of, but ultimately couldn't get into it; I had played Neverwinter Nights to death earlier in my life, and the similarities of the Aurora engine were just so strong that I found myself burnt out.So I booted up the Witcher 2. I was instantaenously amazed by the graphics, despite the game's age. The visual fidelity worked to support what felt like a living, breathing world, and within the first hour I was already hooked on the story. The characters, while suffering from stiff facial animations, are backed up by well-written dialogue and quality voice-acting. There is a moment early in the game where Geralt re-unites with his companions in an inn and, while the "party meeting around a table" is a genre staple, the presentation was so well done I felt like I was in a Lord of the Rings scene.The game's mechanics aren't quite as engrossing as its narrative. The combat is servicable, and feels smooth and well-animated for the most part; targeting hitches, stiff dodging, and difficulty landing magic attacks do weigh down the experience. Likewise, the inventory management and map menus are frustratingly clumsy given their importance to the game. The combat, movement, and interface were all clearly designed for a gamepad, but I found the radial quick-menu lacking in precision; often, I had to resort to the d-pad to navigate, rather than just flicking a stick in the required direction. These quibbles can be just enough to pull you out of the game for a little longer than you'd like, but the environments and the story will always pull you back in. It's not open-world in the sense that Skyrim is; areas have defined (though branching) paths through them. Thankfully they are laid out naturally enough to stop you from feeling like you're on a theme-park ride dictated by arbitrary invisible fences and, while your mileage may vary, I found that the relatively rigid environment was offset by the narrative freedom. You may not be able to go everywhere you can see, but nowhere you go feels empty or lifeless.Lastly, just to address the issue that initially put me off this series; no, there is no character creation. Geralt is Geralt: You can't make him an elf or dwarf, or change his class or gender, or give him a haircut. You can allocate points to swordsmanship, magic, or alchemy, but you'll still always be a Witcher. But as the decisions you make start to shape the world around you, he will very much start to feel like your character, and in ways much more significant than a different name or appearance could provide.To sum it all up: This is a well-polished and engrossing game with a strong narrative, visuals that are both technically and artistically beautiful, and a world so well-realized that even accidentally unequipping your pants for the 20th time can't take away from it. If you think you might have even the slightest interest in trying this game, buy it. You will fall in love.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												An improvement over the first game, although not in all areas.The game's story and characters are a continuation and improvement of the great work from the first game. Geralt's circle of friends have even more of a role to play this time around and join him more often. The game also goes into a lot more detail about The Wild Hunt and Geralt's past. In terms of quests, it does feel like there are a lot less but the ones that are there are more interesting and more involved. The final monster contract, though, features some incredibly dumb puzzle-solving and there are a few quests that you cannot complete unless you keep objects from earlier chapters, such as getting stuck with a dumb tattoo. Pro-tip: if you get the tattoo and don't like it, immediately get the stuff required to remove it.In terms of graphics, it's obviously an improvement. Characters and the voice acting are much more unique and diverse; no more reusing the same handful of models/voices over and over (although a little of that remains, usually with people you can't really talk to). The lighting is appaling though. I spent most of the first chapter fidling with the brightness controls because, either, every dungeon or night was clear as day (who needs Cat?!) or every day time scene or interior was overly dark (brunette Triss). The world also feels much smaller then the first game (although obviously more detailed), and ridiculously small compared to something like Skyrim (or even DAI). This seems to be the the trade-off for prettier graphics.The interface is horrible, at least for someone using the 360 controller. You have to access the main menu to get to things like your journal, level up, map, etc, and then it spits you back into the game world afterwards. Annoying if you want to keep accessing those pages. For example, a common one is looking up info on a monster. For some unknown bloody reason it's split into two areas, there is (a little) info on the bestiary page of the journal and also (the important info) hidden on the "knowledge" page hidden within the "attributes" page hidden within the character development screen! Inventory management is also a pain due to unnecessary difficulty of trying to figure out what you currently have selected. Button prompts are missing on certain screens (most noticeably on the poker screen - it's Y to select dice, you're welcome). The quick menu/radial wheel also leaves something to be desired. You can tell it's the devs first time creating something with controller support. Although it's hard to forgive the fact they haven't addressed these problems in the years since release. The game also creates a new save each time you save, leaving you with literally hundreds of saves and slowing down the game! Also, the game constantly updates quest info, character bios, etc. with interesting writings by Dandelion, yet it is an absolute chore to constantly go back into the menu and scan every entry, slowly scrolling down to the bottom, to see if the last thing entered is something new. It's interesting writing that feels like it goes to waste. Perhaps an option to press a button, say the "BACK" button, to quickly jump to the new bit of info would be nice. And, finally, for those using a controller you are forced to take everything when looting. Which leads to a lot of unneccesary inventory management.The combat is improved, you do feel (at times) like a badass swordsman. But it does often feel like you're just substituting the silly combos of the first game for silly combat rolls and waiting for counters (unlockable "Ripostes"). Once again it feels like certain areas of the game aren't worth the effort. Traps didn't seem particularly useful, since enemies either avoid them or interupt your placement just as often as they take damage from one. Bombs and daggers often seem to do less than you'd expect and are easy to miss with. Generally, they're there to spam if groups threaten to overwhelm you. I found the signs to be disappointing as well. I barely used anything besides Quen (and that barely survives a hit). Ignii seemed to do very little damage. Aard was good for little more than blowing down brick walls. Yrden did help a lot early on, chiefly in a boss fight and with some big, tough, charging enemies but I barely used it past the first chapter. I think part of this has do with the way character development is handled. You have 3 main branches: 1 for swords, 1 for signs, 1 for alchemy. and I think this split is unnecessary and annoying. You are given so few perks in the game you'll only be able to master one branch (which leaves almost nothing for the others). This leaves a rather one note Geralt (who is supposed to be a well-rounded master Witcher). I think it'd be better to have mixed branches with perks from all the Witcher disciplines (sword/sign/alchemy). Maybe name/design them around the three Witcher schools: Wolf, Viper, Griffon. Then no matter where you go you'll have to chance to be well-rounded and dabble in all areas, yet still have a ton of choice.So, despite its flaws (which I hope are addressed in the third game), I recommend the game. It's a great story with great characters and has a lot of interesting choices for you to make, just expect the odd frustration or disappointment.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												The Witcher 2 is by far THE best game I've played since TESV:Skyrim.  I've had this game sitting in my library for a long time, mainly because every time I attempted the game I played the Tutorial (tutorials never seem like a bad idea) and I'd be turned off by it instantly.  But again and again, I'd hear people talk about what a great game this was online, and so I finally forced myself to put a couple hours in before setting it down.  And I'm damn glad I did.  I can't believe it has taken me this long but I'm ten hours into a save and loving every second of it.The game is your classic RPG, melee and magic, but with one large difference: the choices you make actually matter.  I'm not talking Skyrim, where if you do this quest you get this item, or that quest you get that item, but rather on a vast scale, where events will unfold completely differently based on what you say or do.  Combine that with amazing graphics; maps that are intriguing, stimulating to explore, and visually stunning; characters that you can actually connect with and understand; and a complex story that has kept me craving more like each new Game of Thrones episode.My biggest problem with the game is that it has some clunky, unintuitive menus, but after an hour or so you'll understand it to the point that it's barable.  I still have some trouble navigating it, but whatever.The game is absolutely one of the most unique and awesome games I have played.  To those wondering, you can play this game without playing the first one.  It's not necessary as TW2 does a very good job of keeping a self-contained story.  Do yourself a favor: stop reading this review and buy this damn game.  It's the one you've wanted to play your entire life without knowing it.

												10/10 This game is a huge step forward from the first and it is B-E-A-Utiful.This game blew my mind in graphics. It has that style where it looks so real that it can't be real. The Combat isn't just RMB RMB LMB, it requires tactics, planning ahead, observation, and dodging which keeps the combat entertaining. The Witcher 2 takes place where our favorite witcher, Geralt of Rivia, left off. I highly recommend playing the first one. It carries over weapons, armor, and depends on how you look at it, the signs (You actually have to find them in the first Witcher). The finishers are putting a cherry on top of a already perfect ice cream sunday. The few moments of stealth in this game are fun a challenging. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												This is the second adventure of Geralt of Rivia, and it really is a magnificent sequel and a darn good RPG.What are the biggest changes between this and Witcher 1? Well, first there's the visuals - everything's gorgeous now, and Zoltan no longer has a bizarre unfocused look in his eyes that makes him seem permanently stoned. I spent a ton of time just panning the camera around taking in all the scenery, and I was only playing this on LOW settings. Control-wise, the combat system has been revamped. It's still occasionally clunky when it comes to switching between Witcher signs/bombs/traps, but this awkwardness eventually goes away after a few hours of play. Overall, everything feels more natural (when played with a controller) and skill-based than the clicky combat of the first game. The different stances are out and now it's action-orientated, and you've got to roll around a lot and dodge blows with precision. The game is tough at first because Geralt starts as a weakling compared to his foes, and the in-game tutorial does a pretty crap job of explaining the combat, so try the game out on Easy or Normal difficulty first until you get the hang of things and level up Geralt to non-weakling status. (Use the Quen sign as much as possible and try specializing in Swordmaster skills like roll and block if you're having trouble in the beginning.) Normal difficult in the Witcher 2 = hard difficulty in a lot of other games, so be aware.And then there's the story. The plot in Witcher 1 occasionally seemed like it was rehashing the most memorable of Geralt's adventures from the novels with some odd discrepancies; ie: Triss' personality was more like Yennefer's than anything else. Witcher 2 fixes this by making the characters more in line with their book counterparts and crafting a story that is very political and seems like a natural extension of the books rather than a "best of" compilation. The kings of the Northern Kingdoms are being killed by assailants from a forgotten Witcher school, and much of Chapters 2 and 3 focus on the importance of the Pontar Valley, an area that borders the more notable kingdoms in Geralt's world. A lot of names are dropped and places referenced, which can be confusing to newbies that haven't read the books or played the first game, so referring to the in-menu Journal is a must. Lore fanatics will eat this up; impatient players perhaps not as much.As long as you've got time and patience, the Witcher 2 will eat up many, many hours of your life. Best of all, this is one of the few games I know of that's really worth replaying - a critical decision at the end of Chapter 1 will COMPLETELY change Chapters 2 and 3 for you. Lengthy RPGs are usually low on the replay list for me...but I'm planning on a completely new playthrough on Hard difficulty just to check out Iorveth's path, so that's saying something.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												I got this game for the price of a coffee and a dognut. 17 hours later, after finishing the game, I feel like I bought the Mona Lisa, or a Rembrandt.This is not a game, this is a work of art. It's an experience which floods all your senses, keeps you on your toes and has you wanting more and more all the way until the credits roll and beyond. And the best part is you get to shape it the way you want. There's no good or bad in this game, it's just choice and consequences and believe me, your choices actually matter. Some of them, you might not even notice the effect (but it's there) while others completely change how future events unfold.Still, this is a game, and a game needs proper gameplay to support the whole thing. Thankfully, this game nailed it. Combat is very fluid and quite strategic. It's more than just mindless button mash. I played it on easy because I don't play games for the challenge anymore, rather for the experience, yet I encountered enough challenging situations.Do I recommend this game? Definitely! I can't recommend it enough. Even if you're not into RPGs, heck, even if you're not into fantasy games in general, you should definitely give this one a try. You will not regret it.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												I came to this one extremely late, and it's a shame, because it has quickly become one of my favorite RPGs. While the combat feels clunky, and for some reason the game chugged on my upper mid-range hardware, I cannot deny just how engrossing the game is. It has a strange way of pulling me into it's world in a way that few other games can. I actually felt like what I did had some sort of weight and importance in the game's world at large. I found myself becoming infuriated with how certain characters acted, and how much their actions would make my goal harder to attain. And the frustrating combat bits (I can name two boss battles off the top of my head that are just a slog) are so dwarfed by how well the story is told that I pushed through in that sitting, just to see what story was to follow. This is of course opposed to my usual strategy of trying twice, dying twice, throwing my controller out the window and coming back when I could buy a new one.All in all, Witcher 2 is an experience that I'm extremely grateful to have had, and I absolutely cannot wait to play the next installment.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2012
												Now that I've finally gotten a chance to finish it, my prediction from many months ago turned out to be true: it's the strongest competition I've found for Bastion for GOTY 2011 (edit: since displaced by To the Moon, but still in my top three). Yeah, I know it's the end of 2012. I'm a little behind.The presentation of everything is excellent. It all looks and sounds great, and a lot of thought went into the way the world is presented to you and how you interact with things. I didn't feel quite the surprise of some of the delayed consequences of decisions made like in the first game, but they matter just as much for a different reason this time around. The game is a bit shorter, but depending on what you say and do, a huge amount of it changes completely, not just a little bit of dialog here and there or the ending cutscene like some games. You have a major effect on the world, for better or worse.

												I have spent a better part of 90 hours on this game and I love absolutely everything about it. So much has been improved since the first game, I dont even know where to begin. Pros:Beautiful world everywhere you turn. Seemless combat when you level up.Amazing story that follows so well from the first game.Vast amount of improvements from the first game. Lore is everywhere and when you think you have ran out of things to do, someone else runs for your helpCons;The story though deep, seems to end fast.The map size is misleading for the few towns you actually vist.Overall I can say that I loved every minute of this game, I can say without a doubt that I am very excited with The Witcher 3 Wild Hunt, I would highly recommend this game to anyone who loves open world RPG and is a fan of the series.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												After some tinkering, I finally got it to where the game feels fluid and I don't get motion sick.I used FC2 (which admittedly, I don't like the whole package as there's some balancing issues, but the base game animations feel clunky and irritate the living hell out of me)and FOV1.1I've always heard people say that the choices matter in this game, but I was thinking more along the lines of Skyrim or another open world RPG. No, they don't even compare, the choices you make in the Witcher can change the outcome of your game entirely. I've just finished my first playthrough and am eager to  jump back in for another to see what happens when I make different choices.You'll be pulling your hair out with some of the choices you made and glad you made others.For someone that does not like politics, similar to Geralt, I enjoyed this game very much.The Witcher is the political fanaticism version of Lord of the Rings, story is everything.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												10/10 This game is a huge step forward from the first and it is B-E-A-Utiful.This game blew my mind in graphics. It has that style where it looks so real that it can't be real. The Combat isn't just RMB RMB LMB, it requires tactics, planning ahead, observation, and dodging which keeps the combat entertaining. The Witcher 2 takes place where our favorite witcher, Geralt of Rivia, left off. I highly recommend playing the first one. It carries over weapons, armor, and depends on how you look at it, the signs (You actually have to find them in the first Witcher). The finishers are putting a cherry on top of a already perfect ice cream sunday. The few moments of stealth in this game are fun a challenging. Now this isn't a 'Dark Souls' so it is possible to beat, ha ha, but it was still rough on normal. I almost played this game twice in a row until I realized I needed to finish things before end of summer :p.Absolutely fantastic game. Highly recommend playing the first one before this one.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												Unforgiving combat that emphasize strategy over button-mashing; unforgettable characters who are morally ambiguous in very human ways; and player choices that actually matter, makes The Witcher 2 a fantastic role-playing experience.The Enhanced Edition has fixed some of the balancing issues from the first release and filled in some of the story, helping the overall pacing and to bridge the three acts together in a smoother way.Fresh players might be helped by the new tutorial at the start of the game, as this is a game that has some old-school sensibilities in that it kind of assumes that you've read the game manual.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												This game is just a delight from start to finish. This kind of mature, thoughtful, and immersive RPG really boots the Elder Scrolls series into a bin and kicks it down a steep incline. The story has so many nuances to it, the combat is satisfying, and you really get involved in Geralt's dilemmas and especially the world. And, to top it all off, in-game decisions that ACTUALLY MATTER. And  most don't have a clear good/bad choice, which again sets Witcher 2 apart from most RPGS; you aren't a straight good guy or a straight evil guy, you're just a guy, albiet a white-haired guy with super magic powers, sorting through multiple shades of grey. I love and can remember almost all of the characters from this game, and theres such a great array of emotion in the game: laughter, excitement, misery, and sheer honest to god wonder. This mostly comes from the gorgeously designed environments. If this game was a woman, she'd be way out of my league. So yeah, if you have even the slightest interest in RPGs, this is a must-buy. And if you're already an RPG enthusiast looking for something a little more mature and thoughtful than Skyrim, this is even more of a must-buy.Roll on Witcher 3!

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												I know the book series, so I was intrigued by the games. I liked the first Witcher game so I went straight for the third one and I've totally fallen for it. Buuut, the third game's story has many references to the second game and here starts the plight. I mean for me this game was the worst way to spend 2euros on sale. The graphics are nice, the story is more than enjoyable, familiar character brought back some good memories of the book and then... then, there's the player interface, the combat system, the sign casting, those bloody QTEs - all of these feel well cumbersome, like some kind of warm up for the Witcher3. I know, hardcore gamers might start b*tching about me whining and that game is just challenging. Well yeah, it is a frustration challenge of totally unenjoyable cumbersome gameplay. And I am so glad I managed through it on easy difficulty, so I could start a replay of Witcher3 on deathmarch. Oh, that being said, the save system is sh*te as well.  I spared Letho in the end and I have the manual (and automatic) save file with him at the end, but somehow, that save is not visible for the third game, ugh. And I am not replaying this game, ugh .Nevertheless, I am recommending the game (with a sour face, mind you). Just get it on a price discount.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												When I first tried out this game, I was overwhelmed by the combat mechanics and UI. I had a bad first impression and didn't try it out again for a long time. Having read some great reviews by others, I decided it was worth giving a second chance. I cranked up the difficulty to hard (now I want to try Dark) and finished my first playthrough yesterday. It was a lot of fun! I misjudged the game and found that while there are some learning curves to become good at group combat, this is a game that can stand out next to other RPG series like The Elder Scrolls, Fable, and Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic.I can't and won't directly compare this game to Skyrim, because I feel they inhabit different subgenres. Skyrim is more about the open world, exploration, and freedom of action, while The Witcher 2 excels at storytelling, well-scripted combat encounters, boss fights, and living the life of a monster-hunter.The only thing I wish was different about The Witcher 2 is even more monster contracts. There is just something exciting about fighting with silver sword and using alchemy to brew the right potions and oils for the task at hand. I can't wait until The Witcher 3!If you enjoy games like Skyrim, Fable, or KOTOR, give this game a try!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												The Witcher 2 is one of the best fantasy epics I've played for a while. Dark writing that will compel you to push forth and delve into the story; going so far as to consume your days! And then, in the final moments of the game, the narrative will have you begging for more, making you wish the game was longer--or that Witcher 3 would come sooner! (P.S. The game is over 20 hours long, yet I wanted more. Yes, the story is that gripping) The game also treats you with some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ maturity, CDProjekt Red doesn't ♥♥♥♥♥ out here, the game contains a lot of sex--and it's magnificent; especially when other game developers don't have the balls to go there, or when they do, they often don't have the balls to see it through to the end. Sufficed to say, all those who haven't played the previous game (of which I am one) will,  at-first, find themselves lost. The game will try to get you up to speed, however you'll feel very lost at the beginning of the game. But soon you'll be caught up in a web of conspiricy and intrigue that, when the jarring moments of exposition pretaining to the first game come, it will do little to sour your mood, and soon, you'll be back into the fray of the story. Also, choices, choices that bloody matter! Do you know how refreshing that is? Yes? Then jump on in!The gameplay is burtal and unforgiving if you are unready--plus the saving system isn't very... lenient with you. So if you screw  up and you haven't saved, oh boy you're in hot water! Enemies will challenge you, hoards of them can be just as effective as a boss. Which, to mention the bosses, yeah, they're hard too! Especially the last. However, I'm just speaking from my own experience here, it will greatly vary by user ability and game difficulty. (I can imagine that, after playing this bloody romp on normal and dying a couple of times, that on hard it's a bloody nightmare.) The presentation of the game isn't too shabby either, bearing in mind it's been 2 years from release, it couldn't look any better; sure in some areas texture can appear flat or certain other graphical annoyances may appear, however it will do little to deter you from playing! Character models are detailed to the level that you would expect. Glitches are minimal--although some may make themselves apparent. The game has a highly fine level of polish that will be apparent as you play through the wonderful game; the craftmanship that has gone into this game is insane, CDProjektRed are masters of making video games, so you're in safe hands.Convinced yet? I should bloody hope so. If this game is on sale and you're reading this, I can only ask why? Why are you wasting you time? This is such a great game that any [reasonable] cost is well worth it! Especially on your nice fancy PC rig. So, stop reading and add this game to your collection now! You won't regret a single moment, a single dime, that you'll have poured into this game.

												This game is tied with Skyrim as being the best game(s) I have ever played. "Beautiful", is not even close to describing the look, sound, and feel of this game. The graphics and scenary are matched perfectly with the orchestra and soundtrack that barrage you from start to finish. You will feel as if you're in another world, and another time. This game makes you not just escape into the world, but the story truly drives the entire gameplay and turns you into the Witcher. Where every action and choice you make has a consequence and alters the story, you will without a doubt find this game breathtaking and providing you with countless hours of gameplay, and amazing replayability, where one different choice, can take you on an entirely separate journey.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												The Witcher 2 can be summed up as being everything that Dragon Age 2 failed to be. It's storyline is great, the dialogue is awesome, the characters are likeable and memorable, the sex scenes are mature (with uncesored frontal nude and all), and the graphics are gorgeous (and you might need a seven page configuration guide AND a third party application in order to make it run decently on a GTX550ti like mine). But the "It's Toasted" of the game is it's combat system. It's hard, and if you jump head on into fights you're going to die almost always. The mechanics are good and your character is very resourceful, so as long as you're not caught off guard you always stand a good chance.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												The Witcher 2, this game is as good an RPG as it is compared to lots of other RPG games.First of all, the sight to see in this game is marvelous, some might get mad at me for rating games on its graphics, but its graphics is worth more than a part of the 'realistic' games out there, both the scenes and the gameplay. Even having it on low quality has its charm too.Gameplay, I had troubles in combat the first time I tried it out on the tutorial section, it's so tricky to use, but you get used to it soon or later, and will able to use it to the max. The interface is minimalistic and the inventory is well made. One thing I love about the inventory is the fact that we're able to sort it according to weight multiplying to the amount the item has, very useful for inventory weight based games (which a lot doesn't have this feature). Crafting, enhancing, and trading is also well balanced.The story, I haven't advanced that much in the game, but the plot is interesting indeed. Aside from the main story there are also lots of other quests to play through.ConclusionBeautiful Hack & Slash RPG Game, well balanced gameplay features and interesting story to follow.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2012
												Now that I've finally gotten a chance to finish it, my prediction from many months ago turned out to be true: it's the strongest competition I've found for Bastion for GOTY 2011 (edit: since displaced by To the Moon, but still in my top three). Yeah, I know it's the end of 2012. I'm a little behind.The presentation of everything is excellent. It all looks and sounds great, and a lot of thought went into the way the world is presented to you and how you interact with things. I didn't feel quite the surprise of some of the delayed consequences of decisions made like in the first game, but they matter just as much for a different reason this time around. The game is a bit shorter, but depending on what you say and do, a huge amount of it changes completely, not just a little bit of dialog here and there or the ending cutscene like some games. You have a major effect on the world, for better or worse.

												After some tinkering, I finally got it to where the game feels fluid and I don't get motion sick.I used FC2 (which admittedly, I don't like the whole package as there's some balancing issues, but the base game animations feel clunky and irritate the living hell out of me)and FOV1.1I've always heard people say that the choices matter in this game, but I was thinking more along the lines of Skyrim or another open world RPG. No, they don't even compare, the choices you make in the Witcher can change the outcome of your game entirely. I've just finished my first playthrough and am eager to  jump back in for another to see what happens when I make different choices.You'll be pulling your hair out with some of the choices you made and glad you made others.For someone that does not like politics, similar to Geralt, I enjoyed this game very much.The Witcher is the political fanaticism version of Lord of the Rings, story is everything.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2015
												While I didn't manage to complete Witcher 1 (after ~17hrs of gameplay) due to issues I have with the combat system, Witcher 2 is on a completely different level. Even though it was released in 2011, the revamped Enhanced Edition puts the game's graphics on par with current games. As I stepped into the beautiful fantasy world, I was quickly drawn to the lovable characters (with reappearances from W1) and interesting story that at multiple turns forces you to make decisions that have drastic consequences on following events.One of the most important choices you have to make is towards the end of Chapter 1, thereby splitting the game into 2 major fractions each with its own development. Therefore, I highly recommend playing W2 twice. Doing so will allow you to earn steam achievements from both fractions and also to make more informed choices when making the gamesave transfer (/quick decision recap if you lose the gamesaves) for The Witcher 3 (HYYPPPPEEEEEE!!!!!). My first playthrough was 20 hrs, and a second should be much shorter with the option to skip most cutscenes prior to that decision.While there are many positives about the game such as its beautiful graphics, good voice-acting, a larger variety of character models (much needed upgrade from W1) etc, there are some things I didn't like too. For example, I felt that the door/ area transition is pretty clunky, especially when fighting around an opened door and your character moves to the next room when he gets too close. Also, there is a significant lag time after an enemy/ monster is defeated and issuing the next action, such as picking up loot, opening doors, or climbing cliffs.Other than the above-mentioned negatives, which are actually quite reminiscent of old RPGs, the game is really good and a must-play before Witcher 3. I would recommend skipping W1 and start with this title instead.9.5/10Edit (after 2nd playthrough): The game autosaves A LOT and the gamesaves are LARGE. For those wishing to play the game twice, remember to clear your gamesaves or at a certain point a well known bug will occur and cause the game to keep crashing. It will even crash when you restart and select 'load' in the main menu. Other than this, my 2nd playthough while selecting the other fraction was still very enjoyable, as Chapter 2 was very very different.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12
												This game is good, no doubt, but it suffers so much that at times its not enjoyable. The combat is very clunky and at times just doesn't work right and theres very little differentiation in how to defeat enemies besides block/parry/dodge/spam. Theres almost nothing to do with all of the crafting items that you get, items from merchants are way too overpriced, armor except for the chest pieces are virtually the same things The voice acting is super off in some parts and is pretty bad at times. The bosses are by far the absolute dogshit wrost boss fights I have ever encoutered in a video game. The first fight with the Kingslayer is unfair and boring, the fight with the Draug is monotonous and dumb because he'll spam a ranged attack over and over, and the fight with the dragon is literally just a roll back->roll forward->attack->repeat. The signs except for Quen, Igni, and Yren (or however you spell it) are absolutely useless in my opinion. The skill tree is far too big for such a short game, as I ended up being around level 35 when I beat the game. The potion system is very poorly done, because on your first playthrough you have no idea what is going to be up ahead, and therefore you don't know what potions to have used and probably die as a result.Despite all the negatives, the game also does have its good parts as well. The soundtrack is very well done, it has beautiful tunes, but they're overused at times and I probably didn't even hear half of them. The graphics are beautiful for the time, even though I wasn't able to run it on max settings it still looked good and held a very stable FPS. There's a good story, but it is easy to get lost quickly if you don't pay attention or didn't play the first game (like me). I do like that they added a toxicity to the potions so you can't just chug everything at once and become a sterioded mess.Overall, I'd have to give it a 6/10. I have high hopes for The Witcher 3 whenever I get to playing it, but I'd say to skip out on this entry on the series unless you're looking for backstory.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												I know the book series, so I was intrigued by the games. I liked the first Witcher game so I went straight for the third one and I've totally fallen for it. Buuut, the third game's story has many references to the second game and here starts the plight. I mean for me this game was the worst way to spend 2euros on sale. The graphics are nice, the story is more than enjoyable, familiar character brought back some good memories of the book and then... then, there's the player interface, the combat system, the sign casting, those bloody QTEs - all of these feel well cumbersome, like some kind of warm up for the Witcher3. I know, hardcore gamers might start b*tching about me whining and that game is just challenging. Well yeah, it is a frustration challenge of totally unenjoyable cumbersome gameplay. And I am so glad I managed through it on easy difficulty, so I could start a replay of Witcher3 on deathmarch. Oh, that being said, the save system is sh*te as well.  I spared Letho in the end and I have the manual (and automatic) save file with him at the end, but somehow, that save is not visible for the third game, ugh. And I am not replaying this game, ugh .Nevertheless, I am recommending the game (with a sour face, mind you). Just get it on a price discount.

												Very interesting game. Story is sophisticated and combat makes you feel like a bad♥♥♥♥♥while challanging you. There is a lack of customization for combat but thats actually a good thing. The develoapers maneged to improve one combat style very well instead of doing 3 or 4 that lack. The combat is basically a mix of traps, throwable weapons, potions, spells, and simple but never boring sword fighting. On easier diffuculty you only have to worry about doing one or 2 of those things right, but on harder difficultys you need to pay attention to all of them because you will need them. You can craft everything that you will need for combat using simple mix of ingrediants from the world. The story is very mature. If you are interested political conflicts that are dealt with in old fashioned ways than this is the game for you. Characters are all very well put and you will never forget a face in the game. The main character is a bad♥♥♥♥♥ filled with chivelary type of guy but never feeling like he was just made to save the world he has his own problems and he wouldnt mind puting saving the world aside. Overall the game is a piece of gold. a must for any fan of RPGs or well made single player stories.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2012
												Granted I haven't played the original Witcher due to the combat system in it, Witcher 2 is a lot better than its predecessor. The continuation of "multiple" paths in the story line to effect the overall outcome continues and with the well expected conclusion of the trilogy coming out soon, it's even funner now to replay through it again and relive the adventure.The storyline is intriguing and while some actions are locked in place, the overall feeling that you can change the environment is there. Most of the characters have advanced back storys that help add to them to make them feel more than just a single random person throwing quests at you and you don't have to kill the trolls!The combat style supports a miriad of different techniques such as support caster builds, ranged assassin builds, stealth attacks, straight out melee sluggers, and of course the balanced approach for all skill sets. The only thing really missing is the fact you still cannot use a dedicated ranged weapon such as a crossbow or longbow. While I am a fan of swordsmanship, there have been times when having a crossbow would of been a godsend.The gameplay mechanics are smooth and 99% of the time, balanced and fair. It's rare that I find a glitched area or a zone that results in a reset as in some games such as Fallout where you can get stuck on a cliff or stuck in mid-air while jumping. Visual appearances are, even on lower settings very eye-catching and the developers did a very good job in making sure that the game looks as good as it plays.Overall score: 8/10+ Good storyline and solid character builds+ Balanced combat styles that are both unique and worth using+ You can actually for the most part, stealth through the game if you really want a challenge+ Both routes can be set to a good or bad ending instead of fixed- Combat can be unforgiving when barrel rollingDefinetly would recommend this game to anyone who has played and enjoyed Skyrim, Assassins Creed, previous Witcher title, Tomb Raider, Fallout. Worth the time it takes to play and definetly worth playing through four times (both good endings, and both bad endings)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												It is an amazing game with an amazing story. I highly recommend the use of a controller for this one, unlike the first game. The battle mechanic is also an improvement and more streamlined than the original. The world is pretty open with plenty of sidequests, while at the same time having a strong linear structure to it. This fact has its pros and cons. The pro being that the story is incredibly strong and compelling, so the player should never lose interest (even when sidequesting). The con being that the game tends to be shorter than its predecessor (about 10 hours shorter for me) and the explorative breath of the game is simply not as large as the original. The mix of open world & strong linear story elements that the original had was simply more well-rounded compared to this sequel. Nevertheless, The Witcher 2 is an excellent game.For those who might be wondering whether playing the first game is a must before this one, the answer is: Yes. There is a meta-plot in this series, which leads up to the third game. And the meta-plot begins its origins and explanations in the original game. The second game also simply doesn't introduce the main characters or explain them all that well to newcomers. While you can read up on the info in the game's interior journal logs, it does not make up for not playing through the original game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2012
												Granted I haven't played the original Witcher due to the combat system in it, Witcher 2 is a lot better than its predecessor. The continuation of "multiple" paths in the story line to effect the overall outcome continues and with the well expected conclusion of the trilogy coming out soon, it's even funner now to replay through it again and relive the adventure.The storyline is intriguing and while some actions are locked in place, the overall feeling that you can change the environment is there. Most of the characters have advanced back storys that help add to them to make them feel more than just a single random person throwing quests at you and you don't have to kill the trolls!The combat style supports a miriad of different techniques such as support caster builds, ranged assassin builds, stealth attacks, straight out melee sluggers, and of course the balanced approach for all skill sets. The only thing really missing is the fact you still cannot use a dedicated ranged weapon such as a crossbow or longbow. While I am a fan of swordsmanship, there have been times when having a crossbow would of been a godsend.The gameplay mechanics are smooth and 99% of the time, balanced and fair. It's rare that I find a glitched area or a zone that results in a reset as in some games such as Fallout where you can get stuck on a cliff or stuck in mid-air while jumping. Visual appearances are, even on lower settings very eye-catching and the developers did a very good job in making sure that the game looks as good as it plays.Overall score: 8/10+ Good storyline and solid character builds+ Balanced combat styles that are both unique and worth using+ You can actually for the most part, stealth through the game if you really want a challenge+ Both routes can be set to a good or bad ending instead of fixed- Combat can be unforgiving when barrel rollingDefinetly would recommend this game to anyone who has played and enjoyed Skyrim, Assassins Creed, previous Witcher title, Tomb Raider, Fallout. Worth the time it takes to play and definetly worth playing through four times (both good endings, and both bad endings)

												Witcher 2. The second installment in 'The Witcher' Series. Great game, great storyline. You continue where you left off in Witcher 1, but you won't be a complete stranger to combat now. It's eased up and loads of combo-ing fun! The game has the ability of picking up your previous choices from Witcher 1, so I *HIGHLY ADVISE* that you get Witcher 1 first, finish it, then start with this. The storyline is deep, loads of choices to be made.In the graphics department, this game nails it. Character models, weapons, terrain and environment, you name it, it looks great!Only problem is, it is heavy on your system. But, you can play on the lower settings. *Little* changes. Like the view distance. In short, it's a great game developed by CD Projekt RED worth the buy.Have fun!

												I'm not sure why the game's rating is 88. I honestly believe that this game deserves a full 100.Why? The story itself is great! A mix of fantasy and political feud accompanied by a mature plot / narrative will suck you in. The graphics are great, the soundtrack is to die for and the main character is someone who you can empathized with. That's Geralt of Rivia for you.Many say that the gameplay is hard but I beg to differ. This game is NOT like Dark Souls difficulty. It is however, realistic in the sense that you probably would have a hard time beating 3 people instead of 1. The game promotes you to use ALL of your abilities properly and smartly. It may sound difficulty but it isn't. Once you know how you maneuver your character, then you would know exactly what to do.I can't emphasize how much I love this game. Probably one of my top 3 RPGs of all time. PLAY THIS GAME.
