number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												I think by now there's plenty out there discussing what's in the game and what the graphics are like etc so I don't think it's worth going into that here. For whatever it's worth, I'll just say here how it felt overall and suggestions for things you could try to improve your experience.I played through twice to explore both branches and I think that's enough for me. I don't feel that it's a game I'd play thrice. Combat was sometimes annoying and unresponsive: fights where both swords are needed suffer in particular because swapping between the two takes too long. YMMV but I felt that the boss fights were harder than in the first game and while I'm not going to complain about intrinsic difficulty, when they are compounded by extrinsic factors then overall that's not good at all.Also, I recommend taking up GOG's offer of DRM-free free backup copy because savegame loading is so much faster on that version.  When you might die a lot, it is really frustrating having to wait for the list of savegames to appear and then for the save to load - which might take a full minute or two (it certainly feels that long). Not sure but the GOG version also feels smoother and faster than the Steam version.Overall a great game but in my opinion unplayable unless using a gamepad/xbox360 controller because the control scheme makes for some awkward keyboard key mapping. Even though the Witcher games series began on PC, the control scheme of Witcher 2 feels like they targeted consoles and then ported it back to PC. Let me state now that for all intents and purposes I'm essentially a PC gamer exclusively so I do know my way around my keyboard and mouse. The only time I would use a controller would be if I was playing with friends on a console - yet when I picked up a controller for Witcher 2, the controls felt immediately natural.While I'm not a prude I'm glad they dispensed with the whole collectible "sex-cards" gimmick for Witcher 2. I felt they were immature and childish. As a completionist, I did endeavour to unlock them all in one of my Witcher 1 playthroughs but only for the sake of completionism - it was a chore, nothing more. It would have subtracted nothing from my enjoyment of the game if the feature had been absent. The Witcher games are not unique in falling foul of the immature and childish - i.e. sex as a "reward", which is an unrealistic and shallow depiction of relationships. But objectifying the act with those in-game collectible cards was even more silly.CDProjektRED has got be my favourite developer. I'm really looking forward to Witcher 3 to see how the story ends... but even that will just be a warm up for Cyberpunk 2077. I'm so getting the collectors edition of that if I can.If it sounds like I have a lot of complaints about this game then maybe it's because I had higher expectations than the game ultimately delivered. Then again I loved the Mass Effect games even though they were more linear but also felt deeper somehow. Maybe I'd hoped W2 would've been deeper.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												One of the best RPGs I've ever played. The storyline changes based on your decisions. That in all would not be very impressive. The great thing is that they are not your Mass Effect type "good/neutral/evil"-decisions but real nailbiters.The atmosphere is dark and dirty and everything is distrustful. You become suspicious of everybody which does not really help with making easy decisions. Do you help the elf or your companion? The complete second act will chance with that decision.The quests are interesting, the gameplay smooth, the combat-system works great and is just fun.The character customization is a little boring - but it did not bother me all that much.If you are into hardcore RPG: Play the first Witcher first (it's loooong and has some really bad gamedesign and the controls... what were they thinking?! - but it's worth it) - you can import your savegame into Witcher 2 and the story continues seamlessly.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												This game is a must if you declaring yourself as an RPG fan. I recommend to play the first game too to have better understanding about the story of this game and have a better item in the start of the second game. Oh and the frist game is really great too despite slooooww prologue and a little weird combat. And I personally prefer witcher 1 story rather than the second.Allright first, the story of this game is really awesome. You are Geralt of Rivia. A professional monster slayer that slay monsters for golds. But because of the circumstances you become the personal bodyguard of Temerian King. But because of being too close to the king, like a dog and his master, you are being accused with a crime that you never commit. And here we go the quest to clear your name, or you want to pursue other cause rather than just clearing your name? That's your callThis is a game where choices are really impactful in overall your gaming experience. Your experience will be different from the others depend on what you choose in the game. Even the side quests if you do them in different order, the result conseuqence would be dramatically different too. And the result is not instantly occur after the choice you made. You have to continue your progress to see the how the event unfold to see consequences of your previous choice. So you may think carefully about what would it become before choose rather than just load before the choice and know every consequence it will made.I have to mention too, this game has moral ambiguity, nothing is really good and nothing is really evil. There are no best option with everyone win and peace come to the land with people become loving and understanding each other. Only choices with the good thing and bad thing of their consequences. This game will question how is your moral stand. Just like a real world where people relatively have different standard of what is right and what is wrong. And their different point of view can lead into a bigger clash between others.The gameplay now, well it has some learning curve and dying is not uncommon in this game. Maybe you will died, a lot, in this game despite you are a witcher that possesses superhuman speed and reflex, able to drink potions that would instantly kill a common human, having a silver sword, some magic, and white hair and such. Yes you have those ability, if not you will not able to stand against a dosens of trained soldier afterall, but you are still a mortal. You need to think, prepare, analyze how the enemies' attack pattern, know when is the best to roll dodge or block the attack, utilizing your sign (magic), and also using your items like bombs, potions, and traps. Especially potions. It is not skyrim where potion is not really important at all and you can pause and drink it in the middle of combat. You need to drink before the combat and potion is not some "guarantee way to win" or anything like that. It helps, a lot, but the result still heavily depends on how you play. Always remember, a witcher without potions is just a half of the witcher (or whatever it is, I forgot the exact quote)It is a game where you will feel being treated as an adult, the story, the gampelay, the sex (This game has the best sex scene in my entire experience of gaming. MASS EFFECT DIDN'T GIVE US PROPER BOOBIES !!) but some minor issue like tutorial section that don't tell what exactly to do (That mutate ability section, many players stoped playing because they can't figure out the tutorial) inability to change the keybinding, some visual bug. But neverthless, nothing is perfect right?So my score for this game is 9.0 out of 10. A must have if you want a mature, dark, and solid RPG experience with challenging combat that will make kids cry because it's too difficult for them. I suggest you who like this game to play this game at least 2 playthrough to know every story it has. Oh yeah don't forget it has some boobies too. Yeah boobies for the win !!

content:

												The Witcher 2 is an epic, mature and tough RPG. I never played the Witcher 1 and just watched some youtube summary, so at the beginning I was a little confused about all characters and the big picture of the story. The moment I found my way into the Witcher universe the story became thrilling with all its twists and choices. The characters have detailed looks, personality and  a nice voice-acting.  Release was in 2011, but the graphics are still impressive and suit the rough medieval european fantasy atmosphere very well. The gamepaly is quite challenging: If you don´t prepare your fights or analyze your opponents to adapt your tactics, you will lose hard even on normal difficulty level. You will come across various beasts and human enemies, which will be cut down with either your silver or steel sword. The use of different magic signs and the skill tree are just the start of the game mechanics. You can uprade your swords, create potions and craft new weapons and armors with the trophies from  fallen enemies.  Maybe the mouse controls could be a little more precise and the 3rd act is quite short compared to act 1 and 2. I really enjoyed the game and I´m looking forward to The Witcher 3. 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												Astronomically better than the first game. If you're interested in storyline, then I'd suggest reading a plot summary of the first game. The Witcher 1 is incredible considering how good the story is and how large the world is, given the very small budget used to create it, but I would not play it again. Aside from that, the Witcher 1's decisions have such a minor impact on the Witcher 2 that there's no reason to load up a save.The combat mechanics in this game are some of my favorite swordplay mechanics. It's very challenging--particularly on Insane or Dark, where one wrong move in a boss fight, or even in a fight against a large number of mooks, has a good chance of killing you. Insane is truly insane; it's very difficult and when your character dies, the game is over. Your saves are locked. Try again. Don't play it until you've finished the game on another difficulty--there's a high chance you won't survive past the first few levels and will have to play them again. I have been on the final boss fight in insane twice and messed up both times--so many hours lost.The game's graphics are also incredible and it functionally has two different storylines that are intertwined and based on a very important decision early in the game. You really have to play the game twice to get a full picture of what's going on geopolitically around your character--and it's fascinating.The Witcher 2 also maintains the Witcher's morally ambiguous choices. There aren't very many clearly "good" or "evil" choices; you are forced to choose between the options on the basis of the consequences.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												The Witcher 2 is a continuation and a tremendously improved game released by CDPR 3 years after the first Witcher game. The game has everything improved from the Witcher 1. To see all the improvement, from the gameplay to the storytelling, I would recommend playing the Witcher 1 first. This is gonna be another TL;DR review from me:1/ Story: The story continues after the final battle in Witcher 1, Geralt now lives with Triss, still suffering from amnesia. The Witcher 2 continues using the amnesia plot to reinvigorate the story, which creates amazing plot twists and storytelling method. The quest's story, if I am not mistaken from the Witcher 1, continued to be narrated by Dandelion. The story in Witcher 2 has two paths: Iorverth's, the commander of the Elves rebel Scoia'tael and Vernon Roche's, the commander of the Blue Stripes and loyal soldier to King Foltest. Geral will travel with either of the two to find the Kingslayer, Letho to clear Geralt's name and discovers a bigger plot twist. However, for me, the story could have been made a little longer :( The game was so great that I wanted more.Choices DO MATTER A LOT IN THIS GAME. If you have played Witcher 1, you will see some of your choices impact in the Witcher 2, though not that much.The World in The Witcher 2 has a lot of things you can do, which is great, from barber shop, bookshop, inns, swordsmiths, armor shop, potion ingredient shops, a lot :3 you can definitely spend hours in the world without getting bored! But!!!! As with any Witcher game, Money is a huge problem =_= . 2/ Weapons and Armors: The Witcher 2 delivers a massive improvement from the Witcher 1, with new and improved crafting items for weapons and armors. A huge lot of new armors that have different cool look on Geralt of Rivia :3 This is one of the best things I loved to see after Witcher 1. New blade oils, new runes to add to your weapons, and also new enchantments for the armors. Definitely a massive improvement!3/ Combat: A huge difference from the Witcher 1, the combat has beeen improved by CDPR to be more realistic and more dynamic and active. The players can now dodge, swing the swords in light or heavy attacks whenever they want to, making it less.... awkward in the Witcher 1. The new daggers and bombs, together with the critical effect from the weapons and the Signs, do create a perfect combat stimulation for the players. 4/ Leveling up and Meditation: The game offers 3 different branch of playstyles: Mutant - Alchemist, Combat, Magic and 1 basic obligatory initial branch, although the players can actually get all 3 different playstyles in one playthrough ! Each skill can be upgraded twice, having new effects and improvement, creating a variety of playstyle for each player. Meditation system can now be done in most places, a great improvement from the campfire meditation system in The Witcher 1. The game still keeps the traditional Alchemy - Resting - Character leveling up options in Meditation, however, if I am not mistaken, The Witcher 1 allowed the player to drink the potions whenever they want to, but the Witcher 2 only allows that during meditation. 5/ Game saves: The game can import the saves from The Witcher 1, which includes your Armor and your best weapons $_$ Which is a major boosting start for the Witcher 2. I really like the fact that they do import your choices in the first game as well. Some characters from the previous game will recognize you on the way. However, the Witcher 2 suffers from the problem of having too many saves (auto-saves from quests) and unable to delete them easily. Which is a problem, since the players will have to delete them manually, one by one. This is a problem continuing from the Witcher 1. 6/ Mini-games: The Witcher 2 re-introduced Dice Poker - still the same from the Witcher 1, though brutally harder and more difficult, as if the opponents are geniuses with huge luck in poker game - always get the upper hands of probability; Bare hand Fighting - now a quick timing game; and Arm-Wresting - a super hard game that will make you reload every time just to win it, especially in the final Numa arm wrestling match, you gotta try to win it first try, without accusing him of anything to get 15% damage perk, this is something not many people know. But, in overall, the Witcher 2 is a major success and a great game, a must-have in any Witcher fan's collection. Having played this game really hyped me up for the Witcher 3 game, I hope to see what impact my choices in The Witcher 2 will have on The Witcher 3 so much.  The OVERALL SCORE , to me, is 9.5/10 (-0.5 because of the money problem and also because of the mini games and the saves). However, I gave that -0.5 because those problems are trivial and still can be handled , though not with ease. And also for one IMPORTANT THING: THERE IS NO NEW GAME + IN THIS GAME, which you won't get to taste much of your two sweet swords in the end game..... #sadI finished the game on Hard first playthrough. Definitely a great but brutal experience when it comes to combat ! :3 but that's how the game should be played for me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												Apart from some early Bioware titles, i have never been quite so hooked to a game series as i have been to the first two Witcher titles. Immersion is what gives this series, in my humble opinion, the edge over its contemporaries. By not being open world, the Assassins of Kings can focus primarily on its compelling central story line. Open worlds provide you with 'options' but risk not being able to make you care enough about any one thing. The most recent Elder Scrolls for example have had pretty lacklustre main storylines. Other games such as Kingdom of Amalur fall into the trap of giving the player too many, and repetitive tasks.In other words the Witcher 2 plays a very nice balance between freedom and narrative.The world and its lore is incredible and worth immersing yourself in, BUT, if you don't read the Sapkowski novels or play the previous game you risk becoming bewildered quickly. Crafting, levelling, gear accumulation, are all satisfying and add a lot to the depth.There are alternative story paths you will only get to see by playing multiple times, meaning there is great replay value in this; you get to see the result of your choices, either from the first game, or in an early chapter of this game, in what happens later on. for the RPG fan this is very satisfying. No environments are recycled a la Dragon Age 2.So, any caveats with this game?Yes, Combat. it's not such a black and white case of poor combat in the way that Dragon Age 2 was, but, it can be very frustrating. A lot of the time what you really crave is a good duel, one on one (or one versus two) swordfight. Ocasionally, you will have extremely satisfying and rewarding fights with parrying, dodging, the whole shebang. But most of the time especially in the early game it's hard to survive without spamming the 'roll' key, the result being that Geralt launches himself to and fro like a lunatic. With parrying fairly ineffectual before you level up damage reduction and with many enemies invulnerable from the front, you will be reduced to rolling behind them and slashing he/she/they/it from behind. It can feel disappointing when the game forces you to win by these unsatisfying means.However, combat can still look a treat, like the rest of the game, and this is no reason not to buy such a well executed game

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												What a wonderful game continuing the story of Geralt of Rivia. My favourite aspect of the game is how wholesome and real the characters feel. Never have I laughed out loud so much playing a game, and that is thanks to some of the amazing quotes from Geralt and co. I would even say playing the game through to completion the second time is better than the first, because I made completely different decisions to my first run through, and i discovered completely different parts of the story I hadn't seen first time though. This game is all about choice, and your choices and past greatly affect the outcomes of the story, even more so than the previous installment in the series. Another aspect I really liked was that I could link my saved game from the previous Witcher game to this one, so that the important decisions I made in the last game carried over into this one - sometimes my past haunted me! The combat has greatly improved in this installment and I enjoy nothing more the running and killing some beastie of bandit with the wonderful sound as my blade cuts a few organs. The game can also be quite complex, juggling potions, oils, armour upgrades, traps and magic as well as Geralt's swords, which I only properly appreciated on the second run through on a higher difficulty, where you really have to use them all. The decisions in the game are really difficult, it can be really hard to tell who are the liars and who are telling the truth - on many occasions I got caught out. Hence playing it twice through makes it all the more interesting! Overall, a colourful, wonderful, beautiful game that makes me want to read the books it is based on, at least to see if my decisions were the ones Geralt actually makes!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												if you ever thought that fairytales and fantasy creatures are just for kids then you didnt have the chance to take a glimpse of the world of the witcher where power corrupted politics meet dangerous bloodthirsty creatures.The witcher is an rpg game franchise with characters based on short story collections that later became a saga of novels writen by a polish writer Andrzej Sapkowski.Cd projekt red is the team that took this fantasy world into the pc.The story is about a witcher named geralt of rivia.Witchers are mercenaries,hunters of mythical beasts hired even by kings.In the second part of the saga, the kings of the north are slayed by mercenaries and one of them in front of geralt who is accused of the murder as he was found alone with the dead body of the king.The tale starts as he is trying to clear his name by finding and killing the murderer.                   The visual design of the game is plus moderate compared to 2014 games as when it was published was on the top of the rpg games.The lanscapes, the cities, the alleys, models everything on it made me feel as i was part of a graphic novel, living, breathing in it.The game as a whole made me explore every alley of it remembering every path of the map by heart. It resembles the fable saga in a significantly darker tone in a cruel world with nudity and teriffying creatures.                   It worked in general on high frames except the third act where i found it drop at 15-20 frames.It is still a heavy game.Ι also want to point that there is no support for 2560-1080 screens.I used the flawless widescreen app to play it on full screen.                  It took me 35 hours to clear the game but without some sidequests that i missed as it was my original first gameplay, so i think that it provides  38-40 hours of playtime. Surviving in this world depends not only on your sword skills nor your magic skills but as a combinbation of everything that is provided. I discovered that on the hard way as i died again and again on the first hours. I saw the game-over screen many times, the loading screen is the fastest i have ever seen and after finishing the evil within it was like paradise. Runes ,enchantments,oils,poisons,potions traps everything are essential for survival. I found myself using everythimg on my disposal for the first time.Υou dont play a witcher ,the game is made to make you feel that you are one and acting as one .The inventory menu needs some improvement though. Magic is just for support dont expect to make a mage character. Αs for the sword fight, is immersive but with some problems when it comes to multi-fights.       Closing this review i want to add that choices does matter on this one and depending on what you choose, you affect politics and play different quests.So it provides different gameplay build everytime.Plus you can import your witcher 1 save and depending on your inventory and your story path you acquire some swords and coins on your witcher 2 start and in a few occusions it affects the game but dont except really big changes.Have fun !!!mediun to high hardware :sapphire r9 280x toxicintel celeron G1620  2,70 ghz6gb ramsandisk  ultra ii ssd 120gb sata3lg 29um65-prunning on windows 8.1maxxed out+     1)  wonderful visuals even compared to 2014 games+     2)  resourceful  type of combat +     3)  choice-consequences system+     4)  great videos and multiple ways of storytelling-      1) the story doesnt feel adequate enough, needs more depth-      2) doesnt support ultrawide screens

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												This is probably my weakest recommendation for a game to date. The story is this game's saving grace. It has kept me interested with plenty of intrigue, likable characters, well written dialouge, and real consequences for choices. However the gameplay is trash. I have never felt like a witcher once while playing this game. Unless witchers go through all those mutations and years of training made them experts at kiting enemies, taking one swing then rolling away. The challenge of enemies in the first witcher came from not understanding them, you could then take time to study them and learn how to defeat them. In this the challenge never seems genuine. The game doesn't reward hard work, learning your enemies weakness, then exploiting it; it only rewards patience. Do you have the patience to slowly chip away at this boss or that group of enemies while kiting them around the area? Watch a LP or a let's Watch if you don't want to have to supress the urge to uninstall the game. Once again, the story parts of this game are phenomenal A+, gameplay gets a D-.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2011
												The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings is a fantastic, epic spanning RPG, worthy of any PC Gamer’s eye.  Although the game is not without its fair share of technical blemishes Witcher 2 delivers a powerful punch to the player from the moment they click “Play”.  The atmosphere delivered in this title is very engrossing, and as such, Witcher 2 is able to pull the player in and never let go.  The graphics are superb, the art direction is creative and eye catching, and the writing is well delivered, never failing to entrench the player within the game’s vigorously delivered atmosphere.  Although challenging, The Witcher 2 is quite rewarding, delivering an experience like none other.  Most modern RPGs provide the player with two extremes, either absolutely satanic, or non-arguably angelic, and while these games tout their “you write your own story” technique, they fail in delivery.  This is where the Witcher 2 absolutely nails it.  I highly recommend this title.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												This game was amazing with a TRULY GREAT STORY. 92/100. Absolute definitely replayability with two major story arcs and many minor ones.It is Skyrim-like with action-RPG elements, but it is definitely not a true open-world game like Skyrim or The Witcher 3. You have pretty large areas for each chapter of the game and it works fantastically with all of the quests. I love the way that quests have multiple ways to resolve them and quests affect each other in a variety of ways. You actually need to listen (all voiced) and read the quest dialogue. This is not click-click-MMO quest type, thankfully!The combat is solid for action RPG but not perfect. I played with both mouse+keyboard and a PS4 controller. I preferred the controller by a long shot but the M+KB was definitely playable and I have seen opinions supporting both.The graphics are astonishing. If you have the card to handle it (r9 290/290x or 780/780ti) you will want to max it out AND edit the .ini file to increase view distances. Pop-in was not present at all when I did this, and distant objects were crisp and lush.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2014
												Gameplay: Combat is extremely well done, allowing for various different approaches in each situation. Similarly, conversations  always have interesting dialogue trees.Story: The story is akin to that of the 'A Song of Ice and Fire' book series, rich, incredibly detailed and expertly written.Graphics: The graphics in this game are amazing, they really bring the world and its various inhabitants to life and help to deeply immerse you.Sound: Most, if not all of the sound effects sound like something out of a high-quality fantasy movie, such as Lord of the Rings and dialogue is also spoken by clearly skilled actors.Re-playability: There are many different choices throughout the game and multiple playthroughs are required to experience all of the consequences.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												Much of what I said in my review of the first Witcher game will still apply here.  That being said, you are doing yourself a disservice if you don't start with the first game.  But, that's my opinion and it is subjective.Once again we find ourselves in the boots of the Witcher, Geralt of Rivia.  They are much shinier and detailed than before. Also, I think my pants are tighter.The story is still amazing, the characters are life like and reek of complexity.  I found myself, on more than one occasion, staring at my screen trying to make a decision that I knew was going to effect everything going forward.  The Npc's in the towns and so forth could use more material. I get it, you're upset you got syphilis from a ♥♥♥♥♥, but I don't need to hear it everytime I run past you.While the areas you are adventuring in are not massive, after running back and forth 5 or 6 times it feels rather large.The world looks great, from lush forests to open fields, towering mountains, bloody battlegrounds and dirty ♥♥♥♥♥houses.All the different characters style and facial construction from the first game have been updated and I feel it better shows their personalities. Oh, and hairstyles, you have a few choices.  I tried them all, but Geralt's standard Witcher cut fits best.I found the music to be buggy at times and kind of hang on the same three notes over and over.  A quick f5 then f9 solved the issue. I can overlook this issue because the soundtrack fits the game world so well.I don't feel as though the sex and violence overshadows the development of the story at all.  In fact, I think it fits well and was executed just fine.  It's a violent time and people like to get laid, it happens.Combat has been somewhat redone to be more fluid and enjoyable, still very clicky, but in more of a mash kind of way.  I don't dislike it at all.  Dodging and rolling around just feels better than the first game. And although I didn't use a single bomb or trap after the tutorial, having them equipped in quickslots(called pockets, heh) allows you to use them quickly. It seems like a nice touch. The changes to how potions and meditation work feels well thought out as well.  Not being able to use pots during a fight puts it on the players to be prepared for the road ahead.  But, you can meditate pretty much anywhere you want(unlike the first game where you needed a campfire).Now it's time for me to continue my chase of the Wild Hunt.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 15, 2013
												A gritty, sophisticated, and intelligent adventure RPG.I'm not usually into the genre, but this grabbed me, and held my attantion, and still does. The Witcher 2 throws you right into the heart of momentous events that have gravity, and you're instantly made an integral part of the game from the very start.I felt drawn into the Witcher world, and involved in a way that I don't often experience with games.The game is also unforgiving. It's not infuriating, at least I didn't think so, but it's demanding in that you actually need to use combat tactics in real time.You have to dodge and evade attacks, block, parry, and riposte. Dangerous/malicious forest creatures can kill you quite easily if you try a hack-and-slash approach. You have to put some forethought into the items you take along.It's also a visually stimulating game. The design is oh so intricate!...The only downside to this amazing game is that it's quite demanding in terms of hardware.At the time of posting this review, I'm running it on an end of 2009 model laptop, with one of the core2 duo chips from just prior to the i-series release. It barely meets specs.It's still very playable, but far from seamless. Other than a good processor, you'll need a decent graphic card. I have an ATI Mobility Radeon HD 4650 1GB, and it runs.It's hard to find that out if you're trawling through forums and query-posts, but it runs. Laptop version too, so less powerful.One of the more engaging games I've played for a good while now, and complete fun. A joy to play and to look at, 9/10.(Only for the high hardware requirements meaning you really need a top end system to bring out it's full potential.)Well worth it, especially at steam's almost obscenely cheap discount-sale price!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												This is a mature dark fantasy game with rich lore and adult themes. The first game had a rhythm-based combat system where you would click the attack button in time to perform successive attacks in sequence. This game drops that and goes for a more traditional combat system that utilizes slow-heavy attacks and light-fast attacks. Both games are forerunners in combat animation but there's a certain meatiness to the combat in The Witcher 2, you can really feel the blows that land on your opponents. It takes about 40 hours to get through one playthrough of the story, but the large choices that you have to make throughout the story have lasting consequences in shaping the world and lend heavy replay value to this game. The only thing that would make this game more interesting to me is if the developers put time into designing an investigation system into the game, which makes you dig into the lore of the world a bit more in order to solve problems.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												This game is truly a master piece. It's writing is superb, the combat is fun, the graphics are gorgeous and the world let's you immerse.The Witcher 2 is finally a game, that doesn't just throw a quest arrow in your face. You can't finish the game by exclusively looking at the mini-map (I'm looking at you, Skyrim). No, you need to do your research on monsters and events, talk to people and draw you own conclusions, solve a few riddles, learn about the lore to give the correct answers in dialogues.If you are interested, I recommend you suffer through the first game. Yes, the combat controls suck but the story is worth it. I also enjoyed the books quite a lot. There is a whole new universe to discover.It is also a game that is not for the faint of heart.♥♥♥♥♥♥ murder, betrayal, frequent cursing are often occurring themes that make this a title suited for a mature audience.Overall, this is an RPG you shouldn't miss.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												Probably the most underrated CRPG out there. This game is a gemstone that stands as an example to traditional role playing game developing companies like Bethesda and Bioware. It's been developed by a Polish game company named CDProjekt with no desire to be a part of today's competitive capitalist game industry. A lot of time and effort was spent in creating this game as it's a well polished, very original rpg unlike many unripe games we see today. It takes place in a fantasy world where three northern kingdoms, Temeria, Redenia, Kaedwen (and previously Aedirn) deal with internal turmoils as a mysterious assassin begins to collect crowned heads as in south, expantionist Nilfgaardian Empire stands ready. Also, a resistance guerilla force including non-humans called Scoi'tel emerges to fight for the oppressed and the protagonist, Geralt of Rivia finds himself in the middle of the conflict.The atmosphere of the environments are truly amazing thanks to stunning visuals and beautiful background soundtrack. Instead of wandering through one vast geographical area like the one in Skyrim, The Witcher 2 takes place in 3 different regions and the player allowed and encouraged to explore each one in all three chapters, Temerian village of Flotsam next to a swamp-forest, Dwarven city of Vergen on top of the Blue Mountains and finally the ancient city of Loc Muinne, now in ruins.The game's combat system is rather old-school and takes time to get used to it. Once getting familiar with it however, you will see how fun it is. You carry two swords, a steel one for humanoids and a silver one for monsters. Gerald posseses 5 magical abilites called 'Signs' allowing you to stun, ignite, trap, convert enemies along with providing protection. Alchemy system allows you to craft potions and swords oils giving you various advantages, but you need to use them "before" the battle, not during! As Geralt finishes quests, contracts and kills monsters he levels up, providing skill points to spend in TW2's vast skill tree. Since you cannot unlock all nodes in the skill tree, you need to customize your character in Magic, Melee and Alchemy.To sum up, if you call yourself a rpg person, you should definetly play this game. The first game of the installement is said to be very problematic but no worries, you can start of the series directly with TW2 as i did. The lore and role playing elements are well thought and captivating, encouraging you to do more than one playthroughs. It's a very cheap game for its quality. Have fun and remember, you never trust sorceresses ;)

												Wow!!!! If you're a fan of the Mass Effect story structure, or just being able to make choices that matter in a game, then this is the game for you!The story is great, although it may seem a little political at first, it's not the only thing going on but the story continues to get juicier, especially towards the endThe gameplay takes a little getting used to, it may be a little frustrating at first ( I suggest starting in easy mode as you'll want to play this game again anyway) but if you stick with it, all will be clear to you. Posted: June 21, 2014
												By far one of the best RPGs I have played in a while.  The story is very captivating and the graphics are exceptionally pleasing.  (I won't mention all the other eye candy here) The almost seamless transitions between indoor / outdoor / caverns is very nice.  The only drawback I would list to this game, is that the world is not "open" enough.  True you can go do just about anything you want during a certain time in a chapter, but once you move on past that chapter, you can't go back to a previously visited area.  Aside from that, I love the aspect that many of your decisions change the course of the game, and you can play it differently each time, with differing outcomes.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2015
												There are many game series I came late into, and the second installment is usually a good indicator of what the development team behind a series is like in regards to how they feel about their game. The console oriented approach of CDPR may have raised some eyebrows back when it was new information, and with catastrapohes such as Dragon Age 2 it's understandable to be apprehensive of what is generally seen as a focus on console in order to create more mass appeal and thus sell more copies, regardless of the quality of the game. People first assumed this was the case with CDPR and The Witcher 2, that the devs of a deep (if mechanically lacking) RPG based on a niche series of stories by a Polish author based on Slavic mythology had sold out to push more copies and make more money.Whilst that goal is pretty much universal across game developers and companies in general, you need only play the Witcher 2 for a few minutes to see for yourself that it is not what drove the developers to make the game they did.It cannot be said that The Witcher 2 is not flawed, it has difficulty with basic things such as inventory management being time-consuming and non-combat movement being janky, and numerous geometry issues in certain areas across the game. Where the game is successful however, is in it's design of location, character, story and monsters that make it interesting, and the brutal conviction with which it conveys to you all of this that makes it a game that is all to easy to get completely enthralled in, with plenty to do and plenty more ways to do them.

												Seriously, this game is incredible. There are almost no issues with it.Pros:+ Massive, and I mean MASSIVE game world+ Because it's based on a series of equally brilliant novels, the story and the depth of the world could go toe-to-toe with LotR, and it makes TES look like Minecraft+ Smooth gameplay, very fluid controls and combat+ Incredible graphics+ Runs perfect frame-rates, provided you have the sufficient hardware, and almost never crashes (Windows 8 has some issues though)+ Literally hundreds of hours of quests and side-missions+ Brilliant animation and voice acting+ More like an RPG than a lot of RPGs, even though this technically isn't an RPG; combinations of spells, weapons, traps, and allies make it feel almot as if Geralt isn't a pre-set character.+ Soundtrack is mesmerising and very fittingCons:- Menus and inventory a little clunky- Map needs some work- Can have random difficulty spikes, and times where you have absolutely no idea how to progress with very little help from the gameBuy this game. Just do it. You will not regret it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												Overview: The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings is a fantasy RPG set in a medieval landscape.  The player controls Geralt of Rivia as he trys to uncover the truth behind the events that take place in the beginning of the game.  An expansive story awaits and is effected by the player's actions.  The choices you make really will effect the outcome of events.  Pros: A great and detailed story.  The story is definitely the best aspect of this game.  There are a lot of important characters throughout the game who will shape events as they unfold.  Content.  There is a lot of content here.  Each area has a few side quests in addition to the main story quests.  Even if you just stick to the main quests, the story will take you around 30 hours.  Crafting is also available and can take a considerable amount of time.  If you want a break from the main game, an arena area is available with leaderboards.Cons:Crafting.  Don't bother trying to craft that really awesome armor set the vendor is selling.  For one, you will probably never get the money to even buy all the recipes.  If you do manage that, it can be quite time consuming to gather all the leather.  Each armor set comes with a sword recipe for your regular and silver sword.  The swords are the worst part of this crafted set.  They are really awesome for the current area, but require you to have the complete set equiped to use.  Each time you move to a new area in the game, the previous armor set recipes become unavailable.  So, if you spent time just crafting the swords and move to the next area, all that time and resources are now gone.  Crafting armor pieces can be pointless as better or equivalent items can be found by simply thoroughly exploring the area or gambling with random NPCs.  Other than potions and enhancements, crafting is just a waste of time.Combat.  Although Geralt has access to a few spells in addition to swords, the combat is rather simple.  You can easily play the entire game just slashing as fast as you can and dodging away.  You can parry your opponent by waiting for them to attack, but this locks your character in place and is not advisable when taking on multiple opponents.  Since basically every fight has you facing multiple opponents, parrying can leave you open.  Story Presentation.  The story is pretty good, but sometimes it is not presented very well.  The player mainly controls Geralt but at times will very briefly control a side character.  This can happen at random times and can be better handled by just showing a cut scene.Tech Issues.  The audio in the game is all over the place.  Sometimes character dialog will be very loud and other times a wisper.  I also did not care for the narrator's voice when transitioning to new areas.  When I had a lot of saves the game would continually crash when trying to load.  Level Design.  The world consist of mainly tight corridors with very little open space.  It would have been nice to have more room to roam around.Conclusion:The Witcher 2 presents a great story in a not so great way.  The levels feel claustrophobic, the combat can be very simple, and the crafting can be pointless.  If you put that aside, this is still a pretty good game.  There is a deep story here that can be guided by the player.  If you haven't played a serious RPG in awhile and are looking for something decent, play this.Score: 8.1 / 10

												I played this game in the first place just to get the full story before Witcher 3... Man, if I knew it was that good, I would buy a powerful PC on its release date. content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												I had originally played “The Witcher 2” on the X360 and now replaying it again in anticipation of “The Witcher 3”. I got to say after coming out in 2011 it still holds up. Here’s the skinny:•	It has incredible visuals with the environment, character/enemy designs and textures being incredible eye-catchers that will have you wanting to play on the highest settings you can get.•	If you love RPGs you will love this game. It is not as large as Skyrim but because of that the details are much finer and better. It has extensive level up systems, crafting, equipment and combat varieties that I believe are essential in RPG gameplay.•	The combat overall is strategic, if you try to brute force your way it may take you several deaths and tries to progress. You will need to make use of all resources•	The story is incredible with your different choices in game that will results in a variety of endings for this game. But to see if our choices will have true impact we will have to wait for “The Witcher 3” to come out and see if our imported “Witcher 2” files will do any impact on the story or just carry over character upgrades.•	It is dense with content and will give you a considerable amount of hours of entertainment.This game with its dense gameplay, in-depth story and incredible visuals and it fun factor earn it a 10/10.  A game that is truly worth buying and increases my anticipation and excitement for the Witcher 3” and the conclusion to Geralt’s masterfully made adventure from CD Project Red.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2015
												So I originally bought this game back in 2011 when it came out. Suffered through the many patches and changes and even noticed the missions that were removed.  I recently bought it on steam(for those wanting to use a trainer I tried a fling 3.3 and it works currently) when it was on sale just to have a steam copy. I've completed it more times than I can remember and still think its an awesome game.Tech side: Don't even begin to believe the scaled down recommended specs given. Here's a link to a detailed bench test from 2011-12 that will give you an idea of what this game really needs: http://www.techspot.com/review/405-the-witcher-2-performance/page3.htmlI've played this on many different system configurations and can tell you that if you want to max the game and card settings you will need some serious hardware. My current setup (2 gigabyte g1 970's in SLI, 4930 Hex Core see profile to see rest) has been tested w/ all game settings maxed(including ubersampling) and all Nvidia settings maxed. Here's the results:2D 1080p avg 110-120fps            3D 1080p avg 40-55 fps       4k(3860x2160 for correct aspect ratio) 35-45 fpsPlaying at 4k does look beautiful but the 3D is one of the best I have ever seen. In 3D there is so much depth and occasional pop that it really sets the bar for 3D gaming. There's still occasional ghosting but its pretty minor. I imagine a single GTX960-970 will give favorable 2D 1080P experience but you will need some kind of dual gpu if you want to max it all. It is a DX9  game but possibly one of the best looking ones when maxed although if you lower the gamma it still has a bit of a 'cartoon' look but there's still a lot of detail in most textures.The game itself: It's not a true open world but each level or area is pretty expansive. It is a linear story but there are many, many choices to be made and some will impact immediately while other consequences only  occur later. I forget exactly how many different endings there are but I've experienced about 5 or 6. It can be a fun world to explore. This game does have many similarities to game of thrones so fans of those books/shows may enjoy it. And on that note, this is NOT a game for young children.I totally recommend this game to anyone who likes RPG's, even more so if you want a great 3d experience or 4k. It's a game that technology is still catching up to and has considerable replay factors.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												This is the second adventure of Geralt of Rivia, and it really is a magnificent sequel and a darn good RPG.What are the biggest changes between this and Witcher 1? Well, first there's the visuals - everything's gorgeous now, and Zoltan no longer has a bizarre unfocused look in his eyes that makes him seem permanently stoned. I spent a ton of time just panning the camera around taking in all the scenery, and I was only playing this on LOW settings. Control-wise, the combat system has been revamped. It's still occasionally clunky when it comes to switching between Witcher signs/bombs/traps, but this awkwardness eventually goes away after a few hours of play. Overall, everything feels more natural (when played with a controller) and skill-based than the clicky combat of the first game. The different stances are out and now it's action-orientated, and you've got to roll around a lot and dodge blows with precision. The game is tough at first because Geralt starts as a weakling compared to his foes, and the in-game tutorial does a pretty crap job of explaining the combat, so try the game out on Easy or Normal difficulty first until you get the hang of things and level up Geralt to non-weakling status. (Use the Quen sign as much as possible and try specializing in Swordmaster skills like roll and block if you're having trouble in the beginning.) Normal difficult in the Witcher 2 = hard difficulty in a lot of other games, so be aware.And then there's the story. The plot in Witcher 1 occasionally seemed like it was rehashing the most memorable of Geralt's adventures from the novels with some odd discrepancies; ie: Triss' personality was more like Yennefer's than anything else. Witcher 2 fixes this by making the characters more in line with their book counterparts and crafting a story that is very political and seems like a natural extension of the books rather than a "best of" compilation. The kings of the Northern Kingdoms are being killed by assailants from a forgotten Witcher school, and much of Chapters 2 and 3 focus on the importance of the Pontar Valley, an area that borders the more notable kingdoms in Geralt's world. A lot of names are dropped and places referenced, which can be confusing to newbies that haven't read the books or played the first game, so referring to the in-menu Journal is a must. Lore fanatics will eat this up; impatient players perhaps not as much.As long as you've got time and patience, the Witcher 2 will eat up many, many hours of your life. Best of all, this is one of the few games I know of that's really worth replaying - a critical decision at the end of Chapter 1 will COMPLETELY change Chapters 2 and 3 for you. Lengthy RPGs are usually low on the replay list for me...but I'm planning on a completely new playthrough on Hard difficulty just to check out Iorveth's path, so that's saying something.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												Witcher 2 is an RPG like no other that caters to the most mature and serious players in the genre. With absolutely zero hand holding and possibly the best cinematic storytelling I've ever seen, the game provides an experience like no other. When you play this game, you will never see halos or devil horns telling you whether the decisions you make are "good" or "evil". The game simply presents choices and consequences, so it is ultimately up to the player to decide what path they decide to take, and quite often the the lines between what is right and wrong can become muddled and even downright inconclusive to the player, making for some extremely thought-provoking scenarios and questlines. This is bolstered by the fact that the game has dozens of major choices throughout that, with each, will have a significant impact on the story, making for so many ways to play through the game.As I mentioned, the game will almost never hold your hand. This means you will not have waypoints all over your screen telling you exactly where to go constantly. Often times, when undertaking quests, you will need to read over your journal or revisit certain characters to obtain information on where to go or what to do next, and use your intuition along the way. This type of approach gives almost the whole game the feeling of a challenge, rather than just a mundane routine. This along with other things can easily put off several people from this game who are looking for a more casual experience, as it is definitely a game for people who like to think and analyze. Possibly the biggest offput for some people may be the tutorial that the game starts off with, as it is quite bad. Getting used to the combat and inventory systems(which is also not the best at times) can be difficult, but if you can overcome that you are in for an amazing experience.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												Played the pirated version back when it was released. Back when most computers couldn't run it properly (Crysis anyone?), and just absolutely had to buy it, because CD Projekt deserved my money from the start.The game looks great, has very good voice acting, that adds a lot of immersion. The story is obviously fantastic if you kept up with W1. The battle system is opposite of that of Witcher 3, which decided to make things as simple as possible. This one had some cumbersome mechanics, like resting to use potions and buffs, and a unbalanced damage multiplier, I.E dudes are able to one shot you constantly and you have to rely on Quen more than ever.It has different endings, that affect W3 strongly, bosses were fun to fight. It could've been longer, but CD was a fairly small team back then, and we can say that they more than made up content-wise, with W3!Must play for RPG fans. I had a ton of fun raging through Insane mode.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 17, 2016
												I have mixed feelings about this game, probably due to the fact that I played it immediately after finishing the first one. Although the combat is much more complex than in the first iteration and the graphics are great, the second installment in the series really feels like a console port when it comes to the controls (PC gamer here). It took a while to get used to the movements.The game in itself is great if too scripted compared to the first game or Skyrim, for example - you can only take certain paths to your objective, can't even jump on a bridge or in the water if not on the right "spot" - and this takes out a lot of the fun, at least for me.I was also quiet disappoited with the elements taken out from the first game, like:- no potion drinking during combat - this made use of potions almost pointless, as most of the time I needed to reload because I died in the first run. So I preferred to have lots of bombs and long-range weapons on me. In the first game, I could drink potions just fine if I had enough distance between me and the enemy - as to not take a beating while drinking.- meditation impossible if in an enemy area. I had to leave combat in order to meditate, as you can only meditate in neutral / friendly places. Really frustrating, especially if I didn't know what type / how many enemies were to jump me.- I loved the idea of a fire needed for meditating / potion brewing in the first game, it made sense. It made me carry flints all the time, and look for fireplaces in order to meditate. Sometimes monsters jumped me when coming out of meditation but hey I was a witcher, right :).The game would've been perfect for me if the above elements from the first game would've been implemented here as well. I'm about to finish this game in a few hours, and then go on to the Wild Hunt. Can't wait to see how Geralt's story ends :).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												One of the best RPG's I have experienced to date. Obviously the most standout thing on the surface is the graphics. While typical RPG's settle for bland and boring the world of The Witcher is colorful and well detailed. What really sells the game is the complex story telling, which features many different plot twists, and your choices actually influence the main storyline. Its not like Mass Effect where your choices don't mean anything to the storyline. Now the gameplay is difficult as long as you select normal or harder. You dont play as an OP badass, you can die after about 4 to 5 hits from about anything unless its a way lower level then you. Combat is hard, and you will need to plan ahead by drink potions before battle and seting up traps because you can drink potions while in battle and there is no health regen. How I would describe the openess of this game is semi-open world. You can travel freely among the land, but after completing enough main story quests you will travel to a new land, unable to go back to where you came from to complete unfinished side quests or anything you left back there. The game does this often so the best way to get everything done is sidequests first. It is a bit annoying to not be able to travel back but The Witcher 3 fixes this problem and is going full open world. Either way this a must buy for RPG fans and suckers for a good story, its a hell of a ride and the game doesnt treat you like an idiot, you will be presented with challenges that will make you s**t a brick. Now all i have to do is wait for The Witcher 3 and my life will be complete.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2011
												The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings is a fantastic, epic spanning RPG, worthy of any PC Gamer’s eye.  Although the game is not without its fair share of technical blemishes Witcher 2 delivers a powerful punch to the player from the moment they click “Play”.  The atmosphere delivered in this title is very engrossing, and as such, Witcher 2 is able to pull the player in and never let go.  The graphics are superb, the art direction is creative and eye catching, and the writing is well delivered, never failing to entrench the player within the game’s vigorously delivered atmosphere.  Although challenging, The Witcher 2 is quite rewarding, delivering an experience like none other.  Most modern RPGs provide the player with two extremes, either absolutely satanic, or non-arguably angelic, and while these games tout their “you write your own story” technique, they fail in delivery.  This is where the Witcher 2 absolutely nails it.  I highly recommend this title.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2011
												An alarming amount of work went into this game to make it one of the most captivating experiences of the year. The world feels alive and rich with activity. As you wander beautiful, but melancholy forests you'll hear wildlife twitter about you. Drunken guards make racial slurs at you as you walk by. You may see a couple of men accosting the local ♥♥♥♥♥. This game is packed with incindental detail, the sound effects are surprisingly good, and the voice acting is superb. The Witcher 2 forces you to take its mature subject matter very seriously. From racial intolerance to♥♥♥♥♥♥to incest, you will deal with a broad range of topics not intended for children. My one gripe is the combat. In my opinion it's improved since the first game, but it's far from perfect. Dodge rolls and cheap deaths abound. The visuals are wickedly stunning, but the optimization isn't great. So unless you have a beastly machine expect to run at mid-high settings. Gorgeous and macabre, this game is prime. 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												This has got to be the first game I actually felt like my choices made a difference in the story. Sure, the story must end somewhat the same for all players due to the imminent sequel but the middle of the game, the journey seems to change to players. Talking to others who played it and hearing which missions they have done because of it, I feel like playing it again just so I can go and play to see what I missed out on. I loved the ambiguity of it. I was always left wondering if I was doing the right thing or not and that is important. The world and characters are not black and white. It is mature, with lots of nudity, swearing and violence but it never felt forced, everything moved at a natural pace and thats very welcome. Even the side mission/quests dont feel like they deviate from the main storyline, something that I always felt lots of games do wrong (Example: Mr. Freeze waiting hours for Batman while he goes♥♥♥♥♥♥around beating up thugs and looking for riddler trophies around Arkham city, for instance).I ended up reading some of the books while on vacation away from my PC and it was really great getting to know more of the characters and it definitively made me rethink some of my choices. If there are any complaints to the game, is that the tutorial is its worst enemy. What a chore for someone that had no experience with the game mechanics but after that, it was a delight in game design. Also, playing this game as an intro to the Witcher series, it gave me no idea who some characters where and why I should care for them. Something that the first game might have shown but I got around to it by reading the books, which by the way, are an excellent companion. CDProject Red made an excellent adaptation of the world in the game. The Witcher series might not have been on my radar but The Witcher 3 is now my most anticipated game in a long while. If any of this sounds good to you, GO PLAY IT. NOW.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Amazing Game! This game has it all, a compelling story, humorous dialogue, beautiful graphics and solid combat. The only negative I have for it is that it seems too easy after the first act, and most enemies are easily beaten by the same old attacks. That being said, there are a few fights I really had to think to win, Karayan....(kept stupidly rushing in) and Operator of course.  But combat aside, the world is genuinely fun to explore. Nearly every crate/shelf/log has items for you to grab up. The sidequests are fun and actually tie in somewhat with the main story, mostly in the form of background information on characters or places. Nearly every choice you make matters down the line, from completeing a monster quest, saving materials, or chosing npcs to side with will all come to a head eventually. I could go on, but I'm sure you get the point. For how much it costs I'd say this game is a steal, and definitely worth buying.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2015
												Honestly I'm very happy on the witcher 2, it has so many improvements from the first game. On the other the story ending seems extremely rushed, a 4th act would have made this from a great game to an instant classic.The story continue to be amazing however the use of "ploughing" nagged me something awfull.The Combat is by far the best of all 3 games, being challeging and so bloody rewarding that forced me to change style multiple times in the game in order to become just that little bit more effective which makes it even more rewarding when beating each challenge that geralt faces. The first and epsecially the third games don´t do this to nearly as great an effect imo.The alchemy system is not nearly as good imo with potions and especially oil lasting way to short cause of a bloody upgrade tree, I will take my Aard, Igni and the Quen upgrades thank you.Grachics are still extremely good even 4 years down the line however it seems that cd-red took of bit more than they could chew with quite the few grapichs glitches even in the "enhanced edition" Which just leaves me with my biggest complaint! Since I don´t want to spoil the story I will just say the ending(s) feel super rushed and it´s just one gaint infodump that leads up to a gaint war that in the witcher 3 isn´t played up nearly as much making it super anti-climatic. Also as I said the game really could have gone with a 4th act as the games ending again feels aprupt.Note: This game is quite a bit shorter than the witcher 1 and 3 as seen here:Witcher 1: 50 hours (50% of sidequests)Witcher 2: 30 hours (about 60-70% sidequests)Witcher 3: 200 hours long if you do every little thing.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												Seriously, this game is incredible. There are almost no issues with it.Pros:+ Massive, and I mean MASSIVE game world+ Because it's based on a series of equally brilliant novels, the story and the depth of the world could go toe-to-toe with LotR, and it makes TES look like Minecraft+ Smooth gameplay, very fluid controls and combat+ Incredible graphics+ Runs perfect frame-rates, provided you have the sufficient hardware, and almost never crashes (Windows 8 has some issues though)+ Literally hundreds of hours of quests and side-missions+ Brilliant animation and voice acting+ More like an RPG than a lot of RPGs, even though this technically isn't an RPG; combinations of spells, weapons, traps, and allies make it feel almot as if Geralt isn't a pre-set character.+ Soundtrack is mesmerising and very fittingCons:- Menus and inventory a little clunky- Map needs some work- Can have random difficulty spikes, and times where you have absolutely no idea how to progress with very little help from the gameBuy this game. Just do it. You will not regret it.

When I bought this game, I straight played it on DARK mode and did a 2nd run on INSANE mode which was really INSANE in some part of the game. So my view of combats gameplay is solely base on those 2 levels of difficulty.A must have game for sure.easy 10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												BIG RECOMMENDATION!If you like real time action RPG fantasy games that is. One of the few non open-world games I've truly enjoyed from start to finish.Piecewise linear world, fairly big levels though, and a linear storyline you have to follow, but you can follow at your own pace, and it has enough side quests to keep from being monotonous. It is not open world, but it almost feels openworld. At the current pricepoint it is a steal, and easily shames most $59.99 new releases focused on the console market. This was a PC game first, and a console game second, meaning us PC gamers got an intelligent game with excellent keyboard mouse controls.There are two divergent and exclusive middle-game quest lines, so you have to replay pretty much the whole game at least once to see it all and do it all. I am going to take the time to go back and complete the second line.The quickplay arena mode is fun for practice and when you want some quick hack and slash, which you can abandon and walk away from when dinner is ready to come out of the oven.Personal quirk: one thing kept breaking the immersion for me: the voice actor for your character (Geralt) is the same voice actor who played Cal in Independence War 2, a game I have replayed at least six times; so everytime he speaks I think I am in space blasting spaceships, not in a forest hunting evil creatures and gathering herbs...I dearly hope they develop a sequel someday... HOLY CRAP, just went to duckduckgo.com and there is a Witcher 3 coming Spring 2015, and open world too  YEA!!!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
												While The Witcher 2 is a fun game, it takes a bit of time to find the enjoyment in it. It's unique combat made me dislike it at first, but eventually I came back to it and finished the game. I went on to start another playthrough too. It becomes a very rewarding game, much like dark souls in the way that you feel a sense of accomplishment in defeating your enemies, and with the difficult turned up it can be a challenging game. Even on easy difficulty it can be challenging for newcomers. With the price so low, it is still worth buying given that even though it is about 3 years old it still looks good and is fun to play. I can't wait for The Witcher 3 to come out.
